SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANTHONY
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: -I inform the House that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is unwell and that I am acting as Prime Minister until Mr Fraser recovers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) deplores the failure of the Government to list the arguments against construction of the second close-spaced runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport on displays erected this week in passenger terminals at the said airport , and
(2) calls upon the Government to cease presenting one-sided arguments at public expense and calls for an accurate presentation of the arguments both for and against construction of the said runway.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Goodluck proceeding to give a notice of motion-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Franklin will resume his seat. The notice is out of order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) expresses its concern about the developments in the field of genetic engineering and related medical research;

(2) deplores the fact that experimentation and research have been allowed to continue without sufficient community debate about the ethical, legal, social and moral ramifications both for those subjects involved in the experimentation and society as a whole;
(3) believes that the National Health and Medical Research Council should report to Parliament about these issues rather than compiling reports without prior consultation with the community; and

(4) supports the calls by other prominent Australians such as the former Governor-General, Sir Zelman Cowen, the chairman of the Australian Law Reform Commission, Mr Justice Kirby, as well as other civic and community leaders, to properly debate to multifarious legal, ethical, social and moral problems which arise from this research.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Member for Wills be granted 3 weeks leave of absence to enable him to campaign in the seat of Flinders on behalf of the Leader of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House notes with concern the recommendations of the Davidson Committee to charge for local calls on a time basis, and calls on the Federal Government to reject this recommendation as discriminatory against consumers, particularly the housebound and those on low incomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the particular circumstances of the Australian priest, Father Brian Gore, who is being subjected to a campaign of intimidation by the repressive Marcos regime in the Philippines. I ask the Minister: Will he advise the House what action our Embassy in Manila has been able to take to protect Father Gore from attacks and accusations by this regime? Will he ensure that Father Gore is given continuous help, advice and legal protection by our diplomats in the Philippines? Will the Minister further assure the House that he will make it very clear to the Marcos regime in Manila that if the outrageous persecution of Father Gore does not cease then the consequences for Australian-Filipino relations, including economic relations, will be very severe?

—There have been reports in the media claiming that the Government of the Philippines will soon file murder charges against both Father Gore and an Irish priest allegedly for having ordered the killing of a local town mayor. At present Father Gore is on bail in his own parish in Oringao facing charges relating to the possession of explosives and inciting to rebellion. The Philippines authorities have yet to confirm or deny the accuracy of these reports. We have indicated to the Philippines Ambassador, the embassy in Canberra and the authorities in Manila that we have, of course, legitimate consular interests on behalf of Father Gore for his protection and welfare as an Australian citizen. We have asked to be kept fully informed of all developments. The Department of Foreign Affairs has been in constant touch with Father Gore's parents since the first events of the case. I am happy to inform the House that an embassy official will leave Manila today to attend the court hearing which is scheduled for tomorrow in Kabankalan and to ensure that Father Gore's interests as an Australian citizen are fully protected.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the Minister to the closure of the Australian embassy in Beirut during the recent crisis there. I ask the Minister: With the apparent improvement in the security situation in the Lebanon will he review his earlier decision to suspend the operations of the Australian embassy in Beirut? Will the Minister not agree that Australia's interests in the Lebanon warrant the early return of our resident mission?

—I am sure that honourable members will recall the circumstances which led to the closure of our Embassy in Beirut in June this year. Violence in the city, including attacks on diplomatic missions and then the military advance by Israel stopped the small Australian resident mission from doing its job effectively. Its functions were, therefore, transferred to Damascus where the Ambassadors to Syria and the Lebanon remained in residence where they could operate most effectively. Since then the Ambassador, the Charge d'Affaires of the Beirut embassy and several other staff members from the Damascus embassy have made regular visits to Beirut to assess the general political and security situation, to oversee Australian property and to maintain contact with our locally engaged staff in Beirut. I have been encouraged by the fact that the Lebanese Government has made considerable progress in restoring law and order. The Australian Charge d'Affaires was able to return to Beirut on 20 October. Having received his report, I am happy to be able to inform the Parliament that the Australian embassy in Beirut will be resuming operations this week.

—Has the Acting Prime Minister seen the statement by the outgoing Liberal Premier of South Australia that unemployment was the chief cause of his defeat and that the election result was 'a very salutary lesson for Mr Fraser'? In view of this statement does the Acting Prime Minister still maintain that the election was fought on State issues and had little to do with Federal politics?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —There seem to be a lot of statements about the South Australian election. Indeed, the Australian Labor Party tries very hard to claim the result as a major victory. I think it is a pyrrhic victory. The Labor Party has not even got a majority yet; it seems that it will be governing with a minority. One can hardly claim that as a great victory. The facts are that the South Australian election-I think the honourable member for Wills made the statement- was fought on South Australian issues. The election certainly had nothing to do with Federal issues. Even if it did concern Federal issues, the result is not very convincing.

—I refer the Acting Prime Minister to his Press statement of 6 October in which he stated that the Government had accepted the recommendation of the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia that sites near Adelaide and Brisbane be further evaluated for the establishment of a uranium enrichment industry in Australia. Will the Minister be contacting the new State Government to ensure that South Australia will still be considered in the feasibility studies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —I really would not want to waste my time by talking about the uranium issue to the Australian Labor Party. One finds it very hard to get a convincing point of view out of the Labor Party on whether it wants uranium development or whether it does not. The South Australian Government has not made up its mind about uranium enrichment. Although it did make a rather qualified statement that it would allow uranium development to proceed in South Australia, particularly at Roxby Downs, it has reserved its position on uranium enrichment. If the South Australian Government wants to disqualify South Australian sites from consideration by the UEGA study group which is now doing a commercial evaluation it can. If it does disqualify South Australia, the only other site that looks likely is in Queensland.

—Has the Minister for Industry and Commerce seen reports that the Acting Prime Minister called yesterday for a reduction in industry assistance-at a time when others are calling, for instance, for across the board quotas on imports for three years in the present grave situation? Does he share the Australian Labor Party's concern at the vast numbers being retrenched in manufacturing industry right now owing to the wrong economic policies being pursued by his Government and the worsening effect on this situation which will result from the Acting Prime Minister's reported statement? What is the Government doing about these proliferating retrenchments?

—I have, of course, seen the statement referred to by the honourable member. The Acting Prime Minister was referring to the package of proposals which have been pursued since the Prime Minister put down a program for international co-operation in the whole field of trade. There was nothing new in what was put down. The underlying factor is that we-the Prime Minister, the Acting Prime Minister and others-have said at all times that in no way would Australia act unilaterally. What we are seeking to get, in concert with our trading partners, is a more liberal trading world. But we are not going to oversee the demise of Australian industry by acting on our own.

—I refer the Treasurer to recent sales of government securities and ask: Has there been any change in selling patterns, particularly to non-bank investors? Has the Government considered sales to be satisfactory, particularly as an indication perhaps to lower interest rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can inform the honourable member for Barton that the progress the Government has made so far this financial year with the sale of government securities not only has been highly satisfactory but also has produced a number of quite different patterns from what has prevailed in earlier years. So far this financial year we have succeeded in selling about $2,677m worth of government securities to the public. In the same period in 1980-81 we had sold only $597m. There has been a particularly strong take-up by the non-bank public where the sales have been $1,825m compared with only $218m in the same period last year. We are well on the way to achieving the monetary projection that was set out in the Budget Speech, and that remains a very important element of the Government's overall economic policy. Success in controlling the rate of growth in the money supply remains the single most important element so far as our anti -inflationary strategy is concerned. It is interesting to note that so far this year sales of Australian savings bonds, which are particularly welcome in a monetary control sense because they go exclusively to the non-bank public, have been much stronger than in earlier years.

ANSWER.PARA: The other two points that need to be made are firstly that the new tender system for the sale of Commonwealth bonds is infinitely superior to the systems which it replaced and secondly that there has been a very heavy investment by Japanese institutions into Australian bonds and semi-government securities. That has also played a very major role in the take-up of government securities which occurred during the September quarter of this financial year. As honourable gentlemen will know, the September quarter of a financial year is normally the time at which sales of government securities and inflow of private capital are weaker. This year the reverse has proved to be the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Health to his reply to my question on 28 October when he said that I do my sums carefully, that I was being unkind about Medibank and that he saw some encouraging movement. When the Minister looked at the 1981-82 annual report of Medibank Private was he given explanatory notes which explain that the so-called encouraging movement amounted to Medibank being insolvent or, in other words, an undeclared bankrupt in South Australia as at 30 June 1982 and being almost insolvent or similarly bankrupt in New South Wales and Western Australia? Now that the Minister has had more time to examine the report can he tell people who are members of the fund that financially it is either dead or dangerously ill in some States and outside Victoria has not the reserve requirements to meet an epidemic of even minor proportions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly examined very carefully the report on the Health Insurance Commission before presenting it to the Parliament. I acknowledged to the honourable member for Fadden that the remarks he made on an earlier occasion were factually correct. However, I did say on that occasion that I thought he was being a little unkind to the Commission and the management of Medibank Private because they had taken a number of steps which had improved the financial position of Medibank over the year in question. This is certainly true . I am fully aware that the levels of reserves in some of the States are not equal to those that occur in most of the private funds at this time. I have also visited the South Australian office and spent some two or three hours discussing with the management the precise situation in that State. I am confident that the management is of high quality. It is my concern to look at ways and means by which this government-run body, which has high levels of costs compared with private enterprise insurance funds, can compete adequately in the market place.

ANSWER.PARA: I have indicated that I have under way on this matter a study which is looking in great detail at the structure of the HIC. But I would merely emphasise that any government body which is forced, under the rules to operate according to public sector guidelines, to pay public sector superannuation rates and to follow public sector industrial relations practices will not be able to compete adequately with private enterprise without some special support. My objective, on behalf of the contributors, on behalf of the staff of Medibank Private, for whom I have a particular responsibility, and on behalf of the Commission and the management which have been doing a good job in improving the situation of Medibank Private, is to come forward with proposals to address these very real issues. But I point out to the House that it should take this matter as a good example of the need to be wary of any further encroachments by the Government on private sector activity. The policy of the Australian Labor Party in this regard is to transfer all of this activity into the public sector, necessarily at higher cost to contributors and taxpayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a question to the Treasurer. Does the Treasurer agree that , in these difficult economic times, it is in the national interest that the Parliament have access to the broadest possible range of information, especially information of a statistical nature and information that might be characterised as official forecasts? If he agrees, could he inform the House why statement No. 2 of the Budget Papers did not contain certain important information this year on such matters as Department of the Treasury forecasts on work force growth and on the unemployment outlook, as it has in the past? Is it correct that the only information on this sensitive subject of employment published in statement No. 2 was the figure for average numbers of recipients of unemployment benefit, a figure demonstrated on Budget night by my colleague, the shadow Minister for employment, to be patently incorrect? Why were more important forecasts such as the expected rate of growth in employment not in the statement? Is it correct that statement No. 2 presented to Parliament does not represent the full and considered view of the Treasury Department but is, in fact, an edited version of its submission, the editing having been undertaken by a member of the Treasurer' s political staff, Professor John Hewson? Will the Treasurer, in the interests of informed national debate on the real state of the economy, table the original unedited Treasury Department draft of statement No. 2?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose the first observation I should make about that question is that apparently the Opposition wants to have it both ways. A few weeks ago when the honourable member for Wills was trying to embarrass me on the subject of employment forecasts, by quoting some thoroughly innocent and innocuous remarks made by the head of the Treasury to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure a few months ago, he tried to establish that all of the documents presented to the Parliament, including statement No. 2, are not in fact Treasury documents but are in fact the documents of the Minister and of the Government. Now, by implication, the honourable member for Blaxland is trying to call me to task simply because-and I quite freely admit this-I go over statement No. 2. I do not uncritically accept Budget statements that are presented to me by my Department. I think I would be failing in my job if I did.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me also make it quite clear to the honourable member for Blaxland that I will examine statement No. 2 for this year's Budget, particularly in relation to forecasts regarding employment and unemployment levels, to see to what extent the practice adopted on this occasion differed, as alleged by the honourable member for Blaxland, from the practice adopted on earlier occasions. I would certainly agree with the honourable member for Blaxland that, at all times and not only at a time of economic difficulty, it is important that the Parliament have in its possession and be provided with as much statistical information as is possible. I think it is also important, out of fairness to the people in the Treasury Department and other departments who prepare this information, to recognise that the information is in reality not always in the nature of forecasts but is the best projection that departments and officials can provide to the Government at any given time. Quite often some of the projections that are provided in good faith by departments lead, because of changed circumstances , to their being unfairly accused and to the Government's being unfairly accused of misrepresenting the position. I will examine what the honourable member has said and I will see to what extent statement No. 2 on this occasion differed from statement No. 2 on earlier occasions.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CLOSER ECONOMIC RELATIONS WITH NEW ZEALAND

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Trade and Resources say what stage has been reached in the negotiations for a closer economic relations agreement between Australia and New Zealand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable members know, negotiations have been going on since 1980 for closer economic relations between Australia and New Zealand. In June this year a draft report was released to this Parliament and to industry for consideration. The reaction of Australian industry to that draft report was that in principle it believed in the idea but there needed to be some further modifications. As directed by the Government, I had further discussions with the New Zealand Government the week before last and concessions were made on two items of irritation to Australian industry, particularly manufacturing industry. These were the rate of entry into the New Zealand market, including the way in which New Zealand gave access with its import licensing system, and the elimination of export incentives. In both of these areas considerable additional progress was made.

ANSWER.PARA: Those proposals were then presented to both governments. The New Zealand Government has now accepted the package and this morning my Government looked at the proposals and accepted them. There will be an announcement made tomorrow in the Parliament spelling the proposals out in more detail. This is a most historic occasion: We are now witnessing the gradual, predictable and programmed freeing of trade between our two countries over a period of years. We want to see a minimum of disruption to industries on both sides. I believe the majority of Australian and New Zealand people believe it is in the long term interests of both countries to have maximum commerce between our two countries so that we can capitalise on the resources of both.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Why has the Government not yet referred to the Temporary Assistance Authority a reference for an inquiry into the level of assistance to John Lysaght (Aust.) Ltd and Tubemakers of Australia Ltd so as to ensure that these two companies will be able to continue to operate at full production and not have to lay off staff? Is the Australian steel industry continuing to dismiss staff because of the Government's totally unsatisfactory response to the last TAA report on the steel industry? Will the Government again refer the question of temporary assistance for full steel products generally to the TAA in order to overcome the present disastrous situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last week or so requests have been received from John Lysaght. This means, of course, that the normal practice is being followed; namely, questionnaires have been sent to the company and we have asked it to complete those questionnaires expeditiously. Other elements of the industry have to be advised. Their responses will be evaluated and I will then consider whether a request to refer the matter to the Temporary Assistance Authority should be granted. It will be recalled that, because the industry was in difficulty some months ago, the Government referred matters to the TAA. The Authority found that increased imports were not the major contributing factor to the difficulties being experienced.

ANSWER.PARA: What is happening in Australia is not unique to Australia. There are major retrenchments and plant closures in many countries. Despite the fact that the TAA reached this finding, the Government felt that the industry could be vulnerable to further increases in imports and so it imposed, as will be recalled by the honourable member, tariff quotas with 150 per cent duty on any increase over the 1981-82 levels. The Government had to consider the effect of increased protection for steel on downstream industries. To accept the proposition that the decision was irresponsible is not to take account of the findings of the TAA itself. Whilst the immediate situation referred to by the honourable member is of very great concern, it is of particular concern and even greater importance to create circumstances conducive to sound long term development. The Government naturally is giving careful consideration to what should be done in this respect. We will have the Industries Assistance Commission report and the views of the newly formed Steel Industry Advisory Council. I reiterate: I am awaiting the responses to the questionnaire and awaiting the reactions to other elements of the industry before I make the decision of whether or not to make a reference.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment . What action will the Commonwealth take following last week's meeting of the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the last meeting of the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council dealing with the marine park affairs of the Great Barrier Reef which was attended by my colleague, the Minister for Science and Technology, and me as convener, the Press attributed certain statements to the Premier of Queensland. That was one of the few occasions on which the Press has misreported the position because quite obviously the Premier of Queensland would not distort what really happened. The Press reports seemed to indicate that the Premier of Queensland had taken the initiative in getting the meeting to agree to declare the remaining sections of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park-that is the far northern section, the Whitsunday area and the Townsville area-as a matter of urgency. That is not quite the truth because the initiatives came from the Commonwealth Government. Firstly, a vastly increased amount of money was allocated in the Budget. Secondly, we took the initiative at the ministerial council meeting in May to ensure that the remaining areas were declared as soon as possible. In September, my colleague the Minister for Science and Technology , in my absence, tabled in this Parliament the results of the communique of that meeting and indicated that we would be pursuing as a matter of urgency the declaration of the remaining areas. So to sum up, the truth of the matter is that the remaining areas of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park will be declared together as a matter of urgency due to the initiative of the Commonwealth Government.

ANSWER.PARA: We put to the ministerial council meeting last Friday our plans as to how and when the declaration should be made. I think that my colleague the Minister for Science and Technology, as a result of excellent advocacy, persuaded the Queensland Premier and the Queensland Minister to accept our proposals to accelerate the program, so much so that the meeting agreed as a matter of urgency to have the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority come up with a proposition for our next meeting in March of next year wherein the boundaries for the areas will be specified taking into account the sensitivity of certain reefs, particularly in the far northern area, and also taking into account, as was done in the declaration of the Cairns and Cormorant Park sections, the need to ensure that the cities of Townsville and Mackay are not unduly discriminated against in regard to areas which contain no reef and which are required by local people for shipping and recreational purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Defence, follows a question asked by the honourable member for Canning a couple of weeks ago in respect of when a ship would be home ported at Cockburn Sound, to which the Minister replied that he was looking at speeding it up. I also refer to statements the Minister made recently at a seminar in Western Australia that this matter was still being looked at, although it looked more difficult. Is the Minister aware that of the combat vessels of the Royal Australian Navy there are 12 destroyers, 6 submarines and 14 patrol boats home ported on the east coast compared with one patrol boat in Western Australia? Is the Minister aware that in the 1977 election campaign his Government promised that two destroyers and two submarines would be home ported in Cockburn Sound by 1980? Will the Minister now guarantee that next year a destroyer will be home ported in Western Australia? Will he also give an assurance that the originally intended deployment will be incorporated within the current five-year rolling program? If not, will he undertake to make a detailed statement to the House on the reasons for the failure to implement past promises on this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted with this new-found interest in defence that the Opposition seems to have now. I have had a question today on defence and a matter of public importance concerning defence is listed. Things must have been a bit quiet in the echelons in the Labor Caucus this week. I am delighted too that the honourable gentleman read the remarks I made at Port Hedland. Had he done so with a little more precision than seems apparent he would have realised that in 1983 a significant number of Royal Australian Navy vessels not only will be operating in and around HMAS Stirling but also will call at a number of ports in Western Australia. A number of exercises will be run throughout the year. The point is-Mr Speaker, you as a Western Australian would know this-that over in Western Australia there is a very real interest in defence issues, and the Government has been giving attention to the way by which we can show our presence there.

ANSWER.PARA: Learmonth will be completed this year as an Air Force base. Indeed, only a few weeks ago there was a very worthwhile deployment of Mirage aircraft to that base to test the extent to which the facilities were adequate for the purpose. This year we are commencing work on the construction of Derby Airfield. In the general discussion at Port Hedland there was quite apparently a concern to know that adequate emphasis was being placed on the presence of all the units of the three Services and personnel in the west and in the north of Australia. With respect to home porting, as I responded a few weeks ago to the honourable member for Canning, the intention of this Government is to home port there additional Royal Australian Navy vessels as soon as adequate residential facilities for the naval personnel concerned are available. My advice is that probably that will be towards the end of next year. The important part of the whole subject is not just their being home ported there but their operating out of Western Australian ports. Indeed, in 1983 they will be doing that very extensively.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Primary Industry advise the House whether a sheep slaughter bounty is to be introduced in Victoria for drought affected areas and, if so, when, and by whom?

—I am unable to advise the honourable member for Bendigo that Victoria has taken up the Commonwealth's offer of a $3 a head sheep slaughter subsidy. The Victorian Government has what it calls a drought committee that is supposed to be reviewing this matter from time to time, month to month or whatever. Regrettably, when the matter has been before that drought committee either a majority has not recommended acceptance or the Government has not taken up the issue seriously. As I understand it, the Victorian farmers and graziers certainly want it and their organisation is seeking it. The fact is that the Premier of Victoria and his Government have stubbornly refused to introduce it. Therefore this has caused some difficulty for the farmers and graziers involved and sheep are being slaughtered without the benefit of the assistance that the Commonwealth generously offered as part of a total package to assist in ameliorating effects of this drought.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that during the last 12 months tractor imports to Australia have increased by in excess of 6,000. Is the Minister aware of plans conveyed to employees of the International Harvester company to the effect that they can expect their employment to terminate totally within the next six months, meaning a loss of a current 680 jobs in Geelong and a total loss of job opportunities in excess of 2,400, which is the normal employment factor of that company? Does the Government intend to do anything at all-other than to offer unemployment benefits to these people, as the Minister indicated in a telegram to me two weeks ago-in order to try to maintain the job opportunities in an area where alternative job opportunities do not exist?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member, as he has indicated, is aware of the response that I felt bound to make to him in view of the representations he had made in regard to International Harvester Australia Ltd's difficulty. The Government is well aware of International Harvester's significant position in both the truck and agricultural equipment industries and its importance as a major employer in both Geelong and Dandenong. The present difficulties of International Harvester arise from a number of factors, including the situation of the parent company overseas, severe competition on the Australian market, lack of competitiveness and, frankly, reduced sales of agricultural equipment because of the drought. As a result the company is heavily in debt, is carrying a high interest burden and is in need of an injection of further funds to enable it to carry on. Although the honourable member assumes that all will be laid off, and bearing in mind the judgment of Mr Justice Beach, we still have the reality that a petition to the Victorian Supreme Court calling for the winding up of International Harvester is described by the receivers as a protective device not affecting the company's desire to restructure its operations to enable continued trading.

ANSWER.PARA: At this stage I have nothing further to add in response to the representations that the honourable member made. For those who have indicated that the Government has not been prepared to assist International Harvester in the past, I remind honourable members that the company itself received $2.8m under the agricultural tractors bounty scheme and $2.2m under bounty arrange- ments applying to components for heavy commercial vehicles in 1980-81-a total of $5m from this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. I ask: Did John Lysaght Australia Ltd export 329,000 tonnes of galvanised sheet steel and coil in the year ended 31 May 1982? Did imports of competitive products in the same period amount to only 275,000 tonnes? Has the recent imposition of steel quotas enabled Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd to raise the price of JLA's feedstock? If the answer is yes, what does that do for JLA's competitiveness? Do rising steel prices affect the competitiveness of other steel users such as motor cars, white goods and farmers? If so, in what way does it affect them?

—The flow-on consequences of additional protection, which were referred to in my earlier answers, are, of course, relevant to the question asked by the honourable member. I have nothing to add to what I said earlier. I am weighing this matter up, following a request from John Lysaght. I pointed out particularly what the flow-on consequences would be. The Prime Minister, in greater detail some weeks ago, did exactly the same thing. The matters the honourable member raises are worthy of consideration and have been uppermost in the Government's mind as it has sought to find its way through assistance to steel workers and the steel industry in general without creating havoc to end users.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RESERVE BANK OF AUSTRALIA: STATUTORY RESERVE DEPOSITS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to the continuing stalemate of some three months' duration between the Government and the Reserve Bank Board as to whether the Reserve Bank Board will fulfil the Government's undertaking in the Budget to the effect that the equivalent of one per cent of statutory reserve deposits held with the Reserve Bank of Australia would be released as additional funds for housing. Will he state the nature of this opposition that persistently comes from the Reserve Bank Board and will he, to terminate the ludicrous situation which has developed with the Reserve Bank Board persistently thwarting the Government in its policy, adopt the authority under the Reserve Bank Act and direct the Reserve Bank to fulfil the policy commitment of the Government and, at the same time, consistent with the requirement of that Act, table the nature of the disagreement between the Reserve Bank Board and the Government? In any event, when can we expect some firm declaration of intent on the part of the Government and some movement on this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Budget Speech, as the Leader of the Opposition correctly recalls, there was a reference to the possible release of one per cent of the statutory reserve deposit being held by the Reserve Bank. If the honourable gentleman studies the Budget Speech carefully he will observe that the reference was couched in the nature of a statement of intention on the part of the Government to request the Reserve Bank to release the statutory reserve deposit. The honourable gentleman will be aware from his own experience that the question of the level of the SRD and the use of the SRD instrument is primarily a matter for the jurisdiction of the Reserve Bank of Australia, although, as he correctly pointed out, there are provisions in the Banking Act to resolve differences of opinion that might arise between the Government and the Reserve Bank in respect of any matter.

ANSWER.PARA: There are only two things that I can further tell the honourable gentleman at this stage. Firstly, this matter has been subject to a number of discussions between the Governor of the Reserve bank and me. Secondly, I inform the honourable gentleman, because this aspect is relevant to the issue, that, as a result of the measures that were put in place in the statement that I made to the House on 18 March, the volume of money being made available for housing by the banks in particular has increased significantly over the past few months. In a number of cases there are examples of banks finding that the number of applicants for housing loans is not as great as will be required to meet the targets which are implicit for those individual banks in the additional commitment of some $400m which was made to the Government at the time of that statement of 18 March. When I have some further information to give on the matter I will inform the public and the Parliament and, through them, the honourable gentleman.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Administrative Services whether the Government will initiate a program throughout Australia to educate us in the words of our new anthem, Advance Australia Fair. I ask this question because, on the many occasions when we won gold medals at the Commonwealth Games, very few spectators, including myself, knew the words of our new anthem.
—Order! The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. The first part of the question is in order. I call the Minister for Administrative Services.
—I am aware that there are a number of occasions on which people do not know the words of Advance Australia Fair.
—Why don't you set your answer to music?
—Just the first verse.
—Order! The chorus will remain silent.
—I am quite happy to do that if everybody else joins in with me. I will look at the suggestion of the honourable member and reply to him separately .

—My question is directed to the Acting Prime Minister. I ask: In light of the Government's strong affinity with Communist China and its selective antipathy towards Communist Russia, why has the Government endorsed the undermining of the non-communist liner conference shipping services to Australia by the Communist Russia state-owned shipping service, the FESCO Line? What action does the Government propose to meet the substantial increases in freight charges for some ports that will ensue from the collapse of the liner conference services pan-Australia rates? Finally, does the Government's endoresment of FESCO's cut rate shipping services mean that holidaymakers as well as exporters and importers will now regain access to the cut rates of the Russian cruise line service, CTC?

—In recent discussions with representatives of the Japanese East Asia Shipping Conferences, Ministers, including the Minister for Trade and Resources, indicated that the issue of competition to conferences and the possible effects of that competition were matters that properly should be handled in the commercial negotiations between the shipowners and the shippers. The Ministers also indicated to Conference representatives that the Government would be concerned if non-commercial, state-owned competition from the Soviet FESCO Line, for instance, created disruption in the organised Conference shipping services that have served the Australian export industry very satisfactorily over a period of years. In expressing these views the Ministers were mindful of advice by shippers and shipowner representatives that the existing legislative framework of Part X of the Trade Practices Act continues to be appropriate. They did not seek any amendment of the existing legislation, which does provide for the interests of the shippers and the Conference lines by providing facility for the export of Australian goods. But I understand that the Conference lines and FESCO have made arrangements to have discussions in Japan about this matter. It should be noted that the main effect of competition is on the southbound trade to Australia rather than the northbound trade. The Government would not wish to be drawn into the issue unless there was a real threat to the organised shipping services that have served Australian trade extremely well. I hope that the discussions that will take place in Japan between the Conference lines and FESCO will result in a sensible agreement being reached in respect of orderly shipping both to and from Australia.

—During Question Time the honourable member for Blaxland asked me a question about this year's Budget Paper No. 2. In that question he referred to a person on my staff, Professor John Hewson, as, if my recollection is correct, either a political consultant or somebody on my political staff. I think it proper to point out to the House that the use of those words to describe Professor Hewson has a quite incorrect connotation. Professor Hewson holds a chair in economics at the University of New South Wales. He is a former officer of the Reserve Bank of Australia and a former employee of the International Monetary Fund. He was engaged on my staff as an economic consultant. He is a member of the Liberal Party. As a result his political views are very much in accord with my views and those of the Government. I point out to the honourable gentleman that to describe him, in the context of the question asked, as a political consultant was quite misleading. He is primarily engaged as an economic consultant, although his advice on political matters, as is his advice on economic matters, is advice that I greatly respect and value.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in the statement he just made.
—The honourable gentleman wishes to make a personal explanation. He may proceed.

—The Treasurer indicated to the Parliament that in some way I suggested that Professor Hewson was a political analyst or that I attached some sort of improper political connotation in the question. Indeed, the words of the question were:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . editing having been undertaken by a member of the Treasurer's political staff, Professor John Hewson.

Professor Hewson, as I understand it, is attached to the personal office of the Treasurer. That was the clear implication of the question. He is not a member of the Department of the Treasury. He is employed on the Treasurer's own political staff. So, the question is in order. I just felt that it was entirely inappropriate for the Treasurer to come back to make that point when he does not make the point in respect of the editing which we allege has occurred at his instructions, obviously by Professor Hewson, in respect of the Estimates in Treasury Budget Statement No. 2 at page 61. I find it an absolutely lame duck performance by the Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman has now gone beyond the explanation.
—It is an abuse of Question Time to get up and give us this sort of answer.

—I indicate to the honourable member for Blaxland that on a previous occasion I have had to name him and he has been suspended from the service of the House for continuing to speak when he has no call to speak. I indicate to him that if he continues to do this I will have to name him again.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. A lot of latitude is given by you to both the Government and the Opposition on occasions. You know that Ministers have a right of reply at Question Time when they can virtually say whatever they wish. The Treasurer came back after Question Time and sought your leave. In seeking your leave--
—There is no point of order. The honourable gentleman will resume his seat.
—I just think your remarks are unreasonable, Mr Speaker. That is all.
—Mr Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented.

—In the Brisbane Telegraph of 28 October and in last Sunday's National Times there was a suggestion that I had apparently prepared a list-in one case a hit list-of schools which would be denied funding under the Australian Labor Party's education policy. I want to say that this is a misrepresentation. There exists no list of non-government schools which would lose Commonwealth funding under the ALP's policy. As will be revealed on Sunday, the overwhelming majority of the 2,000 non-government schools which still operate below acceptable standards will, in fact, be eligible for additional funds. As for those schools which may be excluded from eligibility for funding, it will be a matter of choice for those schools to decide whether they want to continue to operate at a level which would not justify continued public subsidy. There have been reported remarks also on behalf of the Catholic Parents and Friends Association in Sydney. I want to assure the Association that no school in the Catholic system will receive less funds than it does now and most will be eligible for more.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH-NEW SOUTH WALES JOINT TASK FORCE ON DRUG TRAFFICKING

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members I present volume 2 of the report of the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking entitled: Nugan Hand (Part 1).

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Sir James Killen)-by leave-agreed to.

(1) That this House, in accordance with the provisions of the Parliamentary Papers Act 1908, authorises the publication of Volume 2: Nugan Hand (Part 1) of the Report of the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking, and
(2) That the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Justice Woodward, in his 'Further Report of the Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking', recommended that:

SPEECH.PARA: The evidence concerning Harry Wainwright, Nugan Hand Limited and its associated companies, and the affairs of Murray Stewart Riley (and in particular his associates as revealed in evidence) be referred to appropriate law enforcement bodies for further investigation.

As a result the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) proposed to the Premier of New South Wales that the terms of reference of the Comonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking be varied to enable it to investigate these matters. The Premier agreed to this course. He noted that that investigation should not conflict with the work of the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission and welcomed the Commonwealth's offer to provide any assistance to the Corporate Affairs Commission in its investigation of Nugan Hand.

The Joint Task Force reported in January 1982 on the activities of Harry Wainwright and Murray Stewart Riley and their known financial dealings with the Nugan Hand group of companies. The Joint Task Force recommended, and both governments accepted, that that report should not be made public. All recommendations in that report have been accepted and put into effect by governments. Because of their nature, some of these actions must remain confidential.

The Joint Task Force recommended that the report on Nugan Hand be tabled with certain specified deletions. Views on those deletions have been obtained from Mr Justice Stewart, the Federal-State Royal Commissioner inquiring into drug trafficking, and the Attorney-General of New South Wales in the context of the Corporate Affairs Commission inquiry. Neither Mr Justice Stewart nor Mr Walker had objections to the tabling of the version recommended by the Joint Task Force . Because of the references to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and intelligence agencies the views of the Director-General of security were also sought. He stated:

After careful consideration of the (report), including the references to this Organisation, I believe that from Australia's national security point of view there need be no impediment to the public release of the (report), even in the full, confidential version.

After careful review, and consultation with New South Wales on the Commonwealth 's suggestions for reinstatement of deleted material, a further version of the report has been produced with fewer deletions than recommended by the Joint Task Force. That version is being tabled today. Some material has still had to be withheld to avoid compromising criminal investigations or prosecutions, to protect the privacy of individuals against whom unsubstantiated allegations have been made, and to keep confidential the methodology of investigations. Nothing has been withheld on national security grounds.

The activities of Nugan Hand have been a matter of considerable public speculation. There have been allegations of drug running, arms dealing, and involvement of intelligence agencies. The report will help to shed light on these allegations and to dispel some of the speculation. More work remains to be done by the Joint Task Force, particularly into the involvement of retired United States military and government officials in Nugan Hand from 1977 to 1980. In this regard, following approval by the two governments to a recent proposal by the Joint Task Force, investigators are proceeding overseas shortly to pursue their investigations. The terms of reference of the Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking, under Mr Justice Stewart, are being expanded to enable it to take the work of the Joint Task Force further and to bring into the light of day the broader aspects of Nugan Hand.

The report contains compelling evidence that Nugan Hand, in its many manifestations, paid little regard to the laws of the land and engaged in illegal and criminal activities. In particular, it knowingly laundered and moved money internationally for drug traffickers. Whether or not it was involved in drug trafficking itself is less clear. Even so, it is worth nothing that at page 284 of the report the Joint Task Force states:

While substantial evidence of drug related activity by those involved with the Nugan Hand group of companies was forthcoming, many inquiries simply proved the negative: That allegations made were false or that a 'suspect' client or employee was not involved. With few exceptions, where this occurred there is no reference to the inquiry in the report. In some instances, the view was held that in fairness it should be reported that such a matter had been investigated; for example in the case of widespread rumours respecting well known individuals.
On gun running, at page 490 of the report the Joint Task Force observes:

There is evidence from a number of sources that Nugan Hand was involved, or attempted to become involved, in the international sale of military arms and other weaponry to government and non-government forces, though the evidence is insufficient to accurately define the extent or be certain of the success or otherwise of that activity.

The allegations of intelligence activity and interference in Australia's affairs are not confirmed by the report. Certainly, American citizens who might reasonably be thought to have had an intelligence background were closely involved in the affairs of Nugan Hand in the late 1970s. But the Joint Task Force at page 440 makes the point that:

It needs to be strongly emphasised here that no conclusion should be inferred from that which follows, nor has any conclusion been reached by the task force, about any US or other intelligence agency having a role in the operation of Nugan Hand. It is merely a statement of facts as they are presently understood to exist and a description of the environment under investigation.

The Commonwealth Government has had assurance from the United States Government, at most senior levels, that there was no link between the Central Intelligence Agency and Nugan Hand. Further, the public affairs division of the Central Intelligence Agency on 26 March 1982 took the unusual step of issuing the following statement:

The Opposition Labor Party has produced documents alleging narcotics links between the collapsed Nugan-Hand Bank and the CIA. There are also resurgent charges that CIA engaged in operations against the Labor Government in Australia several years ago. Comment: The Agency rarely comments on such allegations but in this case we emphatically deny these charges; the CIA has not engaged in operations against the Australian Government, has no ties with Nugan-Hand and does not involve itself in drug trafficking.

The Government understands that the United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence has recently been examining alleged CIA involvement in Nugan Hand. The outcome of that Committee's inquiries is awaited.

Against the above background, a short chronology puts events into perspective. Houghton and Hand, who were thought to have intelligence backgrounds, settled in Australia in 1967. Nugan and Hand and others were involved in a number of dubious companies from 1972. Nugan Hand Needham was established on 6 July 1973. That company's name was changed to Nugan Hand Ltd in mid-1974. Hand left Australia in December 1974, severing his formal connection with the Nugan Hand group, but seeming to maintain informal contact. He visited Sydney in July 1975. He rejoined the Nugan Hand group on 16 March 1976. Nugan Hand's involvement in moving money for drug traffickers seems to have begun in November 1975. The influx of retired American military officers to Nugan Hand commenced in 1977 and reached its peak in 1979. Houghton formally joined Nugan Hand in October 1978. Nugan Hand collapsed in early 1980 after Nugan's suicide. Finally, Hand left Australia in June 1980, travelling on a fraudulently obtained passport.

There was apparently a personal relationship between Houghton and Mr Leo Carter , a regional director of ASIO, who vouched for Houghton in early 1972 when he arrived in Australia with an expired entry visa. The Joint Task Force quotes ASIO, on pages 405 and 406 of the report, as stating that it has no record of Houghton and that it is only possible to speculate that Mr Carter, who is now dead, may have known Houghton privately as a restaurateur.

The Government deplores the erosion of business morality as evidenced in the incidence of white collar crime in the 1970s, the consequences of which have become apparent in recent times. The Joint Task Force report, which is based on largely historical investigation, illustrates this breakdown. All the Joint Task Force's holding of information will be provided to Mr Justice Stewart. The Government will act decisively on his recommendations, just as it has acted speedily on the recommendations of the Joint Task Force. I present the following paper:
Drug Trafficking-Report on Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force-Volume 2: Nugan Hand (Part 1)-Ministerial Statement, 9 November 1982.
Motion (by Sir James Killen) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition, like the Government, is very concerned at the erosion of business morality due to the incidence of white collar crime. It is evident from what has occurred in this Parliament in recent weeks that white collar crime has made tremendous inroads into political and public morality in Australia. Of course, Nugan Hand Ltd was concerned with crime . The other serious question for the nation is whether intelligence agencies have been more interested in crime than in intelligence. I emphasise that there have been a number of allegations of involvement by people who have close connection with intelligence agencies or by former employees of such agencies in both domestic and international illegal activities. Intelligence agencies have a direct responsibility to gather intelligence but, the human element being what it is, that sort of cover, that sort of cloak, might be used to give to the same people a chance to engage in massive illegal activities. That is why we seem to be failing to identify the real issue. We know very well the criminals involved, but that begs the question whether people who were legitimately gathering intelligence perhaps engaged in illegal activities to gain funds.

SPEECH.PARA: We should bear in mind that the first report of the Joint Task Force had to be kept confidential. I note that the Government is now saying that the matters which are the subject of the present report will be terms of reference for the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking under Mr Justice Stewart. I put it quite forcibly to the Government that the terms of reference ought to be expanded to include the actions of international intelligence agencies and particularly those people who have been named in this report and elsewhere as being associated with those intelligence agencies. In other words, we should not limit the Stewart Royal Commission to events in Australia. It ought to be given a charter similar to that which has been given to a Senate committee in the United States. A select committee of the United States Senate is now probing the activities of Nugan Hand. It is interesting that the Central Intelligence Agency gave confidential evidence to that Senate committee.

I want to see the Stewart Royal Commission have access to that information and to any other information that the United States Senate committee has because it could reveal a close connection between Nugan Hand, drug trafficking, arms dealing and personnel or former personnel of the CIA. One is not accusing the CIA as such of any activity, but its personnel have certainly come under a searchlight in discussion in Australia and in America as to whether they were entitled to engage in the activities in which they did. In addition to these terms of reference, I think it imperative that the Stewart Royal Commission be given an opportunity to examine not only contraventions of Australian law but also whether there was any international arms dealing. I say that because, earlier this year, I asked the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) whether he was aware that allegations had been made of international arms dealing involving a number of countries and merchant banks such as Ward, Knight and Dunn Ltd and Nugan Hand. The Costigan Royal Commission into the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and other inquiries have clearly identified these merchant banks as being involved in 'gun running'. There is in America prima facie evidence that at least $30m from an arms contract with Argentina was laundered through the Nugan Hand bank in Australia. I say that it is prima facie evidence because it was a verbal arrangement. I wrote to the Prime Minister about this matter and he quite fairly replied that the Reserve Bank's records did not reveal whether any such transaction had taken place. That really means that there is nothing to examine because the Bank does not ask about such transactions. That seemed to be an unfair result. I wrote back to the Prime Minister as recently as August suggesting that in future the Reserve Bank keep at least some sort of register of all the individuals and corporations, including transnationals and multinationals, which may be engaged in arms dealings, so that we will not have such a blank spot or vacant result when we want to find out what has happened from the Australian currency point of view.

It is disappointing to the Opposition to be given what one could call confidential intelligence advice that there was no evidence of any relationship between any members of Nugan Hand and intelligence agencies and then to read this report, which I think is to the contrary. I am talking particularly about matters that have been identified in the report. If one goes through the pages of it one will see that Air America, formerly Civil Air Transport, is identified as a Central Intelligence Agency controlled airline. It follows that people who were involved in that airline would have some connection with an intelligence agency. It was well known that that airline was involved in activities apart from just flying people into and out of airports.

One of the questions that arises is how Mr Houghton came to Australia. If we take a close look at this report we will find that according to Houghton he entered Australia from Saigon in 1972. He was allowed to stay because of a telephone call to one of our Australian Security Intelligence Organisation representatives, Mr Carter, who is now dead. I think it would be well known in intelligence circles-it would be well known, for example, by the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, which certainly had a base in Saigon-that if Houghton was leaving that area for Australia and if he was engaged in intelligence activities for the CIA he would be given a clearance when he arrived in Australia. I think it would be a matter of record that our own intelligence agencies in Saigon indicated to our own intelligence agencies in Australia that Houghton should be allowed in, which he was as a result of a telephone call to Mr Carter. I do not think the whole issue should be put on the late Mr Carter. Certainly our intelligence agencies would have known when Houghton left Saigon. I think that is very clear indeed.
Houghton allegedly had a top connection with the United States Administration. The report states:

On the information available it is probable that Houghton was associated with US intelligence personnel in South East Asia and Australia, and had some type of association with personnel in Australia's ASIO . . .

It was Houghton who introduced Rear Admiral Yates, retired, and Yates who introduced most of those who were associated with the Nugan Hand bank. So we can clearly see some sort of panel of connection between names. I think it is just gilding the lily to suggest here that perhaps we have not got the fine evidence that we need. We should bear in mind that our own Narcotics Bureau had to be disbanded. We should bear in mind that the Wilsons were murdered. We should also bear in mind the activities of the Clarke syndicate and the Mr Asia problem, which were related to illegal transactions involving massive amounts of money.

We come then to the matter which I tried to raise recently and which is called the Volkman case. Volkman, who happened to be just a Commonwealth employee, gave evidence of the most sensational kind in camera to the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs. Quite extraordinarily, he was charged by the Government after that. In the course of an investigation carried out with a search warrant his in camera evidence was taken and copied. In that in camera evidence Volkman talked about massive involvement with narcotics by intelligence agencies. He expanded that evidence later to indicate clearly informants who were also named in the Nugan task force report. He went on to name people who are still, he alleges, in the Customs area and who are still in receipt of money. He talked about plane flights to Alice Springs, which can have only one association with an intelligence agency. He named a person called Cosgrave, who is now dead. In other words, we see again a whole chapter and verse of details of names and facts which I think cannot be contradicted.

The most disappointing thing was that one of our own employees gave this sort of evidence-both in camera and outside obviously, because it now appears that the personnel assisting the Williams Royal Commission were also Commonwealth employees and reported Volkman to their superior officers for giving such evidence-and was the subject of what one might call malicious prosecution by this Government. I cannot understand why. I am not naming any Minister for this. It seems incredible that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) went to the extent of filing an ex officio indictment to bring this man to the courts on the basis of some serious conspiracy when in fact there was no real evidence of such a conspiracy.

I will make my final point to which nobody has adverted. Certainly it ought to be put on the record. It concerns a statement made by Mr Neil Evans, a former bank executive of the Nugan Hand bank, to the entire American television network as recently as 22 September. What does Evans have to say in this interview? In the preamble to the interview the reference is to the collapse of the Nugan Hand bank, the mysterious death of Frank Nugan and the question of illegal currency transactions, big time drug operations and the Central Intelligence Agency. In Evans's statement to the whole of the American network he said:
We were to become--
That is, Nugan Hand-
the paymasters for the CIA around the world.
He was a former bank executive. He continued:
In other words, we were putting ourselves in the position to disperse funds for the CIA to whoever they were directed.
That was his own statement. As the interviewer said Mr Neil Evans was:

. . . given immunity from prosecution, agreed to talk about the Nugan Hand operation on Australian television. From his account and others, the bank had its genesis during the Vietnam War. Four of the original stockholders were Americans who listed their addreses as Air America, Army Post Office, San Francisco. Air America was the CIA airline in Indochina, hauling men and supplies on clandestine missions. And according to former CIA agents, even drugs out of the so-called Golden Triangle, where the borders of Burma, Laos and Thailand converged. Nugan Hand sent Neil Evans to the Thai city of Chiang Mai, the commercial centre of the drug trade. He claims the CIA made millions and used the money to finance some of its secret projects.
Evans said:

The idea was that money would be deposited with the Nugan Hand Bank by the CIA through various channels and also that the Nugan Hand Bank would be the repository for funds coming in from various CIA enterprises, namely drugs and Thailand, marijuana in particular. And that the bank-the Nugan Hand Bank would then be responsible for rerouting that money to an account in America with a New York bank.
The interviewer stated:

Nugan Hand was not your ordinary bank. There were secret numbered accounts and hardly any of its top people were bankers. Many were American civilians and former high ranking military officers with ties to United States intelligence.

The interviewer went on to say that Michael Hand, an American Green Beret who served two tours in Vietnam-one for the Central Intelligence Agency-had disappeared and was now believed to be dead. The interviewer then talked about a person named Edwin Wilson, who is now under indictment for selling arms and explosives to Libya. Honourable members will see that this matter is current in the United States at present. What I am saying is that we now have the Stewart Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking and it would be unfair to limit its terms of reference so as not to be able to inquire into the matters that I have now raised. If the United States Senate can do this surely we can have a commission in Australia to get the same information.

White collar crime knows no levels. It can involve the very highest. If there are intelligence officers who are legitimate in their intelligence operations but who are also acting illegitimately because of illegal extra-curricula activities then they are no longer entitled to the cloak of respectability. They ought to be removed from office. They should not be in either Australian intelligence or American intelligence. It is unfair and dangerous to think that we can have that sort of secret organisation operating for its own financial gain. I know it is virtually a matter of record-it would be if we could identify it-that there has been massive arms dealing with the Nugan Hand bank as a clearing house. We want to get to the bottom of this matter. I think it is unfair that the likes of Mr Volkman and others who want to raise these issues have been so persecuted in the past. I urge the Government to expand the terms of reference to encompass the matters that I have now mentioned.
Debate (on motion by Mr Bourchier) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received letters from the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) and the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Donald Cameron) proposing that definite matters of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion today. As required by Standing Order 107, I have selected the matter which, in my opinion, is the most urgent and important; that is, that proposed by the honourable member for Corio, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The destabilising effect on Australia's defence capabilities of conflicting statements and the indecisive defence policies of the Government.
I therefore call upon those member who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —No subject should have more agreement in this Parliament and the nation than defence. There is no subject on which a long term commitment by the Australian people has been more significant or more continuing . Regrettably, the Australian people's preparedness to spend funds and to commit themselves to adequate defence planning is not shared, nor is it carried through by significant policy actions or responsible administration, by this Government. The state of Australia's defence is probably at its worst since the Second World War. Certainly the understanding of the Australian community-even the defence planners-of the Government's policy cannot be other than confused. The policy reflects short term political opportunism as a substitute for realistic long term planning for the nation's defence needs. In the last couple of years the Government has totally destabilised the whole defence debate in Australia. It has acted in a manner which can only create a situation where, should any threat develop to Australia, Australians will be found to be totally and completely unprepared.

SPEECH.PARA: After this Government came to office it made a statement to the Parliament in November 1976 setting out the defence aims of the Government. That statement was significant. One would have to say that it was well argued in respect of Australian defence. It was never put into effect, nor was it ever treated seriously by the Government in its defence planning. In no year following the announcement of that policy-the White Paper on defence-were the funds allocated to carry through the program. It was finally abandoned in 1980 although it has never actually been abandoned in a statement to this Parliament or in a public statement. It was replaced by what has to be described as a fairly grandiose, emotional and somewhat insubstantial statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) following the Russian invasion of Afghanistan. It was one of those statements large on histrionics and short on practical application, but it did contain commitments to carry out certain defence programs as a consequence of what the Government saw as a changed strategic situation. Those commitments were quickly forgotten. In March 1980 the then Minister for Defence made an expansionary statement in Parliament following those commitments. Among the new programs announced as part of the post-Afghanistan program were additional patrol boats for the Australian Navy, now deferred, and an underway replenishment ship, now deferred. There was a program of advertising to increase the size and capabilities of the Australian Defence Force Reserve. The money was spent, and the program attracted the young people who wanted to commit themselves to Australia's defence. The Government forgot all about the fact that attracting numbers to the reserves does not add to the reserves' capacity. It totally deserted the reserves as far as providing them with the wherewithal, the necessary capabilities and the necessary training arrangements.

That statement also stated that the Government would build up supplies of fuel and other necessary basic stores in order to cope with any defence situation. In the last two Budgets the levels of stores and fuels were cut back to a point at which they are now dangerously low. The Government also announced-I have a quote from the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) as late as a couple of weeks ago- that it would increase the capital equipment program for the defence forces. In fact the 1980 statement said that within five years the capital equipment segment of the defence vote would increase to 25 per cent. Since then the Government has been progressively running away from that figure. It has been trying to suggest that that is not the figure it meant. Certainly its budgetary statements indicate that it did not mean that at all. In fact the last three Budgets since the announcement of the proposed increase to 25 per cent of the capital vote show that the expenditure level of 14.7 per cent in 1980 fell the next year to 14.1 per cent and last year to 10.7 per cent; it is expected to be 13.7 per cent this year. That 13.7 per cent includes a significant proportion derived from the deferment of payments which fell due last year and will cost up to $30m extra this year because of changes in the valuation of the Australian currency as compared with the United States dollar and inflation. This year we will spend $30m of our equipment vote to pay for the Invincible which we did not get and for which the deferments were made.

Last year, because of the devastating effect of the completely ill-planned and ill-considered venture into an aircraft carrier-it should be understood that the Government knew that the Melbourne was coming to the end of her effective life and had probably reached its defence effective life termination by the time it was taken out of service-almost as an afterthought the Governmen announced a program to review the future of the Fleet Air Arm. The Invincible came on the market, a carrier which had previously been rejected by the Australian Navy as not suiting Australia's requirements, and the whole defence capital equipment budget was thrown into the air like confetti and those who could catch some dollar notes on their way down got them.

Last year's capital equipment program was a total disaster for Australia's defence planning and has set back any program of re-equipment by several years. This year the Minister claimed a 21 per cent increase in the capital equipment vote. It is a 21 per cent increase on a total amount which represented under 80 per cent of the amount allocated last year; if we spent nothing we could claim a 100 per cent increase. In fact last year the defence capital equipment vote was devastated by the Invincible and this year's capital equipment vote is now more than 20 per cent below that which it would have been had it been the same as that which was allocated in last year's Budget. A substantial proportion of that which is allocated goes to meet deferred payments.

The Minister, in other statements, said that he believes that a considerable emphasis should be placed on the defence of Western Australia. He made a statement in Question Time about home porting. That is probably the most fallacious and dishonest aspect of government defence policy we have ever seen in this Parliament. In 1977 the Prime Minister made a statement in Western Australia three days before the State election to the effect that within three years home porting would be introduced in that State. Knowing the record of the Government and its Prime Minister, who would suggest that that statement had any purpose but to use defence for electoral purposes? If honourable members think that that was a coincidence, a similar announcement was made four days before the next State election. I asked the then Minister for Defence some time ago whether the announcement would be made again at the next State election. His answer was that he did not know the date of the State election. There was no denial that the two previous statements had nothing to do with defence. They were completely insincere statements designed to bolster the political needs of the Liberal Party in Western Australia. That was what they were all about- politics! The announcement will be able to be made again at the next Western Australian elections because they are due next year and nothing has been done.

We have as a consequence six years of statements and rhetoric about the importance of defence, the Government's commitment to defence and the Government 's total failure to meet those commitments with hard cash and solid planning. It is a defence policy which the Minister and the Government know nothing about, and on a daily basis different statements are made about the defence requirements of Australia. The Government does not know what its defence policies are because it has never sorted out anything other than its immediate political needs. That is the basis of our defence policy as enunciated by the Government. If honourable members look at item No. 33 of today's House of Representatives Notice Paper they will see the most insincere motion ever brought into this Parliament. It was brought into the Parliament as a matter of urgency on 19 August in order to debate the North West Cape issue. It was not designed to strengthen the American alliance; in fact, if anything, it was designed to weaken it by creating divisions in the Australian community and the Australian political scene for the purposes of short term political gain. What did the motion say? The motion said that we will wipe out the local government commissioner at Learmonth. The Parliament spent one day debating that motion in the hope that the Government could score some cheap, shoddy political points because it has no policies on defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you against the North West Cape base?

—The honourable member and I know that that motion was a shoddy political trick. The honourable member does not do himself credit by lending himself to that sort of cheapening of the defence debate.
