Defence is a serious problem; it should be above the cheapness of politics, and the Government should accept its responsibility to the Parliament and to this nation and set out its defence aims and its defence policies and what we will need to carry out those policies. The Government should enunciate them in the Parliament and should not run around the country telling everyone that it will give them this and that when it knows damn well that it will not.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the improved defence of the north-west of Australia. The Minister was over there the other day. During Question Time today he said that the Government will start the Derby Airport this year. He forgot to say that it was programmed to be completed within two years. It has been deferred by two years by this Government. Australia's defence industries are in an absolutely disastrous situation. Only after over a year of fighting has the Bendigo Ordnance Factory been temporarily relieved of the threat of being disposed of. The Lithgow Small Arms Factory has no guarantee of continuance of operation at all; it is under total threat. Maintenance workers employed by private firms contracting to the Army at Puckapunyal have been placed on a three-day week and have no guarantee that they will be employed in future. Some 400 specialised aircraft workers who will be needed for the FA18 program at the Government Aircraft Factories are under threat of retrenchment. The Government Clothing Factory, obviously a necessity in any time of hostilities, is about to be sold to private enterprise, and the capabilities of providing the armed forces with uniforms and other clothing will very quickly dissipate if the thing is not written off for tax losses. We do not know what will happen to the Williamstown Naval Dockyard. It is fairly obvious that the Government is doing everything possible to justify the purchase of its follow-on destroyers outside Australia. Certainly, there is pressure for that.

Recently the contracts for autoclave steam cleaning operatives for Government Aircraft Factories were placed in the United States on the pretext of a lower tender when in fact the Australian contractor was told that certain equipment, the price of which was lower than the highest specification in the program, would not be acceptable to GAF and therefore did not submit a tender, and the Government took the opportunity to place the tender outside Australia. Where is the seriousness in this Government's approach to Australia's defence policy? The more important question is: What is the defence policy of this Government? If it does not know whether it needs an aircraft carrier how does it explain the long term force structure which it is seeking to develop in its defence plan? The one must follow the other. If we say that we have an adequate defence capability to defend the West, where is it? If it has to be transferred from the eastern States, how is it to get to the West? If we need defence industries, why are they being closed down as fast as they can be under this Government's program? Up to 10,000 people in defence industries are currently under threat. The Government is seeking excuses to place further orders outside Australia. Where is the Jindalee program? Where are the air fuel tankers? Where is the policy?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was appointed Minister for Defence in May of this year. So, it was with some interest today that I heard the first question without notice on defence matters asked of me by a member of the Opposition since my appointment. I might add that it was not asked by the shadow spokesman for defence in this place, the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes). It is of interest that the subject of this debate is a matter of public importance proposed in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The destabilising effect on Australia's defence capabilities of conflicting statements . . .
That is the first part of the proposal. I still have to hear which statements are in conflict and with what. The matter proposed for discussion continues:
and the indecisive defence policies of the Government.

I assure the honourable member for Corio who proposed this matter for debate today that there is nothing indecisive about our concern for the defence of Australia. Indeed, the honourable member began by setting out his own attitude towards what he sees as the principal concerns, presumably summarised in his proposal.

I turn now to those three points. I want to look at just what has happened in the area of defence and what are the Australian Labor Party's attitudes and views. Firstly, the honourable member thinks defence is a very serious subject. So it is. So are the consequences of a lack of defence. Those who are responsible, ministerially, departmentally and in the three armed Services have an acceptance of the very serious costs of maintaining an adequate defence not just for Western Australia but also for Australia. Secondly, he said that there should be an agreement between honourable members on both sides of the Parliament. I will say a little about that in a moment.

As far as I am concerned, non-alignment-which is where the Labor Party is heading at the moment-is no policy for honourable members on this side of the House. Any suggestion that there should be a withdrawal from our commitment within ANZUS, with our Western friends and with the Western alliance, would be absolutely nonsensical given the present state of concern that there is about the continued buildup in Soviet aggressive capability and about the extent to which the Soviet Union, over the last 15 years, has spent at a significantly greater rate than the Western powers-certainly the United States of America. It has developed capabilities which, when examined, can be identified only as having an aggressive and not defensive capability. Yet honourable members on the other side of the House are talking about a nuclear free hemisphere. They are moving towards non-alignment, moving away from our arrangements and relationships with the United States. Presumably they are moving away also from our five-power defence arrangements with the United Kingdom, Singapore, Malaysia and New Zealand. So there certainly is no agreement between honourable members on both sides of this House. The Government stands very strongly behind its ANZUS arrangements. I will say a little about that aspect in a moment.

The second point that the honourable member made was that the state of our defences is the worst since the war. What arrant nonsense! In fact, directly the reverse is true. At this stage, Australia's defence capability in the area of sophisticated equipment and in the training and competence of those who are members of the three armed Services is at the highest state ever. Not only is it not the worst since the war but also it is the most adequately prepared defence capability that Australia has ever enjoyed. I pay a particular compliment to my predecessor, the Leader of the House (Sir James Killen), for his role ministerially, and to all those in the central Department of Defence and in the three armed Services who have contributed to that state and to the very high measure of effectiveness that I have found in the time that I have been Minister for Defence.

The third allegation that the honourable member for Corio made was that our defence planners are confused. I acknowledge that, in the planning of defence, there is an abundance of committees. All honourable members will have an opportunity tomorrow when I table the final Utz Committee report on the managerial structures of defence to see how those 90 committees in some ways cause difficulties in simplicity of planning effort. Yet it is essential, if we are to develop adequately and to reconcile as between the competing claims of the three uniform services a single purchasing policy, that there be planned within and between all of the three uniform Services a program which identifies how those scarce defence dollars can be spent.

No one should think that, in the Labor days, the then Government was prepared to allocate greater resources to defence spending. Of course every government has that problem of allocating sufficient resources to ensure that we can meet all aspirations towards augmenting our defence capabilities. But I will not accept that our defence planners are confused. I will accept that, in the development of defence objectives, stratagems and purchasing programs, it is essential that we take account of all the differing points of view of those who are part and parcel of the three armed Services and the central Department of Defence to try to work out the preferred course by which we should set down our acquisition program and our five-year defence plan.

The honourable member for Corio suggested that we have some type of short term political expediency in mind when we talk about individual defence programs. Indeed, completely the reverse is the case. I point out to the House that when we have talked about the acquisition of a carrier we have been talking about having a naval capability at and beyond 2000 or 2010, that is, looking at least 25 years ahead. We have very much in mind in the review that is now being undertaken within the defence area to determine what sort of carrier or other major acquisition program should be developed for the Royal Australian Navy the fact that we do not just want a short term solution. We want to work out the long term structure of the Navy so that we can be sure, when taking into account the three armed Services, that we will be spending our dollars in the way best suited to meet our prime defence requirements.

But, looking at the background behind the matter proposed for discussion one cannot but notice that the Australian Labor Party's new interest coincides with several statements made by the Soviet Union on the 65th anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution. I wonder to what degree the article written by Mr Vladimir Sazanov, is the real genisis of today's debate. I understand that Mr Sazanov is an analyst from one of the Soviet news- agencies, Novosti, which is laying down the line which so many members of the Labor Party espouse with respect to defence. In an article in the Australian of 9 November, we read:
Moscow has paid attention to three reports which came from Canberra almost on the same day: the opening ceremony at the American Omega navigation base . . .

That is a tremendous facility. Those honourable members who have travelled on the Ansett Boeing 737s will know that they have the new Omega navigation capability. They will know what a magnificent instrument that is for the safety of civilian aircraft and also ships. Any suggestion that that facility is in some way a threat to world stability really needs to be well and truly laid at the heels of this Soviet author and the left wing members of the Labor Party who support him. The article continues:
the decision of the Australian Government to extend the range and number of flights of US B-52 strategic bombers over Australian territory . . .

There is no doubt that our co-operation within the ANZUS arrangement is extraordinarily important. Our co-operation with the United States in providing those landing rights at Darwin and low level flights across three States-the Northern Territory, Queensland and Western Australia-is very important in maintaining that Western deterrent to Soviet expansion in the Indian and Pacific Ocean areas. The author continues:
. . . and the visit of James Hartinger, chief of the United States Space Command . . .

There is a suggestion that in some way that visit is a threat to world peace. I do not want to go through all that. It seems to me remarkable that at a time when we have the 65th anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution, we have a display of Soviet military might, and a number of aggressive comments by various members of the Politburo, including Mr Viktor Grishin. We have an article by an analyst in Novosti. All this seems to be the genesis of today's debate.

Let us look at where the Labor Party is going. Let us talk about ANZUS. We all remember that on 13 September 1976 the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), as the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, signed an advertisement in the National Times calling for an independent and non-aligned Australia. The advertisement stated:
We, the undersigned--
The honourable member for Wills being one-

consider that military alliances are a source of international tensions . . . Therefore, we the undersigned, support the campaign for an independent and non- aligned Australia which stands for . . . opposition to non-military alliances, foreign military bases and military interventions.

As I said, the Labor Party is moving towards non-alignment. So much for the Labor Party and any accord that it has with the very determined commitment of honourable members on this side of the House to our ANZUS arrangements. For those who think that example is only in the past, we have Senator Melzer's signing of a further National Times advertisement on 26 April 1980 which stated:

. . . Australia should develop an independent, non-aligned foreign policy, ( including the) removal of the US bases on Australian soil and cessation of Australian military operations under the ANZUS Treaty.
But enough of that. Honourable members will recall that this year John Cain, the Premier of Victoria, wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) stating:
I . . . give you early notice of my Government's policy that it will not permit visits of nuclear powered or nuclear armed vessels to Victorian ports.

We all recall the developments since then. The fact is that there was within the speeches of the spokesmen for the Labor Party a total inconsistency as to what they wanted. Honourable members will recall that there seemed to be four separate ALP positions on the issue. I have just referred to that of the Victorian Premier, Mr Cain. Mr Wran bans visits by nuclear powered ships but allows stops by conventionally powered vessels without insisting on knowing whether they are carrying nuclear weapons. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) apparently opposes visits-I am not too sure what he does now but he did then-by nuclear armed ships but is relaxed about nuclear powered vessels which do not carry nuclear weapons. He insists that Australians should be told if a visiting vessel is carrying nuclear arms. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Lionel Bowen) says that a Labor government will allow visits by nuclear armed ships provided they are simply refuelling and not conducting some staging exercise. The same gentleman is seeking to have some type of nuclear free Southern Hemisphere, presumably banning all American ships, all the deterrents, throughout the whole of the Southern Hemisphere. What arrant nonsense that is!

Without running through the correspondence on the issue, there are frequent references to the Leader of the Opposition's inconsistency on defence. I draw the attention of honourable members only to an article in the Australian of 9 July 1982 by its defence correspondent, William Pinwill, to that effect. We have the fact that we had to introduce in this House the Defence (Visiting Warships) Bill to make sure that the Government's policy of permitting US ships to visit Australia is properly validated and authorised by the Federal Parliament in the exercise of its Federal power. We all recall the communique that was issued after the ANZUS Council's thirty-first meeting in Canberra earlier this year and the comments by Ambassador Walter J. Stoessel, then Deputy Secretary of State of the United States. The communique stated-Walter Stoessel subsequently confirmed this-that the parties to the agreement:

. . . recognized the importance of access by United States naval ships to the ports of its Treaty partners as a critical factor in its efforts to maintain strategic deterrence and in order to carry out its responsibilities under the terms of the Treaty.

I comment on all these things because the Labor Party is demonstrably moving away from alignment. It is moving towards non-alignment. The Labor Party is not prepared to accept the consequences of the ANZUS commitment. I have before me many contributions that identify the extent to which the Labor Party has nothing in common with the Government in terms of developing an adequate defence effort. In contrast, we on this side of the House have increased successively our defence vote. There has been a 148 per cent increase in defence spending since 1975-76. This year defence spending is to total $4.6 billion, an 11.8 per cent increase over last year.

As I explained in the debate in this chamber on the defence estimates, we have not reinstated those items which were deleted when we took the decision on HMS Invincible because we are still to take the decision as to a replacement carrier or otherwise for the Australian defence forces. We do not believe it appropriate to augment in any way the defence vote until that decision has been taken. Within the Department of Defence that decision is well under way. I am advised that it should shortly be taken by the senior committees of the Department. It will then be referred to me. Of course, from that technical appraisal not only of the capability of a carrier but also of whatever aircraft are to fly on it I will be in a position to make a recommendation to the Government and the Government will be in a position to take a decision on it.

Any suggestion that we have cut back on defence spending for anything other than proper and valid reasons to augment Australia's defencive capabilities and to ensure that we are able to meet not only our alliance responsibilities with the United States and New Zealand within ANZUS but also within our five-power arrangements and our independent regional capability is arrant nonsense. We demonstrably are increasing our capability through northern Australia and in Western Australia. This Government is committed not only to maintaining our international obligations but also to ensuring an independent regional capability. I completely rebut the allegations and assertions made as part of this matter of public importance. I believe that the statements made by the Opposition's spokesman on defence are inaccurate. I do not believe in any way that the very significant effort this year whereby defence expenditure will represent 2.9 per cent of gross domestic product moving to 3 per cent next year is anything other than an adequate recognition by this Government of the responsibilities that should properly be accorded to the development of an adequate defence effort by this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented concerning remarks which I made.
—The honourable member may proceed to explain the matter.
—My remarks were about the defence of Australia; the remarks of the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) were not. They had nothing to do with foreign policy.
—There is no misrepresentation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of us were puzzled as to precisely why a Minister with a proven record of incompetence should be put in to run a department that quite clearly is the most administratively complex department that any Minister in an Australian Government has to administer. We who were puzzled by that event had our answer here today. The Minister has been placed in that position not because he has the skills that are necessary for the immediate needs of the Department of Defence but because he has an instinct for the political jugular. There is a requirement for this Government to explain the manifest inadequacies of its defence policies. It cannot explain them, so it will automatically be obliged to confuse the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Today the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) confused the debate, as he has been confusing it since he was appointed, by transgressing in the portfolio of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) in the most incompetent and ridiculous manner. He has been worried about our not pointing to confusion in his defence statements. I will be getting on to some of that confusion in a minute. I ask the House to note the statements that he made about an immediate and grave Soviet threat today because I will go on later to quote statements from him in which he actually repudiated that position about two or three weeks ago. We should not be surprised about that because really this Minister does not know what he is doing. He presides over confusion. Anybody who has anything to do with the Department of Defence knows that that confusion exists-it does not exist within the Defence Department, which the Minister tried to imply, but it exists in the relations between the Minister's office and the Minister and the Defence Department. That is where the confusion exists.

The Minister's Department knows what it wants to do. His Department has had the bipartisan support of this side of the House in what it wants to do. Over the last two years his Department has been destabilised by the attitudes of this Minister and the change of mind of his predecessor. His confusion starts with the strategic assessment. It proceeds through the gluts and bottlenecks in his procurement program, worsened by his continued tinkering with the carrier option , and ends in ridiculous efforts to paper over major inadequacies in the defence infrastructure in our areas of vulnerability in the north and west by reference to United States of America ship visits and joint exercises. The Minister's confusion begins as I said with his strategic priorities.

Until very recently, this Government enjoyed bipartisan support. We acknowledged no immediate threat to ourselves and our region; we all acknowledged that priority was to be given to the defence of Australia and orderly planning attached to it; we mutually agreed that the north and west were our areas of vulnerability; and we concluded that the planning of our procurement and force structures should closely relate to these assessments. On both sides of the House we set off on a sensible course of action-this Government continuing the priorities laid down by the Whitlam Government. What has gone wrong has been the adolescent attention span of Ministers of this Government when presented with the advice of their advisers. They crave, contrary to their advisers' advice, the simplicity of an immediate Soviet threat . They crave, contrary to their advisers' advice, the certainty and security of the old forward defence doctrine when all we needed to do was to plan a force structure to plug into that of our allies-never mind about our need for an independent logistics capability and supply problems.

Part of this process has been involved in the Minister meandering around the countries of South East Asia defining for our allies in South East Asia the nature of the threats to them and to our security. His posturing on issues which are more appropriately handled by the Minister for Foreign Affairs has produced the most amazing backing and filling which calls into serious question the process by which this Minister obtains advice. I will quote from a recent publication of an interview between the Minister and the journalist Peter Hastings as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald some weeks ago. This interview has not received the publicity that it deserves because it reveals the true genius of this Minister and his complete incompetence in this area. Hastings asked:

Minister, when you were in Manila you mentioned increasing visits of Soviet air and naval units to Da Nang and Cam Ranh Bay, and yet a few days later the US Commander-in-Chief Pacific, Admiral Long, said they had levelled off if not fallen.
The answer from Minister Sinclair was:

It's not a great usage, I agree. Anyway, I've stopped saying it because I also saw the commander-in-chief's brief. I made the remark originally because I had been briefed by Admiral Dunleavy in Manila, but of course Admiral Long is his superior.

The public should bear that in mind. What a Minister and the public are obliged to do is not to look for advice from the Office of National Assessment, not to look for advice from the Strategic and International Policy Division of the Department of Defence. What we have to look for is the order of precedence in the United States Pacific Fleet because at any one time depending on that order of precedence the Minister will be receiving advice on the nature of the soviet threat. But the Minister does not leave it at that. He is asked the question:

On the alleged Russian Threat in South-East Asia there is evidence that Hanoi drags its feet on Russian facilities access requests. It regards the USSR as an ally but at the same time does not want to get too close. Now you say Russia is a major destabilising influence in Asia. If that is so, why has it not sought to destabilise Thailand? Why has it apparently restrained Vietnam from seeking to do so?
The answer from Minister Sinclair was:

I had one other motive in referring to the USSR. I think it important for ASEAN countries to work together in defence terms, that it is better they should work at some perceivable threat rather than at very difficult internal political divisions of Cambodia, Vietnam or Laos.

China, after all, is moving away from some of its earlier attitudes, although for how long and to what degree goodness only knows. But our interests lie in trying to get ASEAN countries not just to look at the internal actions of, say, the Filipino forces.
The questioner says:
But they're not. They also look at China.
The Minister replies:
I started off saying I could see no perceivable threat.
He reverses the position he announced today. He continues:
Perhaps in my answers I am a little too anti-Soviet in one sense. I think there is a possible enemy there, as there is in China.
God help us, he has now added China to the list, despite the face that his Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is trying to establish an alliance with them. The Minister for Defence continues:

We would be foolish not to try to develop some collective capability against them . . . However, there is not much merit in an Australian minister rushing around and saying that China's the possible foe, even though Paul Hasluck might have in days gone by.

So in three statements the Minister has reversed his position a couple of times on the Soviet threat and told the Association of South East Asian Nations not to keep worrying about the Vietnamese, as the Government has been inviting ASEAN to do for some considerable time. Instead it suggested to ASEAN that it ought to be developing some sort of collective security effort against the threat which he said in the previous paragraph does not exist. That is the state of this Minister's mind, such as it is, when it comes to defence matters. The problem is that he is concealing, no matter how he attempts to paper over it, very serious inadequacies in the planning of our defence arrangements. There has been a reduction from an amount of 48.3 per cent in non-manpower expenditures in the previous Budget to 45.8 per cent in this Budget. For example in one area, the area which really relates to our readiness, equipment and stores, there is a cut from $256.5m down to $243.1m in this Budget.

The Minister ought to be alerted to the fact that none of the items of expenditure delayed, dropped or cut back by the proposed Invincible purchase have been reinstated. His explanation today is not an explanation. The initial cuts related to expenditures anticipated in the forthcoming year. No matter what the Minister does with a carrier he is not going to entail expenditure now. There has been a massive increase in the forward commitment burden of the Defence Department. It has escalated from $1.5 billion in 1980-81-I am talking in 1979-80 constant dollars-to $4 billion for 1983-84. That is a glut of major proportions that is going to be a problem for him and his successor, whenever his successor comes into office. Into that glut, which affects our capacity to purchase the F18 aircraft, which affects our capacity to proceed with a follow- on destroyer program, to name just a few vital programs he throws willy nilly, without consideration to what strategic purposes it will serve, the purchase of an aircraft carrier. When anyone raises those issues with the Minister all he does is seek to slander. This is obviously what we can expect in defence debates from now on. We can expect no answers to the points that we raise in the same way as I got no answer to the question I asked him this morning. This Minister is not here to do in the Defence Department what needs to be done. This Minister is not here to advance Australia's security. This Minister is here to get this Government over a serious political problem that is a result of developments that it has allowed to occur, particularly as it affects the Western Australian area where the Government has a number of marginal seats because he is well known to have an instinct for the jugular. Unfortunately this is going to be very much to the detriment of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Opposition spokesman on defence matters the honourable members for Corio (Mr Scholes) has claimed that the Government has made conflicting statements on defence policy and that our policy on defence is indecisive. I totally reject his claim. He is totally wrong; he is totally incorrect. The Australian Government's policy on defence is decisive and positive. It is interesting to note that the Opposition spokesman did not refer to one alleged conflicting statement made by the Government. The Hansard record of his speech will show that. Yet he has the temerity to raise in this House today a matter of public importance stating that there are conflicting statements. However, he does not refer to any. The Opposition spokesman, in his speech, did not make one positive statement as to what the Australian Labor Party would do in the defence area. It was all negativism and criticism. There was not one positive element in the Opposition spokesman's statement. He said that the state of Australian's defence was the worst that it had been at any time since the Second World War. That is false; it is wrong, it is incorrect and it is totally misleading. I think it is disgraceful that the Opposition spokesman should make that claim in this House at this time. On the one hand the Opposition claims that it wants a bipartisan policy and on the other hand Opposition members scare the people of Australia with incorrect information.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition spokesman has not proved his case at all. He asked: What are our defence policies? He has heard from the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) who is at the table what they are. He said that the Government is indecisive. What is indecisive about our commitment to buy four guided missile frigates? What is indecisive about the orders placed for the new Phalanx weapons system which is a fully automatic, close-in defence system against sea skimming missiles of the Exocet type. These will be fitted on HMAS Darwin and HMAS Sydney. Is he against that? Is that indecisive? Of course it is not. It is decisive. The Government has acquired harpoon missiles for its P3C Orion aircraft, submarines and frigates. They are a better weapon than Exocet. We did not hear about that today because that is another example of the Government's decisive policies. We did not hear any criticism from the Opposition of our decision to acquire 18 light helicopters because our decisions are positive. The Government has announced that 75 FA18 fighters--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my left have had an opportunity to address the matter. I ask them now to remain silent.

—I was proving how decisive and positive the Australian Government's defence policy was. I was referring to our decision to acquire 75 F18 aircraft, many of which will be assembled and built in Australia with the introduction of new technology and what that means for Australian defence infrastructure. We did not hear today from the Opposition remarks about the $40m for the new PAVETACK system for the F111s. We did not hear about the contract for 10 new P3C Orion aircraft which has been signed. We did not hear about the new Fremantle class patrol boats which are being built. There were many other things about which we did not hear from the Opposition because it knows that this Government is positive about the defence of Australia. I will move on. The Opposition has totally and abysmally failed to prove its case. The Opposition talks of conflicting statements. What a joke! Last week we heard the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) make his statement on the Schildberger show and the rejection by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) of that statement. The Opposition talks of conflicting statements when the honourable member for Wills is about to make a leadership challenge and that is denied the next minute! We do not know where the Australian Labor Party stands on leadership. I will move on because that matter is too political.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—See how they rise to the bait, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—This is a defence debate. What the honourable member has been talking about has nothing at all to do with defence.
—There is no point of order. The remark was made as an aside. The honourable member for Higgins will address himself to the matter under discussion.

—The Opposition talks about conflicting statements. I was pointing out the hypocrisy of the Labor Party in talking about conflicting statements. I will move on to nuclear issues and the matter of warships visiting Australia. The Minister for Defence pointed out that there are at least four different ALP policies on visits to Australia by American warships. By these four different policies I can conclude only that basically the ALP is against the American alliance and against warships visiting this country. Let us look at the North West Cape position. I believe that what the Leader of the Opposition has said about that matter amounts to a veto. After the ANZUS conference and after the discussions of the Leader of the Opposition with Mr Stoessel at the ANZUS conference the demands of the Leader of the Opposition raise serious questions and real doubts as to what his policy is on defence co-operation with the United States.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at where Australia fits into the Western alliance. Australia is part of the Western alliance system. We are part of a system of mutual agreement . Only the Western alliance can muster the array of power necessary to match the growth of Soviet military expansionism in the world. The United States cannot do that alone. Australia takes its part as a middle power in the Western alliance. We have decided where we stand. However, look at the Australian Labor Party. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen), in a speech on 11 August, said:
Australia is part of what is archaically called the 'West'.

In that speech the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has rejected the Western alliance. He is moving the Australian Labor Party to a policy of neutralism and isolationism and the risks that involves for Australia. That is what that policy involves. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is against Australia's participation in the Western alliance. That is set out in that speech for all people in Australia to see. Let me move on to Australia's position. I have described how we fit into the Western alliance. The ANZUS relationship with the United States is vital and is the most important defence umbrella relationship for the country. Australia maintains a defence force which can deal with the lesser situations not involving a Soviet super-power threat. We are capable of an adequate military response. Such a force is a deterrent in the short term to any power other than a super-power challenging us. However, if the situation dramatically changed, if intentions of a potentially hostile power were to become apparent, our defence policy, defence force and infrastructure provide the basis for expansion to match the buildup following any changed situation.

I want to move on to other statements the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has made. There is a total conflict in the Labor Party about these matters. The Labor Party is split. At its July conference it narrowly voted to retain the ANZUS alliance. There is a substantial amount of opinion in the Australian Labor Party in favour of pulling Australia out of ANZUS and out of its relationships with the United States. The only reason the vote went through narrowly at the Labor Party conference in July this year is that the Labor Party is trying to have a patch-up and is trying to present a package to the electorate because it feels that there might be an election. The real situation is that the socialist left is in control of foreign policy in the Australian Labor Party. The defence spokesman of the Opposition has not caught up with the fact that defence and foreign policy are interlinked and are cohesive, as I think the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) recognised in his speech. But he ought to tell the defence spokesman. I take it from the speech of the defence spokesman that he totally rejects the notion that there is any relationship between foreign policy and defence policy. The point is that this Government has coherent defence and foreign policies which it recognises are interlinked in the best interests of the people of Australia. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition said:
It would be naive, and dangerously so, to ask Parliament to base our foreign policy on implicitly trusting the United States.

I take it that the Opposition does not trust the United States. The Deputy Leader has also said that US policy is 'unprincipled and transparent'. I go back to the position on port access which was referred to earlier. When the Australian Labor Party's policy is considered alongside existing policy on the wider Western alliance which I have talked about-the joint facilities, the B52 agreement and the Sinai Multinational Force and Observers contribution-the only possible conclusion that can be drawn is that the Labor Party's objective is the isolation and withdrawal of Australia from security arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BOWEN; COWAN; EDWARDS; FRY; JONES; KEATING; MACKENZIE; SAINSBURY; SCHOLES; SPENDER
PETITION.NAMEIDS: ZE4; VF4; 9G4; GB7; FG7; NH4; BJ7; 8Q7; 5J4; JJ4
PETITION.TITLE: Great Barrier Reef: Oil Exploration
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Great Barrier Reef: Oil Exploration
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of the Commonwealth submits:
That off-shore oil exploration within the Great Barrier Reef Region constitutes a serious threat to the richest and most varied living system on earth.
Your petitioners request that your Honourable House will
1. Prohibit oil exploration within the Great Barrier Reef Region,
2. Declare the entire Great Barrier Reef Region a Marine Park under the Federal Government's Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975,
3. Provide the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority with the staff and resources for effective management of the Region.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Lionel Bowen,Mr Cowan,Dr Edwards,Mr Fry,Mr Charles Jones,Mr Keating,Mr MacKenzie,Mr Sainsbury,Mr Scholes and Mr Spender.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Postal Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows:
1. that Australia as a sparsely populated continent requires the maintenance of a high quality postal service as a vital means of communication.
2. that the Australian postal service meets the needs of all Australians.
3. that any reduction in Australia Post's monopoly power to carry letters for reward will destroy the concept of the national postal service and result in:
increased rates for mail carried outside the capital cities;
a reduction in mail delivery and collection frequencies in non-profitable areas ;
the closure of post offices.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
that the powers of the Postal Commission to carry letters for reward should be strengthened to ensure that the national postal service is retained in the interests of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child and Mr Duffy.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Postal Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That Australia as a sparsely populated continent requires the maintenance of a high quality postal service as a vital means of communication.
2. That the Australian postal service truly meets the needs of all Australians.
3. That any proposal that Australia Post's monopoly power to carry letters for reward be diminished will destroy the concept of the national postal service.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the power of the postal commission to carry letters for reward should be strengthened to ensure that the national postal service is retained in the interests of all Australians.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Dawkins,Mr Scott and Mr Tuckey.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Marine Mammals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Since the Australian Whaling Protection Act, 1980 provides for the banning of importation into Australia of all whale by-products, and
2. The Prime Minister has stated that he and his Government support the International Banning of Whaling,
3. Then consistent with (1) and (2), this Government should immediately legislate to ban the importation of all marine mammal by-products, including the harp seal of Canada, and

4. Through the Australian delegate in the United Nations General Assembly, the Prime Minister should state his Government's support for an International ban on the slaughter of any marine mammal for commercial reasons.
Your petitioners therefore, humbly pray that:
Consistent with Legislation on whaling, this Government should ban the importation of marine mammal by-products, and support an International ban on the slaughter of any marine mammal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cross,Mr Humphreys,Mr Jull,Mr Millar and Mr Thomson.

PETITION.TITLE: Macedonian Language
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth:
(1) That the Macedonian language be used by Government Departments in multi- lingual publications.
(2) That the petitioners urge the introduction of the Macedonian language as a Higher School Certificate (H.S.C.) subject in Secondary schools.
(3) That the petitioners urge the introduction of the Macedonian language in tertiary institutions and that a course be introduced at Monash University in the Department of Slavic Languages.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate action to implement the above measures. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Duffy,Dr Jenkins,Mr Kent and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that U.S., Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
(4) the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will
(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Campbell,Mr Holding and Mr Jacobi.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Student Loans Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the introduction of a comprehensive student loans scheme will:

1. Restrict Access to Education-People from poorer backgrounds will be deterred from studying by the prospect of incurring large debts. These people, if they enrol, will be forced to amass loan debts. Richer students do not face this handicap.

2. Undermine the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme-TEAS should cover the basic living costs of students. Currently the scheme only assists 38% of full- time students and the maximum level of TEAS is a mere $49.67. Government statements indicated TEAS will be further downgraded if loans are introduced.

3. Disadvantage Women-Women students would be disadvantaged by a loans scheme as they have a lesser ability to repay loan debts, because on average women earn less and have a higher unemployment rate.

4. Disadvantage Mature-Age Students-Usually mature age students forego income to study and already have large financial commitments. They could not return to study if it meant incurring substantial debts.
5. Distort Educational Choices-Mounting loan debts would force students into studying shorter courses or not continuing with post-graduate study.

6. Result in Massive Attrition Rates-Students will attempt to undertake extensive part-time work or overload courses to minimise their loans. Increased failure rates will result forcing students to 'drop-out' rather than continuing study and increase their debts.

7. Cause Administrative & Financial Difficulties-Overseas experience shows high default rates will occur on student loans. Government money will be channelled away from TEAS to paying off banks. The government will also bear the administrative burden of pursing defaulters.
Therefore, the proposed student loans scheme will have disasterous effects on tertiary education, which we believe benefits the whole community, not just the individual student.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
The House of Representatives will reject the introduction of a student loans scheme. And your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever humbly pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Dawkins,Mr Kerin and Mr Les McMahon.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the members of the Women's Services of the 1939-45 War not at present considered eligible for Defence Service Home Loans should qualify as 'Australian Soldiers' under the Defence Service Homes Act. They volunteered for service with the Naval, Military and Air Forces, serving wherever they were sent in whatever capacity they were required and yet are refused Defence Service Home Loans.

They took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies which meant to fight His Majesty's enemies, and although not used in actual combat in war zones, they were available for that use and had a sufficiently grave need arisen would have been used, to serve with distinction as have women of other lands.

In accordance with the Acts and Regulations of the period, the women of the Military Forces had enlisted for service anywhere, some of the Naval women to sail in any waters, others with service on warships optional, while the women of the Airforce could have been sent to Papua New Guinea or other territories under the control or care of Australia.

Ex-servicemen of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force who volunteered in the 1939-45 War but were not sent to War Zones are granted home loans. Not to grant eligibility to all Ex- servicewomen of 1939-45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you favourably consider amending the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That all members of the Women's Services 1939-45 War qualify as 'Australian Soldier' under the Defence Service Homes Act for loans because on voluntarily joining the Australian Forces they took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies making themselves available for combat duty in War Zones, and according to Acts and Regulations of the period, the Military woman had enlisted for service anywhere, some Naval women to sail in any waters, with all servicewomen available for service in Papua New Guinea.

As those members of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force of 1939-45 War who were not sent to War Zones are granted loans, refusal to grant eligibility to all Ex-servicewomen of 1939- 45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you amend the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Retirement Benefits: Private Enterprise
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth our concern that:
1. The Income Tax Assessment Act (the Act) and its administration is inadequate in providing retirement benefits for employees in private enterprise.
2. The Commissioner of Taxation (Commissioner) denies deductions necessary to index retirement pensions.
3. Deductions for the self-employed and employed are inadequate.
4. The Commissioner has exercised his discretion improperly by negating a choice the Act allows on investment in government securities.
5. The Commissioner's constant alterations to guidelines and lack of communication has created great uncertainty.
6. The Commissioner is acting arbitrarily, and without proper notice in restricting trustee's investments with employers.
7. The Commissioner seeks to apply new actuarial guidelines retrospectively to July 1981.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, take action to remedy these inadequacies and in particular we pray that action be taken:
(i) To ensure that the Commissioner exercises his discretion only with proper regard to legal principles;
(ii) to ensure that the Commissioner does not delegate to auditors part of his function of administering the Act;
(iii) to enact legislation allowing proper levels of retirement benefits to be provided;
(iv) to ensure that retirement benefits are regulated by a department with a primarily social welfare function.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hodgman and Mr Newman.

PETITION.TITLE: Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that Australia Council funding for the Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland has been entirely cut for 1983.

The Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland has made an important contribution to the cultural and artistic life of the Australian community for the past eight years taking innovative and original theatre to sections of the community who would not normally attend live theatre performances.
The Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland is the only theatre company in Australia which consistently presents theatre of social comment and tours nationally every year.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will resolve to ask the Australia Council to reverse its decision in respect to the Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the present hunt for harp seals in Canada is carried out in a cruel and inhuman manner.
That the population of harp seals has not been clearly shown to be increasing.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government formally call on the Canadian Government to end the harp seal hunt and use its constitutional powers to halt the importation into Australia of products derived from the harp seal, Pagophilus groenlandicus.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That Federal funding of children's services which has been reduced by almost 50 per cent in real terms over the last five years should be restored forthwith to at least 1975-76 level in real terms so that children's services can be more equitably provided throughout Australia.
That Budget allocations for children's services be spent in full for the purposes designated.
That current plans to impose a means test on the users of child care services will place them out of the reach of the bulk of the users and should be dropped forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Manufacturing Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia being employees of Repco Research Pty Ltd and Repco Manufacturing Services both situated at South Gippsland Highway, Dandenong within the Commonwealth electoral division of Holt shows:

1. That the petitioners, representing substantially the whole workforce, offer their unanimous support for the published statements by the Chairman of Repco, Mr Neil Walford, in his address to the Annual General Meeting referring to free trade principles now operating, in which he has unquestionably identified the reason for this country's current decline as a progressive manufacturing nation.

2. The petitioners work for an Australian owned company which has shown a dedication towards the development and promotion of vital industrial arts through training of young Australians and support of the well known Australian innovative industrial skills. Unrestricted free trade principles are being allowed to threaten the progressive and positive attitudes that thrive in this Australian manufacturing company and many others as well. It is these attitudes which will decide in the long run whether Australia will be a nation with a future or whether she will only offer very limited employment opportunities in agriculture and mining only.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the House take action to protect Australian manufacturing industry in the best interests of all Australians.

PETITION.TITLE: National Estate Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of effective Federal environmental protection legislation and urge that suitable legislation be enacted immediately.

Your petitioners are concerned that National Estate areas such as South West Tasmania, the Great Barrier Reef and the Western Australian Jarrah Forests cannot be fully protected until adequate legislation exists and is enforced. Your humble petitioners therefore call upon the House of Representatives to ensure that all provisions of the Heritage Act and the Environment Impact of Proposals Act are fully complied with in respect of National Estate Areas. In particular your petitioners call upon you to adopt the recommendations of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment on South West Tasmania. Your petitioners believe that this is a national issue and must be resolved by the action of the Federal Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sandmining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology and environment of the Island.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the Register of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 take into consideration the protection of the island.

3. That the Queensland Government has given approval to the sandmining of Moreton Island despite the advice of conservationists and despite the opposition of the majority of electors in the Moreton Region.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will request the Government to refuse export permits covering mineral sands mined on Moreton Island.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Labelling of Cosmetics
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.

That the Industries Assistance Commission, because of the Commission's terms of reference, seems unable to impose any regulation or recommend any regulation which might restrict the activities of Cosmetic Companies which produce cosmetics in which animal ingredients have been used, or for which animals were subjected to research.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will:
Legislate to require comprehensive labelling of perfumes, cosmetics and toilet preparations to indicate:
(1) whether a product contains any animal derivative. If so, the ingredient and source should be indicated.
(2) whether the research and development of that product or any of its ingredients involved experimentation on animals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are gravely concerned by the Government's failure to act to relieve the plight of many Australians who are being financially crippled by high mortgage repayments.
That we protest on behalf of all those seriously effected by the current crisis in rising mortgage repayments and those facing the near impossibility of obtaining housing loans.
That your Government's policies are forcing a downward trend in the percentage of Australians striving to achieve the ''Great Australian Dream'' of home ownership.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:

Resolve to demand immediate Government action to institute policies which recognise our grave problem and will preserve and maintain the 'Great Australian Dream' of home ownership rather than continue to destroy that dream.

PETITION.TITLE: Use of Live Animals in Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.
2. That no central records exist on such inhumane use of live animals for experimentation purposes, yet research institutions in several Australian States engage in such a practice.
3. That there exists no uniform legislation between the States concerning responsible standards of research conduct, indeed, in some States there is a complete lack of legislation altogether.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will enact legislation to require
(a) the Australian Bureau of Statistics to produce annual statistics on the numbers of live animals involved in research, and provide information as to research purpose; and

(b) the National Health and Medical Research Council to develop humane and responsible standards of conduct for researchers using live animals in all Government, Industry and Educational Research Laboratories.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed New Adelaide International Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(1) the present Adelaide airport is not a suitable locality for an international airport,
(2) residents in the vicinity of the airport suffer considerable inconvenience and discomfort from aircraft noise,
(3) the provision of international services at the existing airport, as announced by the Government, will further exacerbate the noise problem and safety hazard at Adelaide airport.
Your Petitioners therefore pray that:
The Government take immediate action to purchase a suitable site for an international airport outside the metropolitan area, and that planning for the new airport begin as a matter of urgency.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Roads Construction Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners believe that:
The decision to subject the National Roads Construction program to the tendering system will:
(a) threaten the jobs of 790 workers employed in 17 main road depots in N.S.W.,
(b) impair the day labour system and undermine the capacity of Departments of Main Roads to train staff and test road construction concepts,
(c) have a disruptive effect on the employment opportunities available in small communities,
(d) reduce the flexibility of the Department of Main Roads to handle emergencies caused by flood or fires,
(e) ultimately increase the cost of road construction at taxpayers' expense.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government withdraw this disruptive proposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mrs L. Irhazi
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the citizens of Australia shows:
That the Hungarian Government is committing Human Rights violations by refusing people to leave the country.
That the Hungarian Government has refused to issue a passport to Mrs L. Irh'azi and her children of F"o utco 56, Hidegkut 8249. Hungary to leave Hungary to be united with her husband in Australia.

That Article 13, paragraph 2, of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights-to which Hungary is a Contracting Party-proclaims that: 'Everyone has the right to leave any country, including his own, and to return to his country'.
That paragraph 2 of article 12 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights provides that: 'Everyone shall be free to leave any country including his own'.

As Hungary is a Contracting Party to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, Hungary has an obligation to provide the above Human Rights.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

1. That the Australian Government ask the Hungarian Government to practice its legal obligation in relation to Freedom of movement, as defined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights; and

2. That the Australian Government prevail upon the Hungarian Government to provide Mrs L. Irh'azi and her two children with a passport, to allow them to leave Hungary to be united with her husband and their father in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Shortland respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to withdraw public telegram facilities and downgrade telegram standards by:
(1) planning to withdraw the 24 hour telegraph service at the Chief Telegraph Office in each capital city and in Canberra and Darwin,
(2) closing country telegraph offices,
(3) increasing telegram charges whilst downgrading the service,
(4) withdrawing telegram operating facilities from a large number of suburban and country post offices,
(5) generating serious delays in telegram delivery by reducing standards of service through centralisation of the network and reduction of operating and delivery staff,

will reduce an available means of communications in commercial enterprise, deny the opportunity for people of Australia to make contact with family and friends in times of emergency, and civil or natural disasters, particularly for the 30 per cent of Australians who are not telephone subscribers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will take measures to ensure the maintenance of an efficient, effective public telegram service to meet the needs of the Australian people socially, publicly, commercially and in times of emergencies and civil or natural disasters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Kalgoorlie respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to withdraw public telegram facilities and downgrade telegram standards by:
(1) planning to withdraw the 24 hour telegraph service at the Chief Telegraph Office in each capital city and in Canberra and Darwin,
(2) closing country telegraph offices,
(3) increasing telegram charges whilst downgrading the service,
(4) withdrawing telegram operating facilities from a large number of suburban and country post offices,
(5) generating serious delays in telegram delivery by reducing standards of service through centralisation of the network and reduction of operating and delivery staff,

will reduce an available means of communications in commercial enterprise, deny the opportunity for people of Australia to make contact with family and friends in times of emergency, and civil or natural disasters, particularly for the 30 per cent of Australians who are not telephone subscribers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will take measures to ensure the maintenance of an efficient, effective public telegram service to meet the needs of the Australian people socially, publicly, commercially and in times of emergencies and civil or natural disasters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Kennedy respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to withdraw public telegram facilities and downgrade telegram standards by:
(1) planning to withdraw the 24 hour telegraph service at the Chief Telegraph Office in each capital city and in Canberra and Darwin,
(2) closing country telegraph offices,
(3) increasing telegram charges whilst downgrading the service,
(4) withdrawing telegram operating facilities from a large number of suburban and country post offices,
(5) generating serious delays in telegram delivery by reducing standards of service through centralisation of the network and reduction of operating and delivery staff,

will reduce an available means of communications in commercial enterprise, deny the opportunity for people of Australia to make contact with family and friends in times of emergency, and civil or natural disasters, particularly for the 30 per cent of Australians who are not telephone subscribers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will take measures to ensure the maintenance of an efficient, effective public telegram service to meet the needs of the Australian people socially, publicly, commercially and in times of emergencies and civil or natural disasters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Our opinion on paper: That ever since the early seventies, high interest rates of staggering magnitude have made a complete mockery of justice, unparalleled in our time.

Resulting in the elimination of employment on a vast scale, in every phase of production causing house ejections, with mind effects and mental disturbances, leading to interrupted education, road toll and social disruption.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your House urge politicians of all parties to nationally unite for the return of justice by using the powers vested in them to immediately and drastically reduce these destructive interest rates. Further and to this end a conscience vote is essential, if justice is to be served.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned supporters of the animal rights campaign and citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray the House of Representatives will legislate to prohibit the export of live animals and allow only carcass trade and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HODGMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Capital Territory and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the requested amendments be made.

Following the passage of the Customs Tariff Bill through the House it went to the Senate. In the course of its deliberations the Senate referred the Bill to its Scrutiny of Bills Committee which effectively came back with a recommendation, conveyed to me in writing by the Chairman of that Committee, that the Bill be amended. The requested amendments are simple in nature and are supported on bipartisan lines both in the Senate and, I believe, in the House. The requested amendments relate to the provisions in the Bill for the Minister to publish in the Gazette a substitutes and imitations notice where goods are considered to be substitutes for, or an imitation of, goods of another kind. Such a notice has the effect of imposing on the substitutes the rate of duty in respect of them as if they were goods of that other kind. The purpose of the requested amendments sought by the Senate is for the Parliament to be given the same powers and restrictions as to disallowance of a notice as apply to a regulation and to prevent notices from increasing duty retrospectively. I believe, on behalf of the Government, that the request for the amendments by the Senate is a reasonable one. The Government intended to move towards such amendments in any event next year. The Senate has requested them now and the Government is very happy to meet the request.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) said, the request of the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee was made on bipartisan grounds. As he anticipated, the Opposition in this place supports these requested amendments. I add merely that this move perhaps should have been made some time ago but it is better late than never. There is no reason why the Parliament should not have had a lot earlier the same powers over notices as it has over regulations in this area. It is an area in which I have a number of reservations. It so happens that while the Parliament is not sitting changes in duty are merely gazetted and become law. Changes are debated in the Parliament only once a year unless we debate them when the Parliament is sitting immediately notice is given by a Minister of such changes. Not enough attention has been given to the details of tariff changes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister is probably aware that on a great number of occasions-indeed, at every opportunity I have had-I have suggested that the House of Representatives which, by the Westminster tradition, has more power over financial matters should have a committee to look at the details of changes. This would lead to many more members of parliament being familiar with changes in tariffs. I am sorry that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee did not make a recommendation along those lines. It may not have been within its power to do so. At least I am taking another opportunity to remind the House of my personal view on this matter; that is, that we ought to look at the details of changes. At least these requested amendments, which have bipartisan support, will mean that the Parliament has a little more power in this area. I repeat: The Opposition supports the change.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONCILIATION AND ARBITRATION (MANAGEMENT OF ORGANIZATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 October, on motion by Mr Macphee:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once we get into the area of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and, indeed, the whole field of industrial relations, this House is entitled to be deeply suspicious of the actions of the Government. I think it is a matter of deep misfortune for this country that the Government's approach to industrial relations ever since the end of 1975 when it came to power has not been a constructive one of trying to analyse the issues in consultation with the trade union movement and employers to see how best the powers of government can be exercised either administratively or legislatively to improve the climate of industrial relations. Rather, as the record shows, more than any other government in the history of Federation, this Government has sought to pursue the policies of confrontation. This has been shown on many occasions in its approach to legislation reflecting the belief that if one brings in tougher and harder legislation somehow or other that is going to improve the industrial relations climate in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I think one can say, without being accused of being partisan in this matter, that the record in this country and other countries shows that this sort of approach is not productive, that one is never going to improve the industrial relations climate here or in any other democracy by the processes of coercion. What is required, as I think the House will know I have consistently said over the years, is an approach whereby government seeks to use its undoubted powers to bring parties together in a constructive, co-operative fashion. Having said that, I do not want it to be inferred by others that the Opposition is simply going to oppose this legislation on the basis that it represents a continuation of the sort of approach by government to which I have alluded. I will be making it clear that we believe that the legislation is not necessary. I doubt very much that the Government itself believes it is necessary. We will move amendments at the end of my speech and when the Conciliation and Arbitration ( Management of Organisations) Amendment Bill is being considered at the Committee stage.

There are things that I think need to be said about this legislation and its background. Of course, we in the House understand the background to the Bill. The Government really sought to move against two unions-the Builders Labourers Federation and the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of Australia. It has done this by way of establishing a royal commission in the case of the Ship Painters and Dockers Union and deregulation proceedings in the case of the Builders Labourers Federation. It is an interesting fact of political life that, certainly in respect of the fishing expedition that was conducted against the Ship Painters and Dockers Union, it has produced results far beyond the anticipation of the Government. Of course, if the Government could have its life over again, which is one of the luxuries that we cannot enjoy, we can be absolutely certain that one of the decisions it would not have taken is the one to establish a royal commission to investigate the Ship Painters and Dockers Union.
