Unquestionably, this is the decision that the Government has most deeply regretted since it took office at the end of 1975 not because of anything that may or may not have been turned out in regard to the Ship Painters and Dockers Union but because of other ancillary matters which have flowed therefrom.

But let us come to the direct point of the legislation. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee) in his second reading speech-I will go through that speech in a little more detail later-pointed out that the Bill really is concerned with two areas. One is the question of the fitness of certain people to hold office in trade unions because of their involvement with certain offences. The second is the question of the conditions under which loans can be made by unions. As I say, I will deal with each of these areas in a little more detail in a moment. However, I think it is important if we are to consider legislation of this kind that we get the record straight about the character and quality of the Australian trade union movement generally. Before I say anything about that, I think we on this side of the House are indebted to the Minister for the responsible way in which he has approached this matter. He was generous enough in his second reading speech to indicate that he certainly did not believe that the character of the Australian trade union movement generally warranted the sort of legislation which he was bringing before the House. He is right in saying that.

I guess that no member of the House would deny me the right to say that I probably know the Australian trade union movement better than any other member of the House. I can say, I believe without the possibility of contradiction, that overall the Australian trade union movement is an honest movement, staffed and serviced by dedicated men and women whose main and overriding consideration is the pursuit, honestly and according to the law, of the interest of the working Australian men and women whom they represent. It may well be that at times in the pursuit of those objectives they may make decisions with which some of us would disagree. But, overwhelmingly, they are honest people who act legally according to their perception of what is in the best interest of the people whom they represent and I believe consistently with what they believe to be the interest of Australia as a whole. They are ordinary Australian men and women. It is necessary that that be said because too often there is a tendency in some conservative areas in this country to try to create an impression that somehow or other the people who inhabit the trade union movement almost come from a different planet, that they are not ordinary Australian men and women. Of course they are.

The Australian Council of Trade Unions, which is the central body and the umbrella under which the trade union movement operates, covers over two million of our fellow Australian men and women. It cannot be stressed too hard-and it must be, of course, stressed very hard in a consideration of a Bill of this kind -that overwhelmingly as I say again, the full time and part time officials of the trade union movement at branch, State and Federal level are honest, competent, loyal and dedicated Australians. I suggest that it is even more necessary that that be emphasised at this stage because, if one looks back over the last few years, one would find that many of those loudest in their condemnation of the Australian trade union movement for not abiding by the law of this country have been revealed themselves as absolute hypocrites who are prepared either to break the law or to avoid the provisions of the law for their own aggrandisement and to deny the contribution that they should make to the welfare of this country.

Indeed, in this context, it is very interesting to see the language that was used by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on 30 August when he made a speech in South Australia. I hope that he goes to South Australia to make a lot more speeches because he does not seem to have made a good impact as far as we can judge from the results of last Saturday's election. But this is what the Prime Minister had to say on 30 August, speaking at a meeting in the electorate of Kingston:

I have said in my State, that I think those high priced lawyers and accountants who have devised and promoted tax avoidance schemes do more damage to the basis of this society than a thousand Gallaghers in this world, or a thousand Builders Labourers Federations . . .

That was an occasion on which the Prime Minister, getting into the area of industrial relations, albeit peripherally, spoke with a great deal of perspicacity and truth. I think it is appropriate to get this balance into place in the consideration of this legislation. We have here a piece of legislation concerned with ensuring that officials of the trade union movement act honourably and according to the law.

It is as well in our consideration of the Bill that we have clearly in our minds the words of the Prime Minister in respect of people engaged in tax avoidance. I remind the House that the Prime Minister was not talking about evasion. He said:

. . . high priced lawyers and accountants who have devised and promoted tax avoidance schemes do more damage to the basis of this society than a thousand Gallaghers in this world, or a thousand Builders' Labourers Federations . . .

Of course, he is right. However, one would have hoped, in the circumstances of that unequivocal condemnation of people engaged in tax avoidance as being so much more dangerous than the union people to whom the Prime Minister alluded, that he would not have adhered to the position that he adopted subsequently when he came into the House and said that tax avoiders were not ogres and not the sort of people who did such great damage to the fabric of society.

We have seen the way in which the Prime Minister and the Government went to water on this issue and made this very significant distinction in this matter. Nevertheless, the point I am making is that we have there from the mouth of the Prime Minister an indication of the sort of perspective that this society should have in relation to where the greatest danger to the welfare of this society lies. Much more danger is posed to the fabric of this society by the people engaged in tax evasion and tax avoidance than by any trade union official or trade union in this country. The authority for that is the Prime Minister of this country.

In that context I come now to the actual proposals of the Bill we are considering. As the Minister indicated, there have been discussions by the Government through the apparatus of the National Labour Consultative Council, which provides, as we all know, the mechanism for discussions with the trade union movement and the organised employers of this country. I think the Minister will agree with me when I say that the position of the ACTU, as put there and elsewhere, was not that it welcomed the Bill and said the Bill was necessary. Rather it put to the Minister and, indeed, to the Opposition in discussions that it believes that the Bill is not necessary for the reasons I have put about the general honesty of the trade union movement and the existence of other provisions; but the ACTU takes the view that with the qualifications to which I will be alluding it should not take the position that the Bill should be vehemently opposed.

On behalf of the Opposition, I will therefore look at the Bill in a little more detail to indicate the Opposition's position. First of all, I refer to proposed new section 132F, which relates to prescribed offences and which sets out the offences which would attract the penalty of inability to hold or retain office. In the Committee stage of debate I will be making more detailed observations about our position here. At the second reading stage I indicate that we believe that one part of the section dealing with prescribed offences should be deleted. I refer to the part dealing with offences in regard to certain sections and parts of the regulations thereunder of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Penalties are involved if the offences listed there are committed. We believe that this proposal smacks of double penalties in respect of trade union officials in that if trade union officials are guilty of the offences listed there the Conciliation and Arbitration Act provides penalties in respect of those offences. If they are found guilty they will then suffer the penalty attached thereto. We think that this is a case of imposing a severe double penalty improperly and unnecessarily. I will perhaps go into that in more detail when I move the appropriate amendment at the Committee stage.

At this stage I refer to proposed new section 132F (1) (d) and point out that there is, if one likes, a looseness about the offence referred to. One of the prescribed offences is described in the Bill as:

(d) any other offence under a law of the Commonwealth, of a State, or a Territory or of another country, being an offence involving the intentional or reckless use of violence towards another person, the intentional or reckless causing of death or injury to another person or the intentional or reckless damaging or destruction of property.

I point out to the Minister that 'reckless' is not a commonly used term. I think the Minister is indicating that he acknowledges this. The term 'reckless' is not pre-defined in this Bill or anywhere else. Again, I will perhaps say more about that at the Committee stage of the debate. In setting out our general position in regard to the Bill, I think it is appropriate to point out to the Minister that we would be hoping in the Committee stage to tease out the sorts of situations that he envisages being covered by terminology of that sort. We hope we may be able to get some response to what seems to us to be the potential danger of the looseness of the language there used.

In respect of the concept of double penalties, I ask the Minister to consider the situation in regard to medical practitioners who have been found guilty of some offences under the relevant legislation. There is no suggestion that they not be allowed to continue their profession. Although they are required to put up some notice indicating that they have infringed the provisions of the legislation and been found guilty, they are allowed to practice without inhibition. I suggest to the Minister that this is a relevant consideration in terms of the point I am making about the double penalty that is involved in proposed new section 132F (1) (d) to which I have referred. I hope the Minister will take that into account.

So much at the second reading stage of the debate for that section of the Bill concerned with prescribed offences which would operate to preclude a person from holding or continuing to hold office as a member of a trade union if he or she has been found guilty of those offences. I turn now to the second purpose of the legislation and that is the purpose of dealing with the situation of loans or grants by officials of the trade union movement. It is important that we look at what the Minister has had to say in his second reading speech about this matter and contrast it with the provisions of the Bill. After referring to the background of the royal commissions that have been established by this Government in conjunction with the previous Victorian Government, the Minister referred to the Winneke report into the Builders Labourers Federation. The second reading speech states:

Another recommendation was made for an amendment to the Act to provide that the funds of any registered organisation, or any branch, should not be applied in the granting of loans to any officer or member of the organisation or branch unless the terms and conditions upon which the loan is to be granted have been fully disclosed to and approved by the membership of the organisation or branch in general meeting.

The Minister in his second reading speech to the House accurately puts the position as to the re- commendation that was involved in the Winneke report. There was concern about a looseness, as the Royal Commissioner saw it, of the conditions as he found under which-in the union he was looking at-loans were able to be made by the union to officials of that union. The Minister, in introducing this Bill and in giving his justifications for the provisions of this legislation, relies upon Royal Commissioner Winneke's report in that respect. One can follow that. It is quite logical that if that is being quoted out of the report of the Royal Commission, which this Government has established , that the Government should then say, 'All right, this is our royal commission. A recommendation has been made that we should cover the situation of unions being able to make loans to officers or member of that union'. One can follow that. That is perfectly logical, but that is not what the Bill does. If the Bill were confined to that, one could say: 'There is a logical sequence of events. You establish a royal commission, the royal commissioner looks at something, finds a problem, makes a recommendation and the Government comes in and gives effect to it.' The Government has gone much beyond that. It is not merely dealing with the provision of loans or grants to an officer or a member of the organisation.

What is being provided in this legislation are provisions for disclosure in respect of grants or loans to anyone or to any organisation; it is not just to an officer or a member of the union. This is what the Royal Commissioner reported on. What does that mean? It means that, as a result of the legislation, we are going to have a position where much of the trade union movement, as is well known, has an association with the Australian Labor Party. It will make donations at particular times to the Labor Party and it has made them to other political parties. What we are getting at here is legislation which will make it compulsory for the disclosure of that sort of financial transaction. The Royal Commissioner was not concerned about that. This is not what the Minister is referring to in his speech, but that is what the legislation deals with. I am aware of the fact that under the existing regulations there are provisions whereby people can get access to that information, but I notice that the Minister is quite straightforward. He realises this is creating a different situation and is adding to it by legislation. It is certainly-I think the Minister must agree-not something which flows as a matter of logic from what the Royal Commissioner was talking about.

Let me make the position of the Labor Party clear on this issue in case there be any possibility of misrepresentation. We are not taking a position where we would oppose the legislation operating in a way which would provide for disclosure of donations by a trade union to a political party. We are not trying to have anything hidden in that way. That is not our point.

I think the Minister must agree that if he brings in legislation which goes far beyond what the Royal Commission was concerned about-that is, the provision and the conditions under which loans are provided to officials or members of the union in the terms of his legislation so that all financial transactions are required to be disclosed including transactions involving grants or loans to a political party-then the fair thing in those circumstances is that the Minister should ensure that steps are taken to get even-handedness in this approach. The Minister will recall that. He justifies the approach he takes in this legislation in regard to offences by saying: 'We are trying to get an even- handedness. You have provisions under the relevant companies legislation which preclude the situation of men or women holding offices as directors if they have committed certain offences and you want to get a certain even-handedness'. It is very hard to argue against that. The Minister must accept what follows in the terms of what I am putting; that is, if we are going to have this even- handedness then the trade unions will be compelled to disclose their donations to political parties as they must do under this legislation. Let us ensure even- handedness and ensure that the Government takes steps to provide for the same principle of disclosure of donations on the part of companies.

The logic of it all is inexorable. I will repeat it briefly. It has been said that there has been a royal commission and that certain recommendations require a tightening up and disclosure of the conditions under which loans and grants are made by trade unions to its officials and members. That is okay, but the Government has gone beyond that. It has gone to a situation where it is not talking about loans or grants to the officials or members, it has gone to a situation which will cover any loans or grants above $1,000. This will embrace inevitably-I think the Minister agrees-the situation of donations to a political party. The Minister has justified his approach in respect of offences on the basis that he wants to get even-handedness between trade unions and companies. That is all very well. Let him take his logic through and make sure that if this approach is going to have this effect upon trade unions in ensuring the disclosure on their part of political donations that he will, through the Government, move to see that the appropriate action is taken to get the same position in regard to companies. I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'whilst not generally opposing the provisions of the Bill, the House calls on the Government to extend the principle of disclosure of donations by organisations and to legislate immediately to require full disclosure by companies of all donations of a political nature made by them'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of his remarks the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) never once referred to employer organisations. It is necessary to bear in mind that the amendments contained in the Conciliation and Arbitration (Management of Organizations) Amendment Bill are to apply both to employer and employee organisations; that is, to trade unions and to employer organisations registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. To take the point last made by the honourable member, when one looks at the position of loans and the restrictions that apply under proposed new section 133B those restrictions apply equally to employer and employee organisations just as do the other restrictions in this Bill. Both employers and employees are treated on the same basis and without discrimination.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Wills did not say very much in his speech about the provisions in the Bill so far as those provisions deal with disqualification of members or of individuals from holding office or from election to office in registered organisations: That is again-I make the point-both trade unions and employer organisations. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee) has outlined in his second reading speech how the provisions are to apply but it is worth while, in the light of the failure of the honourable member for Wills to refer to the operation of the provisions, to outline briefly how the disqualification provisions are to apply. In brief, it is to be found in proposed new section 132B, which states that a person who has, whether before or after the commencement of the Act, been convicted of a prescribed offence-I will come to those offences at a later stage-effectively cannot be a candidate, hold office or be appointed to an office within an organisation for a period of five years unless he is granted exemption. That period of five years applies either from the date of conviction of the offence or, if the person has served a term of imprisonment, from the date on which he was released from prison.

The purpose of that kind of provision is perfectly plain. We all know there are people who, by their actions and by their record, have rendered themselves quite unfit to be trusted, and it is to meet that kind of situation that the disqualification provisions are framed. I doubt that any person in this chamber would say that some of the persons who have been referred to in Mr Costigan's Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union should ever hold office in a union or in any other body at all, be it an employer organisation or a company. It is in the interests of that public good that these provisions are introduced. For my part I welcome them. I do not believe that many persons will be affected. I agree with the honourable member for Wills when he says that most members of the Australian trade union movement are good citizens amd most of their officials are seeking to do the best by their members. I have no quarrel with that proposition. Most members and most officials of employer organisations answer precisely the same description. Nevertheless, there will be cases, and the painters and dockers have provided us with a superb example, which will lead any reasonable person to say that certain individuals should not be allowed to manage the affairs of an organisation.

In this Bill we are dealing with trade unions or employer organisations. The Companies Act, from which these provisions are drawn, deals with companies, be they $2 companies or companies the size of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. I particularly welcome these disqualification provisions since I have advocated their adoption for about the last 18 months-first of all to the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) during his short tenure as Minister for Industrial Relations, then to his successor and, lastly, to the present Minister , and of course through them to the Government. In a grievance debate on 19 August I advocated essentially what appears in the Bill in relation to disqualification of persons from holding offices. The reason is plain and it has been touched upon; it is the public interest.

I shall now say something about the operation of the prescribed offences provisions. The honourable member for Wills said two things about the disqualification provision, and only two things. First of all he said that the provisions are not necessary. How it is possible for him to say that these provisions are not necessary in light of what we know about the painters and dockers escapes, I think, any reasonable mind. There we see a situation in which , on the evidence disclosed, a union-it is very much an isolated example-is controlled by criminals. How he can say that there is no need to legislate against the possibility of this kind of abuse in the future is astonishing. There is an interest not only for the public at large but also for members of trade unions and for members of employer organisations to make sure that rogues do not take over the government of organisations, be they employer organisations or trade unions.

The other criticism that the honourable member for Wills had to make about the disqualification provisions related to the provisions which are to be found in proposed new section 132F (1) (b). It sets out a description of the kind of offences which are to attract the disqualification provisions. It seems that the honourable member for Wills has no quarrel with the first of the four heads that appear in that provision; namely, where there has been committed an offence under a law of the Commonwealth, a State, a Territory or of another country involving fraud or dishonesty punishable on conviction by imprisonment for a period of not less than three months. I would understand him to say of that, although he said nothing, that it is perfectly reasonable; that we would not want those sorts of people to be in charge of organisations immediately after conviction or immediately after release from prison until they have either been vetted by a court or have gone through a probationary period. Nor does he have, it appears, any particular quarrel with the last two provisions. The first deals with offences in connection with the formation, registration or management of an association or organisation-that is, a trade union or an employer's organisation . He does not object to the last provision, subject to one qualification, which deals with offences involving intentional or reckless use of violence towards another person, the intentional or reckless causing of death or injury to another person or the intentional or reckless damage or destruction of property. As I understand him, the word 'reckless' in that context is vague and therefore needs to be looked at.

But what the honourable member did complain about are offences listed in new section 132F (1) (b), and these are all offences which are defined by relation to provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act or regulations made under the Concilation and Arbitration Act. What he says about those offences is: 'It is a double penalty'. If he is right, that argument applies equally to all offences and not just to offences under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. It applies equally to an offence involving fraud or dishonesty which has nothing to do with the Act as it is does to an offence which arises under the Act. All one can say as to that is that it is a piece of special pleading and it seeks to exempt certain offences from the disqualification provisions that attract the operation of the Act. Why? Because, apparently, they are offences under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, and not for any other reason at all. The honourable member said that they are double penalties. All I can say is that it is the application of a double standard; that is, if one has been convicted of an offence under the Act it should not affect one's position in a registered organisation, although the honourable member was of course concerned only with unions.

I now draw attention to one anomaly in this Bill that relates to the operation of the disqualification provisions. The Minister pointed out in his second reading speech that the operation of the disqualification provisions does not apply to persons who hold office, be they elected officers or appointed officers , but that those disqualification provisions apply to persons who seek to be elected or appointed to office after the passage of this legislation. So we have the wholly anomalous position where persons who now hold office, who were, shall we assume, convicted of an offence involving fraud or dishonesty two years ago, are entitled to continue to hold office when the Bill becomes law, yet, if their period of office expires within five years of their conviction or five years after their discharge from prison and they have to seek re-election or re- appointment then apparently they are not qualified for that and they are subject to the disqualification provisions.

It seems to me that the Bill would be very much improved if it applied both to future office holders and to those who presently hold office whose past conduct would otherwise attract the operation of the disqualification provisions. Any hardship can be met very simply by an application to the court under the Act to demonstrate that in all the circumstances such persons should be entitled to continue to hold office. A great amount of publicity has been given to the activities of some of the members of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Do not all honourable members really think many of those persons, by reason of their past conduct, have disqualified themselves from continuance in office and should attract the operation of the provisions now before the House? Yet, as I have said, we have this anomaly that those provisions will not apply to present office holders but only to future office holders.

I pass now to the criticism made by the honourable member for Wills of the provisions concerning loans. He said that the recommendation to which the Minister referred was one thing and yet the provision which we now have before us is another. He gave the example of the application of the provision to grants to the Australian Labor Party. He said that, in effect, it is all too wide. He again overlooked the fact that the Bill applies both to employer and employee organisations. So it would apply equally to trade union organisations and employer organisations. I suppose if an employer organisation makes a grant that comes within the Bill to the Liberal Party, the National Party or the Australian Labor Party, that organisation will have to disclose that fact in accordance with the Bill, and so it should, or it will have to ensure that the loan has been properly made, and so it should.

The honourable member for Wills referred to the fact that companies are in a somewhat different position. If one looks at the position of companies under the Companies Act one finds that some wide ranging prohibitions on loans are being given to directors, spouses of directors or other persons. It is perfectly true that these provisions do not go as far as the provisions now before the House. But let me state one very good reason why they should not. Employer organisations and trade unions are concerned with advancing the interests of their members. They are not trading organisations. In particular, if one looks to the position of a trade union, one sees that the trade union's source of funds is what it receives from its members and what it may have by way of investment income. As honourable members would know, some unions are now very large organisations and do have some investment income. But it is perfectly right that since what is held is effectively held in trust for members and not for trading purposes stringent restrictions should apply to the kinds of loans that trade unions or employer organisations can make.

I do not suggest that this Bill will have a widespread application. As I have said, I agree with what the honourable member for Wills has said about officials in the trade union movement. I would think very few would be affected. But history must demonstrate to this House that there is a need for this sort of legislation. If the legislation had been in position some years ago it is very likely that many of the activities which have been examined by Mr Costigan in his inquiry into the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union could never have taken place. It would have been a very good thing for this country if that had been the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation before the House introduces new sections into the Conciliation and Arbitration Act which attempt to bring that Act into line with the Companies Act in relation to the prescribed offences and disqualification provisions. However, when one looks at the Conciliation and Arbitration (Management of Organizations) Amendment Bill which is before the House one has to ask: Why is the Bill before us? I believe it is a political piece of legislation-if I can use that term. It has no industrial base. It will do absolutely nothing for industrial relations. Yet we have it before us.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee) and the Government know that this whole legislation is a fraud. It is a front. Why is it a front? If one digs deeply enough one will find that our flagging economy might be one point in question. With over half a million people unemployed, the inflation rate at 12 per cent and interest rates extremely high, I think the Government is looking for other avenues in order to divert attention. After all, this Government has a unique record in the area of international affairs. Unemployment is rocketing up at the same time as inflation. The American economy , for instance, which admittedly has around 17 per cent registered unemployed and people looking for full time work has an inflation rate which is down to a few percentage points. But this Government has the unique record of having both arrows going in the one direction-that is, up.

If we take the letter of the legislation we see that it deals more with confrontation, which we have been used to in the last seven years, than with conciliation. It is a pity that this Government did not put as much effort into the eradication of unemployment as it has into these draconian pieces of conciliation and arbitration legislation. When one recalls the Minister's second reading speech, one would be excused for wondering why the Government is saying that unions are full of crooks. Of course they are not. The Minister at least acknowledged that in the second reading speech when he said:
The Government does not doubt that by far the majority of registered organisations are honestly run . . .

Again one asks: Why do we have this piece of legislation before us? One could ask that question after almost every sentence because it just does not add up. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) in his speech kept referring to the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of Australia and how this legislation seeks to eradicate the Painters and Dockers Union. Really, it is a little bit like having a fly annoying one in the house on a hot day, running down to the local supermarket to buy every can of aerosol one can find, running back home and emptying the lot over the inside of the house to eradicate this one poor fly.

The provisions in the Bill whilst fixing, one might say, the problem of the Painters and Dockers Union-if that is what the Government's problem is-would gather in a lot of other people. Proposed new section 132F (1) (a), which has been alluded to before, states that a 'prescribed offence' means:
an offence . . . involving fraud or dishonesty punishable on conviction by imprisonment for a period of not less than 3 months.

That raises a lot of other points. The legislation will not gather in many people at present. I agree with that. In fact, 99 per cent of the unions and registered organisations in general are honestly run and have honest and good people in them.

The effects of this legislation differ from the effects of the Companies Act. When the Companies Act disqualifies someone from taking part in the management of a corporation, those people usually are in the middle aged bracket and, supposedly, should know better, one might say, than to get into trouble and find themselves in court. I am concerned about the young people who wish to take up a career in a registered organisation, namely, trade unions, probably more than any other type of organisation. At some young silly age-this was brought up in the Victorian Parliament some years ago-people do some stupid acts such as pinching a watch. Many people-I would say that many in this chamber too, may have done or been involved with some stupid things in their life. But they have outgrown that stage and have matured in their late teens. They then settle down and go on to their careers. Under this legislation, if someone does something silly at 17 or 18 years of age, is convicted of that offence and punished with three months imprisonment that person can then find himself or herself disqualified for up to five years from entering the career that he or she wishes to follow. That can mean that that person is 23 or 24 before being allowed to be appointed or elected to a registered organisation. That really can quite markedly put the brakes on one's career.

Throughout our society we very rarely hear of the professions and the very detailed and good occupations involved especially with the trade union movement. These opportunities have grown over the years. I think this Government is to blame for some of that lack of knowledge. The occupation of industrial advocate has blossomed over the years. Many learned people from all walks of life with university degrees have entered the trade union movement and have started on very long and successful careers. If they are silly at a young age, a big damper is put on them. Under this Bill they are disqualified for five years from being elected or appointed to an office within any registered organisation. Why, one must ask also, does that person have to suffer a double penalty? Under the law of the land that person was convicted and sentenced to three months, six months or whatever period of imprisonment. The legislation provides that a person is not eligible to be elected or appointed until five years after release from prison. So, people come out of prison only to find that they have another penalty, not one which was prescribed by the judge or magistrate at the time of sentence but one set by the Federal Government under this piece of legislation.

Let me continue for a moment on the term 'prescribed offence'. The honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) has alluded to paragraph (b) of proposed new section 132F (1). We will move an amendment to this provision in the Committee stage. The paragraph is concerned with some 25 provisions-20 sections under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and five regulations under the Conciliation and Arbitration Regulations-under which one may commit a prescribed offence. Some of them might be reasonable, such as that concerned with the rigging of ballots. The Bill refers to section 143 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act-that is, the application for cancellation of registration, the deregistration proceedings . That concerns me somewhat. In proposed new section 132F (1) (d) the word ' reckless' is used on three separate occasions. This provision could be used by a government of any persuasion for political reasons. One could make sure that at a demonstration where a union official or, for that matter, any member of a registered organisation was present at and he or she became involved in a skirmish. That person could be removed from office. Under this legislation, bingo, out he or she would go. If one does not like a particular official, one can easily set him or her up under this legislation. That is what the legislation provides. The Minister may say that that is not really what the legislation is intended to do, but that is what can occur under the legislation.

I do not think it is good enough for a Minister to introduce into this House legislation with a clause that, for example, provides for 'intentional' or ' reckless' use of violence. What does 'reckless' mean? I ask the Minister whether he can define it. The honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) suggested to me before this debate-I believe he was a learned member of the legal fraternity before entering the State Parliament in New South Wales-that the situation is, in fact, like backing a car out of a parking lot. In doing that, someone could be considered to be driving recklessly, if one looks at the meaning of 'reckless ' use of violence under the legislation. Such a person could find himself or herself disqualified from holding union positions under this legislation. It seems to me that those words have been put into the legislation intentionally; otherwise, as the honourable member for Wills said, why have such unusual words been used? I ask the Minister to explain that point at a later time in this debate.

I am not carrying a candle for anyone, let alone a trade union or trade union official who does not do the right thing. There is no legitimate reason for legislation of this nature. It will not assist in achieving good industrial relations. Therefore, it will not assist our flagging economy, nor will it foster a better type of person, as the Government might put it, in the industrial movement. All this is achieved by fostering better industrial relations, conciliation, and granting the union movement and occupations and professions concerned therein the high amount of respect that they deserve.

I must say at this point that the degree of professionalism and integrity in the trade union movement and all registered organisations is extremely high. The number of people becoming interested in such occupations is increasing. This is very good to see. Considering that, I again ask: Why do we have this double penalty type of legislation before us? The honourable member for North Sydney suggested that it covered all employer organisations too. Of course, the legislation is concerned with registered organisations. As the honourable member for North Sydney, who practised at the bar and in the industrial scene, would know, not all employer organisations are registered organisations.

I spent quite some time before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the television area, shall I say good humouredly striking blows with an employer organisation which was not registered, which never had been registered and which, unless something dramatic has happened, still is not registered today. Therefore, that organisation would not have to comply with the loans, grants and donations section of the legislation. The honourable member for North Sydney talked about loans but he conveniently forgot to talk about donations. That is what we are looking at. We do not mind disclosing our sources of donations. Let us hope that this will be the first step towards a full disclosure of all moneys advanced to political parties, whether by registered organisations or otherwise. I hope that this is what the Government is intending to do. I wonder whether we will have similar legislation requiring companies to state where their donations go.

I cannot find any good reason for this legislation. This whole debate is probably an academic one because just about every honourable member who has spoken has agreed that 99.9 per cent of the personnel in registered organisations-let us be honest, we are talking about trade union officials-are beyond reproach. So why are we trying to swat a fly with a whole host of fly swatters? It just does not make sense. I again quote the honourable member for North Sydney, who said that the reasons are plain, that it is in the public interest. He talked about the painters and dockers being 'controlled by criminals'. Page 5 of the Bill, under prescribed offences, refers to a person being convicted and imprisoned for a period of not less than three months. I hope that not everyone who has pinched a watch or who has been convicted of such a paltry offence-not that we are condoning any such thing-would be described as a criminal, which is what the honourable member for North Sydney has suggested.

We will move certain amendments at the Committee stage of the debate and I will have more to say then. I really do not believe that this piece of legislation assists industrial relations in this country at all. I cannot see any good reason for it in any way, shape or form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Conciliation and Arbitration (Management of Organizations) Amendment Bill does not add a great deal to the general body of legislation which is necessary to regulate industrial relations in our country. If the Government were concerned, as I think we all are, about allegations that certain officers of unions had abused the trust reposed in them by virtue of their holding an office and had used that office for criminal purposes, legislation which was directed specifically at meeting that contention -that is at heart the contention which underlies the basis of the Government's whole approach-would have been drafted. My opposition to the prescribed offences that operate in this legislation is that they are too broadly drafted.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me give the House a simple illustration of that. One cannot accept the simplistic statement of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) that because officers of certain unions have been involved in what he described as criminal offences-they were almost a class offence-they are not entitled to hold any position in any responsible structure in our society. It is that approach and that concept that I want to examine. It would not be unknown to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee) that it is a common practice at the end of the year for employer organisations to have social functions to which union officials are invited and for union organisations to have social functions to which employers are invited.

Let me put to the House a situation which, I think, is possibly not unknown to the Minister of an active member of a union who does not necessarily hold any office and who, on attending such a function, celebrates excessively, has too much to drink, and is involved in a motor car accident on his way home in which damage is done to property and someone is injured. As a result of that unfortunate set of circumstances he is convicted and sentenced to 12 months imprisonment. In all other respects, everyone would agree that he is a responsible and decent citizen and this particular act was an aberration. After he does his 12 months sentence he could be asked to stand for or seek union office. He would then find himself under a circumscription in terms of his rights and capacity to do that. Is it not extraordinary that if he chooses to nominate for a seat in the Federal Parliament-this Parliament-he would be under no such circumscription? Once he has done his period in gaol he can be elected to this House. Indeed, if his party wins government, he may find himself in the exalted position that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, occupy. Is it not an extraordinary scenario that we have drawn for ourselves in what seems to me to be a government 's over-reaction to a set of allegations? With due respect to the findings of the royal commissioners, they are no more than allegations until such time as those matters have been tried and tested in our courts. This Parliament and this Government could be charged with what is an extraordinary set of double standards if the Government says, presumably, that it regards the Parliament as not as important as any one of the registered unions in our community. I do not believe that the Government believes that. I do not believe that the Minister believes it.

It was good enough for our founding fathers in their wisdom to take the view that a citizen convicted of any major crime which is less than treason should not be disqualified from standing for Parliament once he has served his sentence . While he is under sentence or in gaol he is disqualified but once the sentence is completed, as far as this Parliament and our Constitution are concerned, he has the same right as every other citizen. What an extraordinary set of double standards it is to say that that will be the rule for the Parliament but will not be the rule for the same citizen who, in the circumstances I have outlined, wants to contest an office in a registered organisation under the Act. That is what I mean by overreaction. I would like to have tabled and incorporated in Hansard a letter which was kindly given to me by my colleague the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Armitage) in respect of--

TALK.START.PARA: —I interrupt the honourable gentleman. It is not possible for material of that nature to be incorporated in Hansard.

—I simply acknowledge my indebtedness to the honourable member who, in terms of the circumstances I have just outlined to the Parliament, had that legal position confirmed for him by the Acting Chief Australian Electoral Officer as to the restrictions on the rights of citizens standing for Parliament . I believe that when we are looking at these disqualification provisions we have to see them in the broad context of what is the problem with which we are endeavouring to come to grips and, therefore, what is an appropriate amendment to deal with the problem. In my view what is contained in this legislation in terms of prescribed offences is an overreaction.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of the trade union movement shows a number of distinguished officers, men who have in the past, because of the nature of Australian society and by virtue of the social circumstances under which they lived in a society in which economic conditions were far more difficult than they are now-although, God knows, we seem to be getting that way under this Government-in fact, had a conviction. Having discharged their debt to society they went on to hold responsible positions within the trade union movement and, ultimately, were a credit not merely to the trade union movement but to society as a whole.

I do not believe that this legislation meets the needs of the complexities of the social structures because trade unions are social structures which reflect the social aspirations of the group in the community they represent. I do not believe that legislation which is not geared to meet the complexities of those social structures will work. If it does not work all we are doing is putting on to the statute book one more piece of legislation which does not make industrial relations any easier. It makes them more complex. It is perfectly true to say that there is no great excitement or enthusiasm in the trade union movement, or indeed I suspect even amongst employer groups, one way or the other, about this legislation. Most of the unions and the employer organisations concerned do not see this legislation as affecting them particularly in their day to day operations. Officers of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, with whom members of the Opposition discussed this legislation in order to ascertain their views, have made it perfectly clear that they regret this legislation coming forward as a somewhat meaningless cheap, political exercise.

The other aspect of the legislation deals with the amendments the Government requires in regard to rules of unions to provide that the committee of management has to satisfy itself as to the details of any loan, grant or donation and which require such details to be filed annually with the Industrial Registrar. As one who, over many years, has had both a legal and a political relationship with a large number of unions it has been my experience that, for the most part, unions are very prudent and cautious-indeed, to the point of being conservative-in the handling of union funds. In the presentation of their balance sheets and accounts to their members they are very open.

I am bound to say, again from my experience, that the average union organisation and the average union secretary is far more open and candid in the presentation of the accounts of the unions, its finances and its balance sheets, than are many of those who run our large financial institutions operating within the corporate sector. From time to time-it is public knowledge in my party-my party has sought political donations from the trade union movement. When I was president of the Victorian branch of the Labor Party I, like every president before me, sought contributions. When those contributions were made they were not made secretly. They were publicly acknowledged in both the records of the union and the records of the Labor Party. More often than not a picture would be taken and published in the union journal which went to all the union's members of, usually, the union secretary or perhaps the president writing a cheque or making a donation to the Labor Party for the forthcoming election compaign. There was no secret about that.

I say to the Minister that we on this side of the House are putting the Government on notice. The Government is not entitled to say to the trade union movement that it will disclose its donations but that there will be another rule entirely for the corporate sector. A director of a large public company is as responsible for the management of his company's funds as a union secretary. If this Government is saying that we now require the trade union movement to make public its donations, the Minister may rest assured-regardless of whether he does it-that a future Labor government will have absolutely no hesitation at all in taking this precedent and saying that what is good enough for the trade union movement, which already handles its situation in this matter with an openness and a candour which is not repeated in the corporate sector, will certainly apply to the corporate sector. There is no reason why as a matter of law, principle or logic this Minister is entitled to say that we will make the requirement of disclosure operative upon a trade union secretary who wants to give $1,000 to the party of his political choice-usually that is the Labor Party -but that the director of a large company who wants to give a $50,000 donation to the Liberal Party will not have a similar requirement imposed on him.

For that reason the Opposition, in order to test the sincerity of the Government on this issue, foreshadowed the amendment to the motion for the second reading which has been moved by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke ). It is a logical amendment. In my view the principle is unarguable. I would hope that, as the Government has adopted this standard for the trade union movement and its officers-let me say that this provision is not seen as being any great pain or penalty by trade unions or their officers because they already do this-we will see whether this Government has the sincerity of its convictions when it says that we will not have one rule for the trade union movement and another for the corporate sector.

This legislation, in terms of its requirements for disclosure and in terms of its requirements that union funds be properly accounted for, goes further-as has already been pointed out by the honourable member for Wills-than the actual recommendation of the Royal Commission into the Activities of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation. Again we are not terribly excited about that, but we believe that point ought to be made. Of course, as the Commissioner recommended, loans made to officers of a union certainly ought to be fully accounted for and subject to full disclosure to the committee of management and to the membership. There again the Minister knows, as I know, that within that part of the corporate sector which is involved in the lending of funds many officers of companies get privileged treatment compared with that given to the general public and shareholders of the company when it comes to seeking a loan for housing purposes. I am not saying that there is anything irregular in that. If the manager of a large financial institution is disposed to give to a senior officer of the company who is of importance to the company a loan to buy a house or for some other purpose at interest rates well below the requirement of the general market, is that a matter that ought to be disclosed to the shareholders of the company? Is that not a matter on which again the standards ought to be the same?

I think the problem with this legislation essentially is that the Government has had recommendations from two royal commissions and, without looking at the social context or the history of the unions involved and without looking at the extent of practices essentially operating within a very limited area and relating to the history of the industries concerned, it has produced legislation which I believe, for the reasons I have outlined to the House, goes further than is necessary. When the Government goes further than is necessary in the field of industrial relations it often produces a result completely adverse to the result it is intending to achieve. I beleive the Minister would do well to ponder the remarks that have been made and to consider whether some of the proposals made by the Opposition in respect of this legislation should be incorporated in it before it passes to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MACPHEE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: — The honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) and the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) have actually shown considerable misunderstandings about the nature of this legislation. I shall deal with their remarks in a few moments . I start with the remarks of the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) and the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). In fact I wish to congratuate the honourable member for North Sydney for the work that he has done over time to help introduce a piece of legislation of this kind. He has spoken about it quite often and he has been helpful in its preparation. As he said, I do not think any reasonable person would doubt the necessity for legislation of this kind. As he and all other speakers have acknowledged, and I acknowledge, we expect it to be used rarely. That does not in any way gainsay the need for legislation of this character. I shall dispel the misunderstandings of the Opposition as I proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: It will be seen that this legislation is in no way an overreaction or too extensive to meet the quite limited but serious situation to which it is directed. The honourable member for Wills in his approach and in moving his amendment was concerned that we be even-handed. I remind him that in my second reading speech I acknowledged that we were endeavouring to draw upon the Companies Act. I also said:

The policy in relation to these companies provisions is under consideration in the context of the planned exposure draft of the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1983. It is hoped that the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities will later this year agree to this exposure draft being made available for public comment. The Attorney- General (Senator Durack) has directed his Department to ensure that when the public comments on the exposure draft are being examined, consideration is given to the question whether the companies provisions need any amendment so that, as far as possible, they cover the same range of offences as those set out in proposed sub-section 132F (1) contained in this Bill and to the question whether any other adjustments would be desirable to the companies legislation to bring it into line with the relevant provisions of this Bill.

In that spirit the Government has sought to marry together the concepts of the Companies Act with the concepts which it believes should prevail in respect of office holders of registered organisations under this legislation. Where we have found them to be out of kilter we have indicated a willingness to seek to have the Companies Act brought into line with this amending legislation.

In the same spirit I am quite happy to refer to my colleague the Acting Attorney-General (Mr N.A. Brown) the matters referred to in this amendment in order to have them examined by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, because it is, of course, uniform with legislation enacted by the State governments. I have no difficulty at all in putting that forward even though I agree with the points made by the honourable member for North Sydney that the even-handedness of this provision lies in its application to all registered organisations, whether they are employer organisations or trade unions. Nevertheless, as we have been drawing so liberally upon the Companies Act, quite clearly I would be happy to refer that to the Acting Attorney-General to see whether similar provisions can be extended to that Act.

When I come to deal with the remarks of several of the Opposition speakers regarding donations it will be seen that the legislation is nowhere near as extensive and embarrassing to organisations as has been painted by some Opposition speakers. But there is no question that the public would consider that the response of this Bill to the revelations of both the Winneke Royal Commission on the Activities of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation and the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union is appropriate. We are talking of an abuse of office and the unfitness of persons to hold office. We have said, and all speakers have said, that this will apply to only a very small minority of registered organisations. But there is no doubt from a reading of the reports of those two royal commissions that serious offences occur in relation to the holding of office in the case of the Builders Labourers Federation and that the most grave aspersions one can imagine have been cast in relation to the criminal records and therefore the unfitness to hold office of some of the persons who currently hold office or who have held office in the Ship Painters and Dockers Union. There is just no question in my mind that legislation of this kind is necessary. It is equally necessary in respect of the Companies Act. As the honourable member for North Sydney said, there are $2 companies and some of them have been involved in Nugan Hand-type operations. They are the smallest possible percentage of registered companies. But no company director finds offence at having this kind of legislation applied to him or her. Equally no officals of a registered organisation, an employer organisation or a trade union, should be at all offended by the application of these kinds of provisions to them.

The honourable member for Isaacs made the point that not all employer organisations are registered under the Act. That is true. If they are not registered under the principal Act or under a State Act similar to it, they do not get the benefit of tax deductibility for their funds. Not all the trade unions, of course, are registered either. Some have been deregistered; some have never been registered. Certainly the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the labour councils have not sought registration.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ACTU could not be registered.

—No, the ACTU could not be registered. The Confederation of Australian Industry is not registered. Some of the major organisations with which the public identifies would certainly not be covered. People are not being debarred from holding office in the ACTU or some labour councils or the CAI because of this sort of legislation. I do not really think we need to take up the debate with these very minor points.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Isaacs spoke of the Government's approach as being confrontationist. He said that it was not conciliatory. In fact, the legislation is designed to cure a quite specific defect. We are tackling this matter in what we think is a most appropriate and fair way. The legislation is certainly not designed to be confrontationist. Our support for the Australian Trade Union Training Authority, which again has received a quite substantial increase in funding in the Budget, is evidence of our concern to have effective professional trade union officials. I think that this measure could be seen to be complementary to our quite positive approach to training trade union officials. The Government parties when in Opposition always supported the Trade Union Training Authority. When we were in Opposition I was a foundation member of the council of the Authority. Since becoming Minister I have renewed my deep interest and direct involvement in the activities of that organisation. We have been quite bipartisan in our approach to that matter. I think this approach of weeding out or debarring people who are on any reasonable community standards unfit to hold office is a complementary side to our very positive support for an increased professionalism in the trade union and employer organisation ranks.

The honourable member for Isaacs used, in my opinion, some very intemperate and foolish words such as 'fraud' and 'front' in marked contrast with the very measured words of the honourable member for Wills. There certainly is justification on industrial relations grounds for this legislation in that it does seek to bar from office persons who are by any general community standards unfit to hold office. Certainly, and more importantly, what this legislation will do is protect the members of registered organisations from any corrupt officials. No one denies that there are some corrupt officials. Certainly, on the employer organisations side, I would not be the least bit surprised if over time there were people who had their finger in the till or who otherwise contravened the provisions of this legislation. I would not be at all surprised if over time more people in some smaller registered employer organisations were picked up. This is not an anti-union Bill; it is a Bill designed to protect the interests and financial concerns of members of organisations no matter which side of the industrial fence they are on.

Mention has been made of youthful escapades. The honourable member for Isaacs referred two or three times to the stealing of a watch. I think the honourable member has overlooked the criteria and the case law which has been built up over a number of years in respect of the Companies Act. In fact, those criteria, which are quite explicit, are set out in clause 4 of the Bill. A great deal of experience has been gained and a great deal of guidance will therefore be available to the Federal Court in discharging its obligations under this Bill. A person could be convicted of some minor misdemeanour which is nonetheless technically a misdemeanour. However, a more serious criminal offence certainly has to be taken account of. As the House will note, under proposed section 132E the nature of the prescribed offence, the circumstances and nature of the person 's involvement in the commission of the prescribed offence, the general character of the person, the fitness of the person to be involved in the management of organisations having regard to his conviction of the prescribed offence and any other matter which in the opinion of the court is relevant, have to be examined. So this is a very carefully designed piece of legislation embodying the criteria of the Companies Act and case law and guiding the Federal Court in the application of the Bill. I do not think we could have been fairer or more thorough in the way in which we have prepared this legislation.

The honourable member for Wills said that the Bill provides for a double penalty in that there is provision already for offences under the principal Act and people may have paid their due penalty under that Act. He asked why they should be debarred from holding office if we believe that they have paid their debt under the current provisions of the legislation. We believe, and I believe, that society would support us, that if the offences to which he is referring are serious offences in respect of the discharge of office or if they go to the character of a person and there is a pattern of conduct-not an aberration but a pattern of conduct-which reflects adversely on the fitness of the person to hold office, it is the responsibility of the Government to protect members of the organisation from such a person and at least to expose the matter to judicial review. It is not that these people are debarred from holding office under this legislation. What we are doing is obliging the courts to examine a person's fitness against the criteria to which I have referred and in accordance with case law under the Companies Act. It is not in the nature of a double penalty; it is a protection for the organisation concerned that its office holders are people who conform with the basic codes of conduct which our society expects.

I want to refer to the remarks that were made by the honourable member for Wills in respect of the provisions concerning recklessness. These words were drafted with some care. In fact, a great deal of thought was given to the way in which proposed sections 132F and 132D were drafted because we wanted to exclude the kinds of petty offences or wrongdoings that might otherwise get caught up. We all know that in the industrial relations arena not only can there be the sort of Christmas party festivities and so forth to which the honourable member for Melbourne Ports referred but also that at times of tension in industrial dispute settlement people sometimes can get into arguments in pubs and elsewhere and might even inflict unintended but nonetheless fairly serious injury upon someone. We wanted to try to exclude that sort of situation so we put in the word 'intentional'. It could be that the pattern is not one of thuggery. The tension of the moment could get the better of somebody who ordinarily would not resort to fisticuffs or whatever. We wanted to make sure that we did not catch up an otherwise impeccable career of an official. We do not want him to be ineligible to continue in office or to serve because of some slur of criminality . That is the reason for the inclusion of the word 'intentional'. The 'reckless use of violence' provision was deliberately designed not to catch the inadvertent damage by motor vehicle or some such thing but more the nature and pattern of the thuggery which has characterised some aspects of the building industry in particular where damage to persons and property has been part of the mode of operation and something which is quite intolerable to the community.

They are the reasons. It is certainly true, as the honourable member for Wills says, that we have not drawn upon other legislation. But I think the courts are so used to expressions such as 'intentional' or 'wilful' that they will be able in the spirit of this legislation and having regard to the criteria set out in the immediately preceding section to understand the intention of the Parliament so that we do not catch up some much more innocent event. The honourable member for Wills raised the question of medical practitioners having been found to engage in reckless or negligent conduct and being able to continue to practice. I will refer that matter to the Minister for Health (Mr Carlton) to see whether the Commonwealth has any role in that respect. But, quite frankly, we thought we drew that section in a way which was very much in keeping with the pattern of behaviour revealed by the two royal commissions and designed to prevent the inequities that otherwise might have appeared.

I think I have covered many of the points made by the honourable member for Melbourne Ports. I hope I have covered the motor manslaughter provisions. If that offence is connected with excessive alcohol, it is rightly regarded as a criminal offence. If that offence was an aberration, under those criteria the courts can reduce the five-year period of disbarment. If a gaol sentence was involved, one would expect that the official would not any longer continue running the organisation from gaol but would, in fact, be ineligible to serve during that period anyway as a matter of practice. The community should not and does not take drink driving and, therefore, manslaughter cases arising out of it , lightly. Therefore, there is nothing in this Bill in respect of the period of disbarment that could be said to be unduly punitive. I stress again that this matter is open to judicial review and the penalty can be reduced. For example, in the event of a person going home from a dispute settlement and going to sleep at the wheel from sheer exhaustion, again the courts could take that into account. If a charge of manslaughter ensued, of course, the penalty would have to be reviewed judicially. I am sure if it involved an aberration in conduct, the courts would, under those criteria, take that factor seriously. I believe nobody could object to that.

I think the Opposition in respect of the loans and donations matter has been quite paranoid. It was not our intention to do other than to conform with the Act as it currently stands. As the Act currently stands, Part VIIIAA and the supporting regulations cover all loans, grants and donations over $1,000, and contain provisions which enable members or the industrial registrar to get details of those loans or grants or donations from the organisation. That was a recommendation of the National Labour Consultative Council. As I am informed, the Australian Council of Trade Unions had no difficulty in accepting that proposal. In fact, this Bill does not require that these donations be published. It simply says that they must be approved by the committee of management, that there must be adequate security in the repayment arrangements in respect of loans and they must be made available to a member of the organisation at that person's request.

We could not have drawn the provision more narrowly. Had we tried to do so we would have excluded the very sorts of loans that were revealed in the Winneke Royal Commission into the activities of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation. For example, there were loans by the Builders Labourers Federation to persons who were not members of that union. It would not be in the interests of union members to have donations to persons who were not members of the unions exempted from this provision. What a nonsense it would be if the BLF members were entitled to find out about loans to members of the unions but not loans to friends of union officials. That is the very point which the Winneke report was concerned about. Neither the words of that report nor the words of my second reading speech should be seen as not narrowing that down. I cannot accept the amendment proposed but will refer it to the Attorney-General in the manner described and certainly take note of the concerns of the Opposition in that regard.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition wishes to move an amendment, which has been circulated in my name, relating to clause 4, page 5, lines 14 to 18 of the Conciliation and Arbitration (Management of Organisations) Amendment Bill. The amendment is in regard to proposed new section 132F (1) (b). I can be brief as I dealt with this matter in the second reading debate. So, I just indicate here that that proposed new section includes as prescribed offences those offences listed under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and its associated regulations . I simply make the point to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee) that we regard this as a situation in which the legislation lays down its own set of penalties. We regard it as inappropriate that, in the circumstances of an official of a union or an employers organisation being found guilty of an offence and paying the penalty, there should be imposed this quite severe additional double penalty which is involved in making such an offence a prescribed offence for the purpose of exclusion from office. For those reasons, we say to the Minister that it would be appropriate that he should accept the Opposition amendment excluding that part of proposed new section 132F (1) (b) from the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I again make the point that in regard to the approach that has been adopted, the example that I gave before of members of the medical profession being involved in a fraud or dishonesty under the relevant regulations was not, I think, picked up by the Minister in his reply. I suggest to the Minister that there is really a double standard here. If a member of the medical profession has been so found guilty all that happens, as I am instructed, is that a statement is put up on his surgery wall or somewhere to say that he has been so found guilty. There is no suggestion of a double penalty in respect of his being precluded from pursuing his profession. I suggest to the Minister that this provision represents a double standard approach.

I also briefly make the point that I did not find entirely convincing the Minister's observations in regard to proposed new section 132F (1) (d). I simply flag that in respect of that provision I hope, whatever the good intention of the Minister was, that we do not find a situation where acts of officials, which he would not intend to attract the penalty of being excluded from office, by the vagueness of the wording of 'reckless' use of violence or the causing of death or injury to another person or the reckless damaging or destruction of property will be caught up. We may find that that paragraph is capable of catching up acts which were neither intended by the Royal Commisioner to be covered by what he was talking about nor indeed are in the mind of the Minister. Having made these points, I simply move the amendment which I have circulated and which I repeat seeks to exclude from the legislation the proposed new section 132F (1) ( b). I move:
Clause 4, page 5, lines 14-18, omit proposed paragraph 132F (1) (b).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MACPHEE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that I have already in my summing up on the second reading covered that point. While I am not sure that we have any legislative authority in respect of fraud and dishonesty by doctors-I think it is purely a State matter-I will take the matter up with the Minister for Health (Mr Carlton). Without condoning fraud or dishonesty by the medical profession, I could see a difference to the effect that having been guilty of fraud or dishonesty of itself does not disqualify a person from being an effective medical practitioner in the strict sense. Of course, this provision is aimed at the conduct of people in respect of the holding of office. Therefore, anyone who has been guilty of any of the offences listed here has been involved in something which clearly is improper, whether it is tampering with ballots, the defalcation of union funds or whatever. That does go very much to that person's character.
—They can continue to be financial.
—Yes, they can continue to be financial members of the union.
—What I am saying is that a doctor, in regard to the relevant legislation, is in a position where what he does in regard to financial arrangements--
—Order!

—I understand the point. There is still the question of dealing with clients, being honest in respect of the medical funds and the rest of it. I will refer that matter to the Minister for Health. Again, whatever the shortcomings of that legislation, State or Federal, for the time being it does not gainsay in my view and in the Government's very firm view the judgment that members of an organisation, whether they are employers or unions, are entitled to be protected from officials who would contravene what is generally seen to be a proper standard of behaviour. There is an avenue for judicial review. If the application of this section is, in the eyes of the courts, deemed to be harsh in a particular case the court may reduce the period of disbarment from five years to nothing at all. So really there is total discretion there. The Opposition would be wise to see how this matter works out in practice. Certainly through the National Labour Consultative Council and through a review of the Act which is now under way and which will find its way back to the National Labour Consultative Council there will be avenues for review on a tripartite basis and certainly on a government basis. I think that the matters that have been put can be taken into account once we have this section in practice.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Macphee)-by leave-read a third time.
Sitting suspended from 6.8 to 8 p.m.
Debate resumed from 27 October, on motion by Mr Nixon:
