That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I wish to say that the Opposition does not oppose the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill. We welcome it. I will not refer to all the details of the 11 or so amendments because the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) detailed them very thoroughly in his second reading speech and in the explanatory memorandum. On behalf of members of the Opposition I wish to record our thanks to the Australian Wheat Growers Federation for keeping us well informed of the genesis of these amendments, part of which flowed from the national grains conference last year. The way the Federation argued them through its own conferences and its own associations has been very encouraging indeed because these measures represent quite an advance in the marketing of wheat. The Australian Labor Party still backs the Australian Wheat Board as a single seller of wheat, but in these times when there is a fair amount of debate going on about flexibility I do not think we should wipe out discussion-I emphasise the word 'discussion'-about the flexibility that could be granted to licensed agents . The Opposition has no clear policy on that matter; it is something that should be discussed in the interests of flexibility.

SPEECH.PARA: As we are all aware, the wheat industry is to go before the Industries Assistance Commission for the next five-year plan, and the IAC will have to report by about 30 September 1983. Tonight we are discussing interim adjustments -if I may put it that way-to the present plan. We will have a new wheat Act for the 1985 season. In terms of these amendments and the marketing flexibility that the Wheat Board will now have, I should also like to take this opportunity to say that it is just as important to pay attention to the role, the function, the organisation and the composition of the Australian Wheat Board. The Labor Party hopes that some of these matters will be given attention, as well as marketing flexibility, because the Wheat Board is a statutory marketing authority that handles very large sums of money-something like $2.5 billion last year-and it is very important that it be properly structured, that adjustments and changes to the way in which it acts be put through the Parliament and that it be given as much flexibility as possible.

There has been a lot of discussion in this Parliament and in the past one about ministerial responsibility, ministerial control, the delegation of authority, and accountability, and the Australian Wheat Board has been at the centre of some of these discussions and findings by committees. We welcome the fact that the Wheat Board is coming out of a period in which it was under a lot of attack, particularly by the Auditor-General with respect to the presentation of its accounts. One of the amendments tonight makes it easier for the Board to record accounts and the closing of its pools from one season to the next. We welcome this measure very much indeed. I think it is very important that the policy of the Wheat Board be separated from marketing to a functional degree because the marketing arm of the Wheat Board certainly requires as much flexibility as possible. The marketing arrangements in this Bill are a great advance.

I guess it is appropriate to look quickly at the world scene and the Australian scene. There is a large crop of wheat in the world at present. The United States price support program will probably keep prices at about their current level. Production is up in Western Europe and it is down in Eastern Europe. There is a near record crop in the United States, and there is a disastrous crop in Australia. I think we are all very much aware that the present drought, as far as Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland are concerned, is very much a wheat belt drought. I hope that the Government will recognise that fact next season as some wheat growers will not get all that much advantage from the generous drought measures announced by the Government in terms of the provision for buying seed for next year's planting.

The world situation always concerns Australian wheat growers. One could take a very pessimistic and a very optimistic view of how our future will go in this regard but it seems to me that the reality always comes down somewhere in between. If we did have two or three bumper harvests in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and a rapid expansion in the European Economic Community, if the Americans used their loan rates and commodity credit programs, and if stocks went up and then they provided a lot of credit facilities, this would cause a lot of trouble in this country. On the other hand, if the USSR has continuing problems with its wheat production, if there are downturns in United States of America and Canadian production and if there are some reforms in some of the inadvised economic policies of the EEC, we would have a situation where world prices would boom. As I have said, I think the situation is always somewhere in between. I would think that next season, as the Americans have their granaries full to overflowing, they would willingly activate their set aside program. World trade this year will be of the order of a 100 million tonnes. This figure is probably a bit up on what it was last year or so. Recently President Reagan announced that he would be sending more wheat to the USSR.

I turn now to the question of our policies with respect to wheat, and the situation of Afghanistan. Australia, under the Fraser Government, went along with President Carter who put grain bans on the USSR. We had a problem inasmuch as we did not know which United States Administration slavishly to follow. Of course we ended up not following. We just paid a bit of lip service to both Administrations as our trade with the USSR has gone up many times. I think we should move to more regular trade with the USSR instead of abusing that country selectively for domestic political advantage. The realities of world politics are such that in moral terms I cannot see what is diferent from the USSR policy, the murder in Afghanistan, United States policy with respect to Nicaragua, El Salvador or, going back a decade, Vietnam. It is not just a question of ideology . It is a question of large powers acting out their own interests. Of course I accept that the United States is an ally. It is a friend of this country. In the case of wheat, of course, it is a competitor.

If we look at the Australian situation we see that our wheat output was estimated by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics at the end of October to be 8. 9 million tonnes. It is my understanding that that estimate has gone down a bit further to about 8.6 million tonnes which is barely half of last year's crop. Barley and oats are in the same position. If I can just read from the BAE's grain estimates, the winter cereal production is estimated at 11.6 million tonnes-about 10 million tonnes less than last year. Of course this is due entirely to the failure of the critical spring rains over most of eastern Australia. There have been some patchy rains in parts of these States in September but they were not sufficient to stop further large reductions in the size of the crops. Some of the seeded areas are being grazed off, have been grazed off, or are being cut for hay but, of course, farmers wish to avoid the risk of total loss on fields severely stretched by moisture deficiencies.

Three south-eastern States-New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia-are expected to produce only about 2.8 million tonnes of wheat this year. That is the lowest output for these States since 1957. The worst State is Victoria where the crop is estimated at a little bit over half a million tonnes which is only 24 per cent of last year's crop and the smallest in that State since 1934. The overall picture would have been even worse but for the average or better rains received during August and September in most of the Western Australian grain belt. That State's wheat crop should yield slightly better than average this year and is forecast to produce about 5.5 million tonnes, although my colleague Senator Peter Walsh from Western Australia tells me that the wheat in some parts of Western Australia is not as good as he expected when he was there recently. As I have said, it is very much a wheat belt drought. Interest rate provisions under the drought assistance measures introduced by this Government will help wheat producers, particularly those who have bought machinery. Many wheat producers will try to sit this drought out and hope for a better season next year. I hope that this Government is open to any requests from wheat producers. Perhaps it can help with seed purchases when they replant.

I shall go through the amendments briefly. They will apply from 1 October 1982 for two seasons. As I said, the current IAC hearings are intended to recommend the arrangements thereafter. The revised arrangements will be backed up with changes in legislation in each State as the whole system depends on complementary Commonwealth-State legislation. The proposals came from the Australian Wheat Growers Federation and the Australian Wheat Board and aim to improve the commercial flexibility of the Board. I think a lot of this arose from the grains conference of last year. These 11 amendments have become necessary to complete the operation of the five-year plan introduced in 1979. One additional measure that the Government has initiated, of course, is the amendment with respect to the import of wheat.

The substantive amendments are that the Australian Wheat Board will be allowed to hedge sales of wheat and commercial borrowings through the wheat futures markets and the financial futures market. The legislation is carefully drafted to define hedging so that there is no speculation on future markets. If one speaks to wheat growers one finds that they are still a little worried or concerned about the whole idea of futures. I guess that it is a fair statement to say that most people do not understand futures markets and they are somewhat worried. However, the bill is very carefully drafted. The Wheat Board will proceed with this added flexibility in a very thorough and professional manner. There is not any risk in the way that this venture on to the futures markets is going to take place. Another substantive amendment will be to give the growers a choice between several deferred payment systems to receive the guaranteed minimum price. Another amendment is that the accounting year becomes a seasonal year from October to September. As I have said, that will help the Wheat Board in its accounting.

Another amendment allows the Wheat Board to make provisional allowances and charges to cover quality and freight and then to adjust them later-again another measure for flexibility. Another amendment is to allow small quantities of wheat to be transferred between annual pools to get them finalised earlier. I think this again gives added flexibility. Another amendment allows wheat to be redelivered to growers for stock feed purposes at a discounted Australian Wheat Board price. This is in the interests of growers, particularly in a drought or where they have delivered more wheat than was wise. There is an allowance also for the Australian Wheat Board to accumulate reserves. I think this is to be welcomed. The financal relationship between the Board and the authorised receivers in each State will be altered to some degree. Another amendment, as I have said already, will allow the Wheat Board to import wheat. There will also be tighter control over the requirement for Board members to disclose their pecuniary interests in a matter being discussed by the Board.

There is also an amendment that states that food aid commitments on behalf of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau can be met by buying overseas wheat . I noticed yesterday that the Australian Wheat Board announced its estimate of receivals for this year to be 7.9 million tonnes based on a production estimate of 8.6 million tonnes. This means that the expected gross income from this year' s crop is about $1,480m. Last year the gross value of wheat produced was $2,535m . When we look at exports we find that the BAE estimates our export income from wheat will be down by about $200m even though Australia's production will be down by half. This means that this year there will be only about a three per cent or four per cent decline in the value of rural exports from a drought affected wheat industry. Next year may be a very different case indeed. The Wheat Board has been selling off its stock to meet its export commitments. Quite apart from the problems for the wheat industry the problems for the economy will come next year if we do not have a bumper crop to meet our export and local demand and replenish our stocks. I think it is proper to say that the drought and the situation of the Wheat Board should be a very good demonstration to people in the cities of how dependent we are on our rural exports for export income and how critical this is to our balance of payments situation. We have a balance of trade deficit of something like $9 billion. That necessitates maintaining high interest rates to get capital inflow. If we had a bigger wheat crop this year, and certainly stocks available for sales next year, we would be in a healthy position.

The whole situation makes me somewhat concerned about the Government's ability to manage the situation if there is not a bumper crop next year. I would like to explain why this is so because the wheat industry links very directly to the general macroeconomic management of this economy. Other than a paragraph at the outset of the Budget handed down by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) on 17 August no indication was given that there was a major drought in eastern Australia. There was no indication that hundreds of millions of dollars would shortly be allocated for drought relief. At 17 August the Budget deficit was estimated at $ 1.6 billion. As honourable members know it was an election Budget and the Government was prepared to expand the deficit by that degree. Less than two weeks later we had an indication that the deficit could easily double. It could double because export income would be down and government expenditure would be up probably by $700m part of which was with respect to two drought measures-the fodder subsidy and the interest rate subsidy, let alone the extra funds for carry on finance and other drought measures. The Budget deficit figures are clearly going to be blown out by wrong estimates of the unemployment levels and that has been the centre of debate in this House.

The Government announced its expenditure on drought relief with almost no consultation with any of the States involved which have to administer the schemes. From my reading of the Senate's Estimates Committee transcript it was probably against the better advice of the Department of Primary Industry in its administrative procedures. The legislation was certainly rushed through Parliament. Will this Government ever have any long range plans for primary industry or will it simply react to crises and in the process create more crises ? I am pleased that the Government and the Minister for Primary Industry have commissioned a 600-farm survey to assess the impact of the drought on primary producers. I understand that the BAE will carry out the survey in the next three weeks and prepare a report for the Australian Agricultural Council. The Opposition hopes that the result of this survey will prove to the Government that there is a need for a long term drought policy, not ad hoc measures after the event. The question is: How are primary producers expected to budget and do their farm management planning when from one day to the next they do not know what assistance this Government will or will not provide? As I said on earlier occasions, I think droughts are different disasters from floods, fires or cyclones. For example, I know of producers in Victoria in drought declared areas who bought fodder the day before the fodder subsidy measures became operable. These producers will not be eligible for any assistance. I do not blame any one government for that but I am trying to illustrate the fact that when measures are not in place all the time some absurd situations occur. The example I have given is quite inequitable and one which the farming community finds impossible to understand.

As I have said before in this House, the package of drought measures rewrites not only the farm management guide book for Australian agriculture but also our macroeconomic management policy. It is clear, from what has transpired, that the annual budget is not as important in this Government's management policy as this Government previously had us believe. Within two weeks the deficit looked as though it would double and by six weeks there were projections of it being $4 billion. In these amendments to the Wheat Marketing Act 1979 which is before us are references to the Government and the Minister for Primary Industry overseeing some of the commercial management decisions of the Australian Wheat Board which these amendments will allow. I hope that eventually these sorts of questions are defined more thoroughly with respect to all the statutory marketing authorities under the Minister's control. The questions of ministerial delegation and powers of direction are something that need to be more clearly specified. I can only say that given this Government's performance as an economic manager I do not see that provision as being much of a guarantee for the Australian public or the wheat growers. The Minister for Primary Industry's performance as overseer in the meat substitution scandal and with respect to P.T . Indomilk and the Reserve Bank of Australia loans to dairy farmers and the previous Minister for Primary Industry's performance with respect to the Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd affair do not give me much faith in those provisions.

The amendments to the Wheat Marketing Act are to improve the commercial flexibility of the Australian Wheat Board and to allow it to use its commercial judgment in management decisions. I hope that this commercial judgment will extend to a recognition of what is also required by wheat growers. For example, the Barley Board has announced that barley growers will receive an earlier payment than usual to assist them through the drought period. I would hope that the Wheat Board will consider the similar plight of its suppliers and not just the best interests of the Wheat Board alone. It certainly has a very difficult job on its hands.

I touch briefly on the matter of domestic price. I think we are all agreed that the guaranteed minimum price mechanism is working very well; but, given the drought, there has been a bit of debate recently about the situation of the domestic price. By and large the present plan provides for the domestic price to be about 20 per cent above the export price. As we export so much, we have about a 15 per cent or 20 per cent premium on an average of 8 per cent of the crop. So , it is not something that gives the growers a great deal of benefit but it causes some concern to internal consumers. The domestic price is at present above the export price. For most of the period of the various wheat plans, the wheat growers have subsidised domestic consumers. That involves the transfer of well over $1 billion if one takes the full period since, I think, about 1947-48. I cannot remember the exact figure, but something like $1.4 billion seems to come to mind.

I think we have to stick with this sort of arrangement. I think it is in the long term interest of the wheat industry and domestic consumers that we have some ups and downs, some flexibility and some sort of formula. One of the matters that is not recognised particularly by the community is that the flour mills are carried by the Wheat Board or the wheat growers inasmuch as the wheat is stored by the wheat industry and, effectively, credit is carried through the year so that the flour mills in Australia have their wheat flowing throughout the year and get the choice of the best qualities. The wheat industry is helping domestic consumers in that way.

The arrangements for the pricing of wheat sold on the domestic market recognise the different uses of wheat-namely, for human consumption, stock feed and industrial purposes. The present Act provides for a fixed domestic price for wheat used for human consumption which applies throughout the marketing year and is uniform at all ports of export throughout Australia. That price is determined annually by the Minister based on a formula set out in the Act. For stock feed wheat, the Wheat Board can exercise more its own judgment. The formula takes account of the estimated current season's export price, movements in export prices over the previous eight seasons and those of the previous year in the index of prices paid by farmers. Movements in the formula price from year to year are subjected to a limit of 20 per cent. This limit applied in both 1980 and 1981. In addition, a further component is included in the domestic price of wheat used for human consumption to meet the cost of shipping wheat to Tasmania from the mainland.

Australia will produce an exportable surplus with or without government intervention. The principal function of intervention on the domestic market is price stabilisation and not price support. I am not fixed in my attitude about how best to provide price stabilisation but I would like to make a few points. The price paid on the domestic market over the longer term should reflect the prices received from sales to overseas countries of comparable grade wheat. I think it should be recognised by the industry that any premium built into the longer term price has only a marginal impact on growers' returns. This is because the domestic market absorbs such a relatively small proportion of total production. However, any premium falls heavily on Australian consumers and other rural producers. In fact, consumers bear the direct and indirect costs of any premium. That is, the premium is reflected, for example, in bread prices as well as in the price of eggs because of the feed wheat fed to hens and the nature of the intensive livestock industry in general.

I think consideration should be given to using the guaranteed minimum price as the instrument for stabilisation with no premium extracted from the domestic market. I am saying only that that is something that should be floated. I do not hold firmly to that view but it is something I expect the IAC will examine. I point out by way of qualification a consideration that under certain circumstances in the short term there is a case for including a premium under the domestic pricing formula. For example, when production is down, say, as a result of drought or world prices suddenly fall substantially below trend, growers returns and cost ratios fall for reasons totally outside their control. In those sorts of circumstances short term transfer from Australian consumers to wheat growers is justified as a useful supplement to a more general package of assistance. Advocates of a freer domestic market must recognise that such policies are likely to conflict with stabilisation objectives.

I would like to canvass two other matters briefly. They concern the transport, handling and storage of wheat. These remain the major problems facing the wheat industry, with the capacity or ability still to threaten the wheat industry's future prosperity. Any reform of the existing system will require existing participants to acknowledge that they are part of a national system and are not self-contained, autonomous components. The Wheat Board needs greater influence over the transport, handling and storage of wheat, but there are quite a few political impediments to prevent that from occurring. The State bulk handling authorities and the Wheat Board at various stages have not even been able to talk freely. If Australia is to minimise grower costs and to maximise marketing options, it needs to be able to specify where and when grain is to be transported and how it is to be segregated. To undertake this function adequately, the research effort of the Wheat Board also needs to be extended.

Finally, I would like to talk about research. There is still within the wheat industry a quite active debate as to the extent to which potential yields flow through and are of direct assistance to the growers, the extent to which wheat breeding should still concentrate on top quality bread making and the extent to which wheat breeding should concentrate on disease resistance. As part of my research with respect to the plant variety rights debate I went to quite a few wheat breeding institutions and saw the magnificant work being carried out with respect to disease resistance, particularly at Wagga and some of the other public plant breeding institutions where scientists were very actively engaged in this form of research for the wheat industry.

There is still an excessively bureaucratic system of committees and organisations with respect to research, and there is a need for some mission- oriented program of research. There are various committees in each State. While I would not say that they should be torn down, because they have been there for quite a while and the industry thinks they have served it well, I think there is a need to look at the overall research program and to give it a bit more mission orientation. Some recent work was published about the yield potential of wheat and how much of that flowed through. One study showed that of a 5.2 per cent increase in wheat yield only about 0.9 per cent was actually due to the plant breeding. It was more a question of the yield potential being reached because of technology, rotations, agronomic practice and farm management. I think there is still a lot of room for reform with respect to the overall classification of Australian standard wheat in Australia's wheat breeding programs. It seems to me -I think the Wheat Growers Federation agrees-that too many wheats are placed into the one overall grade and that there is a need for more indications, more messages, more signals, to be sent back to the industry in this regard.

I will not take up the time of the House any longer. The Opposition welcomes these measures. They give the industry a lot more flexibility. They came from the industry itself. They did not come from the Government. The Government has acted reasonably quickly on this occasion to implement the wishes of the wheat industry. I have stressed through this speech that they will give the Wheat Board a lot more marketing flexibility. They will give the Wheat Board the chance to exercise its commercial judgment. What is needed more and more is for the big agricultural marketing authorities which show the potential, the ability and the capacity to exercise commercial judgment to be given the opportunity to do so. They should be free from as many controls as is possible. The Opposition welcomes the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill contains some very significant and widespread amendments to the Wheat Marketing Act 1979. The implementation of these amendments will bring into being those proposals put forward by the Australian Wheat Growers Federation and the Australian Wheat Board for variations to the existing wheat marketing and pricing arrangements. This season, as the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) has already said, the cereal production throughout Australia will be very much reduced. The very severe drought that we are experiencing, particularly in the eastern States, also coincides with a world-wide economic recession and this has resulted in a major loss of confidence in our rural areas. Many economic uncertainties exist today across the whole face of rural Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess all of us realise that drought is an inevitable part of rural life. It is also a paradox that the worst farming conditions on the eastern side of Australia in at least 40 years follow one of the most incredibly productive seasons in Australia's cereal industry-the 1981 season. We all appreciated, too, that rural communities are total communities. Farmers, small business people and rural wage earners appreciate their dependence on each other and it will need a combined effort using all our resources to overcome the difficulties of the months ahead.

The rural sector of Australia has undergone massive change over the last 50 years. The farming sector generally has been able to meet the challenges of technology, the impact of rapidly increasing fuel prices and the destructiveness of inflation by improved farm techniques and increased productivity. I think this drought is now bringing home to many people in our urban areas the importance of agriculture to the economic viability of this country. The amount of $8,000m annually has been the average of rural export returns over the last 10 years. I believe we have the capacity to double this amount over the next 10 years. Unfortunately, at the present time, world economies are sluggish and protectionist policies throughout the world are growing. Major markets, such as the European Economic Community, Japan and the United States of America, are restricting trade, and trade with the Soviet Union and its allies is always subject to political interference. The months that follow will be a testing time for all our communities because of the drought, declining farm returns, high interest rates, and, as I have said, tariff barriers.

This Bill does a number of things. The proposals in this Bill empower the Australian Wheat Board to operate on wheat futures and financial futures markets , to establish financial reserves and to introduce options in arrangements for the payment of a guaranteed minimum price. Proposals put forward by the Australian Wheat Board will be accommodated in this Bill in the context of the current severe drought conditions. The Bill will empower the Board to import and market domestically foreign wheat should the need arise. Additionally, the Bill will enable the Australian Wheat Board to act on behalf of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau to secure foreign wheat for Australia's food aid program if necessary.

The existing marketing and pricing arrangements will rely on complementary Commonwealth-State legislation and each of the States intends to amend its legislation to put the revised arrangement into effect. The revised arrangement will apply to the 1982-83 season, beginning on 1 October 1982. As I have said, the Australian wheat industry and particularly the Australian Wheat Board will experience very severe difficulties in the month ahead, particularly in the marketing area. Severely reduced production will make it difficult to service our major markets-markets that have been developed with great expertise and effort over the years-and will make it difficult for the Australian Wheat Board to meet Australia's responsibilities to the world food needs.

Estimates released earlier this month by the Australian Wheat Board and the Bureau of Agricultural Economics indicate that the 1982-83 wheat crop will be well down on the 1981-82 level of 16.3m tonnes. The BAE had estimated that the 1982-83 production would be about 8.9m tonnes while the Australian Wheat Board's estimate was 8.6m tonnes, which is the lowest since 1972. I believe that this estimate could be well reduced even further in the days and months ahead. As I said production is down significantly in all our eastern States but fortunately, in contrast, I hope that in Western Australia we will have a record crop for harvesting.

I turn now to some of the specific proposals in this Bill. Probably the most significant proposal is that which will give the power to the Australian Wheat Board to operate on wheat, financial and currency future markets. It will give the Australian Wheat Board use of futures markets which will enable the Board to hedge on the wheat future market of the world. It will give the Australian Wheat Board the ability to hedge on the currency futures market and financial futures market to protect Australian wheat sales and also its commercial borrowings used to finance payments to growers. It will provide authority for the Board to hedge transactions on futures markets which will enable it to use a marketing mechanism that is accepted in the international commercial trading of grain. Of course, it will allow secure price assurances for our unsold wheat. I also emphasise in relation to this proposal that the definition of hedging has been included in the Bill to preclude any suggestion of speculation by the Board on futures markets. Of course, the Board's future operation will be subject to very strict guidelines approved by the Minister for Primary Industry.

A further proposal in clause 6 of the Bill enables the Australian Wheat Board to establish financial reserves from the 1982-83 season onwards and to deduct money from the sale of wheat and wheat products from those reserves. It will allow for deductions for reserves and these will be excluded from the guaranteed minimum price arrangements. Details of reserves will be disclosed in the Board's annual reports. When reserves are no longer required money in the reserves can be distributed for the benefit of the wheat industry. In this Bill we have assured that the Government's financial liability under the guaranteed minimum price arrangements will not be increased as a result of deductions made from these reserves.

For a number of years-particularly in my electorate which is one of the major wheat growing regions of Victoria and Australia-growers have been requesting a better system of payment. One of the proposals contained in the Bill will enable this to take place. Farming today is of a sophisticated, modern nature. It requires more flexibility and a better ability by the wheat industry to manage its financial situation. As a result of the proposal which is contained in clause 7 the Australian Wheat Board will be able to enter into optional arrangements for the payment of the initial advance of the guaranteed minimum price entitlement to growers. Under these arrangements growers will still be able to receive their guaranteed minimum price entitlements as a lump sum on delivery of wheat or, if preferred, in the form of two or more payments on conditions as determined by agreement by the Australian Wheat Board and the grower, subject to equity being preserved between growers.

A further proposal simply gives authority for the Australian Wheat Board to make advance payments to growers other than the initial advance without the approval of the Minister for Primary Industry. This will remove an unnecessary control and quicken procedures for payment. Contained in clause 6 of the Bill as well is a proposal that will enable the Australian Wheat Board to transfer a residual stock of wheat from one pool to another subject to the Australian Wheat Board having determined a price for that wheat. Of course, it is the intention of the Minister to consult with the Board as to the desirability of its determining and announcing each season its policy in respect of the residual stock which is intended to be transferred to these later pools.

In another proposal contained in clause 11 the Australian Wheat Board will be able to allow growers to redeliver wheat of one season to a grower subject to the terms and conditions determined by that Board. It will ensure that the redelivery provisions give growers the option of obtaining stock feed wheat by taking delivery of wheat delivered by them. The delivered wheat of course need not be of the same quality as that of the previously delivered wheat. The price charged for redelivered wheat will be determined by the Australian Wheat Board and will be equitable between growers. This will be based primarily on recovering the guaranteed minimum price with adjustments for quality and storage and handling costs. A further proposal in the Bill will enable the Australian Wheat Board to make payments to authorised receivers on the basis of rates determined by the authorised receiver in each State and in accordance with the remuneration agreements in force at the time. That is contained in clause 17, and it allows for that remuneration by the Australian Wheat Board for costs incurred by its authorised receivers to be at specified rates.

There are a number of other proposals in this Bill, but one which is important, in view of the current discussions relating to statutory authorities in this country, is the adoption of an accounting period in line with the crop year ending 30 September. This will bring the Australian Wheat Board's financial year in line with the crop year and ease administrative overloads. Following on from this change, the Australian Wheat Board's annual report will be submitted to the Minister for Primary Industry by 31 March of each year, instead of 30 June, unless a later date has been approved by the Minister. It may, of course, be necessary to extend the reporting period for the Board's next annual meeting, which will be during the transition year.

Perhaps one further proposal that should be mentioned is the proposal in the Bill that will enable the Australian Wheat Board to determine provisional allowances for the quality of wheat delivered, and for State freight, handling and storage charges, and to make adjustments with respect to individual growers by the amount that the provisions differ from the allowances determined at their final level. This will be more equitable than the existing arrangements under which the full amounts of the charges and allowances, which can differ significantly between growers, are not necessarily brought to the account of those individual growers.

Finally, I turn to that proposal which empowers the Australian Wheat Board to import and market domestically foreign wheat should the need arise. This measure has been brought about because of the current widespread drought. Its purpose is to give the Australian Wheat Board increased flexibility in the complex task of allocating limited wheat supplies from the 1982-83 crop amongst the needs of its regular and major export markets and the requirement of the domestic market and for our food aid programs. Any imports of wheat will need to satisfy quarantine requirements and be subject to the approval of the Minister for Primary Industry under the Customs regulations. Before the Minister gives approval under these regulations to the import of any specific shipments of wheat he will need to be satisfied that the import arrangements are in respect of a specific demonstrated requirement for that wheat, that it will comply with quarantine requirements, that it is consistent with the existing orderly marketing arrangements under the Wheat Marketing Act and that it will not create logistical problems at Australian ports.

In order to satisfy these requirements and in view of the Australian Wheat Board's predominant position in wheat marketing arrangements, it is expected that any application to import wheat will emanate from the Australian Wheat Board. I believe it is important that the marketing arrangements for domestic and foreign wheat are consistent, otherwise they will be inequitable between users and will undermine existing orderly marketing arrangements. Accordingly, the price charged for foreign wheat will need to be consistent with the pricing policies for Australian Wheat as set out under the Wheat Marketing Act.

The final proposal that is of some significance to our aid programs is the proposal that will allow the Australian Wheat Board to act on behalf of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau to secure foreign wheat for Australia's food aid programs. The Act is being amended to enable the Australian Wheat Board to act on behalf of the ADAB in securing foreign wheat to meet our food aid commitments, and it is important that the Australian Wheat Boards' expertise is used in negotiating shipments of foreign wheat direct to Australia's food aid recipients.

In 1979 the Government adopted recommendations made by the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest relating to a code of conduct for all persons holding statutory positions of public trust, including members of statutory authorities. Accordingly the opportunity has been taken in these Bills to incorporate the necessary change to existing provisions in the Act regarding conduct of members of the Board to align them with the requirements of that code of conduct. The provisions as amended by the Bill are consistent with such provisions in legislation enacted since 1979. Similar amendments are being made to statutory authority legislation in force prior to 1979 as the opportunity arises.

I am pleased that the Opposition does not oppose this Bill, which was obvious from the speech of the honourable member for Werriwa as he tended to speak about issues other than those contained in this Bill. I assure him that if he wishes to travel into the farming community area which is suffering from widespread drought at this time, he will find that the Government's very significant and generous proposals that have been put forward concerning a number of drought measures are understood and appreciated. I can assure the honourable member that no more generous proposals than these have been initiated by any Federal government in Australia. This Bill, as I said earlier, does give effect to the specific requests of the Australian wheat industry. It provides a new flexibility to meet current conditions and gives the Australian Wheat Board the capacity to operate in a sophisticated trading environment. Of course the amendments are a product of the wide consultative process that this Government, and particularly the Minister for Primary Industry, conducts with the Australian wheat industry and all other rural industries in this country. Of course, the Government very strongly supports the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Australian Labor Party also to support the proposals put forward by the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation and the Australian Wheat Board. In doing so I make it quite clear that it does not necessarily mean that the Australian Labor Party supports either the National Party or the Liberal Party. Here we have legislation enacted on behalf of those people who are putting forward proposals to the Government. It must save the Government a lot of problems and work when organisations such as the Wheat Growers Federation and the Australian Wheat Board are prepared to put so much time into drawing up proposals to enable the Government to bring down legislation. It is no trouble for the Opposition to come into this Parliament tonight and actively support these proposals because it is quite clear that even from the first and last paragraphs of the speech made tonight by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) the work has been done by the industry. It just goes to show what sort of a situation can develop if there is a little socialism in the planning of the wheat industry rather than the so- called free enterprise that members on the Government side are always putting forward. It is no problem to us on the Labor Party side actively to support proposals put forward by the Wheat Growers Federation. There is no doubt that the organisation of a national wheat industry certainly is to the benefit of the wheat growers and to the general economy of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: As I go through my speech I will be able to point out to the wheat growers and to the public of Australia that they have a lot of problems as they would know at the moment not only with the drought and the world economy but also the Government which sits back and allows them to put forward proposals and which runs the economy to their disadvantage. The proposal of a guaranteed minimum price in the Wheat Marketing Act allowed for early payment to wheat growers with a 15 per cent variation limit. Something that needs to be pointed out is that many operations are funded by borrowings by the Wheat Board. Among the sorts of borrowings that last year created for the Government a lot of heartburn was the fact that the Wheat Board had to go on to the open market for funds at a time when the monetarist policies of this Government were such that people going on to the market for funds were creating enormous pressures on interest. Those interest pressures have rebounded very solidly against the farming community.

Let us look at some of the adverse effects of the Government's policies in relation to farmers and particularly the wheat industry. One of the most crippling factors, besides the drought, that farmers face at present are interest rates. We know that because of the drought the Government has decided to give some rebate on interest rates, but that will not go to the majority of farmers. There is no doubt that they will find that out as time goes along. The assistance which some farmers will receive until it rains will not be of any benefit in comparison with what good economic management of this country would have achieved. In fact, if the Government had collected its taxes from the time when it took over in 1975 and started to collect the oil levy within my area in Gippsland-and it probably had the best economic base of any government in the Western world upon which to govern the country-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member is now losing relevance to the question before the House.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill clearly changes the Act in such a way that allows the Wheat Board to do certain things in the economy, including the futures market and hedging, for example, which are definitely economic adjustment matters. What I am saying is that, whilst the Wheat board can put forward proposals which are of assistance to it, this Government, by its own policies, is counterbalancing that assistance to the detriment of the wheat industry. One of the great costs in the industry is fuel. If fuel is not an issue as far as the wheat industry is concerned, I do not know what is. Of course the cost of diesel has gone up by something like 6c per litre . The farmers have to pay that sum and then seek a rebate. We are looking to another increase of 6c on 1 January. This results from the management of the economy because of which the value of our money is going down in relation to the value of American money. Many wheat farmers are well aware of the sort of approach that this Government has taken in respect of the economy. All these measures that the Government would like to take credit for are not those of the Government. If we look at the Government's policies, either those of the Liberal party or of the National party, we will not find too much in them about the sorts of matters in this Bill. Industry has to come forward with these proposals for the Government to be able to take action.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a counter-balance. We have a Bill which is of benefit to the farmers. It has been counter-balanced by the poor policies of the Government. There is no farmer in the community who does not understand the sorts of expenses that farmers ran into in the last three, four or five years because of the Government 's management of the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will not vote Labor.

—Honourable members should not worry about their not voting Labor. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) said that they will not vote Labor. His party certainly lost the Upper House seat in his own area at the last Victorian State election. He should not bet his bottom dollar that they will not vote Labor. They are certainly heading that way now.
—It is not a wheat growing area.

—It is not a wheat growing area, I must admit, but the wheat growing areas right throughout Victoria were Labor at one stage and they will return again. There is no doubt about it; the way the Government is going, it will push them back.

SPEECH.PARA: I now move on to a point regarding the domestic consumption price. Over many years we have had a set price for domestic wheat which at times, even though it is only a small proportion of the amount of wheat that is produced, has been far in excess of the world export price. At one time, one could say that the domestic consumer was subsidising the wheat industry to some degree; but any proper evaluation over a period clearly shows that the position equals itself out over a period. There is no doubt that the policy that the Wheat Board has had in operation for many years is one that whilst at times is harder on the domestic consumer over a period equals itself out. Even though at times it is playing to the producer there will be other times when the producer will subsidise the consumer. That is one point in this Bill that we do not oppose but we believe that it needs consistently to be looked at.

I refer now to a couple of other points. One is mentioned in the Minister's second reading speech, a copy of which I have before me and which relates to the powers of the Board and its futures operations. The Minister said:

The Bill will empower the Board to hedge wheat and financial transactions on future markets thus enabling the Board to secure price assurances for its unsold wheat. The Government accepts the view of the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation that the Board should be authorised to hedge on future markets at this time.
Once again the Government does not take the decision on its own. It clearly outlines that that is the view of the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation. The Minister continued:

The authorising of the Board to hedge transactions on futures markets will enable it to use a marketing mechanism that is accepted in international commercial trading of grain. Experience has shown that the hedging of transactions on futures markets facilitates grain trading.

It is worth making a couple of comments in that area. Of course our traders will be going into an area where thay have not had the experience that other people overseas have had. I hope that the Government will see that the right sorts of experienced people are appointed to deal with these futures markets so as to protect Australian industry and the Australian economy. The Minister further stated:

Under the proposed arrangements the Board will be able to hedge on wheat futures markets, currency futures markets, and financial futures markets to protect its wheat sales and also its commercial borrowings used to finance payments to growers.

We are talking about a very vital issue. I would like now to quote from the ' World Agricultural Report', thirteenth volume, dated September 1982, an article by Greg Ansley entitled 'Collapse in rural America'. I think this is something of which all Australians, and all wheat growers in particular, should be well aware. He states:
Rural America, with the rest of the nation, is in the grip of a slump that has all-too-ominous overtones of the Depression of the 1930s.
Net farm income, adjusted for inflation, is at its lowest ebb since 1938.
Farmers are living off their equity and many this year will pay more in interest than they'll earn from the property.
Total farm debt stands at more than $200 billion, with a debt/income ratio of more than 10 per cent.
By mid-June the Commodity Credit Corporation had spent $10.5 billion on farm price supports and loans, against previous annual outlays of less than $3 billion.
A massive increase in United States Government Budget spending is creating an enormous surplus. Mr Ansley continues:
The way things are going, federal farm price supports may add $9-$13 billion to a budget deficit that has already topped $100 billion.

Support industries are in chaos. The collapse of elevator companies is so serious that the US Department of Agriculture has issued advice to farmers on how to reclaim their grain from bankrupt businesses.
Farm machinery and equipment sales continue to fall, with a combined $223.7m loss for the April quarter, posted by International Harvester and Massey- Ferguson alone.
We know what effect International Harvester Australia Ltd is having in Victoria at present. The article continues:
Unemployment is running at 9.4 per cent, the highest level for 40 years. International Harvester has laid off more than 40,000 workers since 1979.

Increasing pressure for more protection, especially retaliatory action against the EEC, is a major threat. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade warned that current world production trends could spark another 1930s-style crash.
Record crop projections and mounting stockpiles add to the problem, especially as there seems little chance of an early turnabout on global commodity markets.
These are the markets and the types of atmosphere into which this Government is now going to send Wheat Board futures dealers. The article continues:
For the grain trade--
This is vital to the wheat industry in Australia-

those stocks are potentially devastating. If the US is moving to sell them off under subsidy it could launch what Australian Wheat Board Chairman Sir Leslie Price fears would be 'the greatest grain price war in history'.
And through it all, the overall US economy limps along with what even some Reaganomics supporters say is a slim (at best) chance of an early reversal.
It probably has as much chance as Fraser economics. Mr Ansley goes on with this vital paragraph:

What happens now in the US is of immense importance to the rest of the world. Only America can inflict more harm on other economies than they can return and most farm sectors are depending on a US-led recovery for their own well-being.

Although we have had a big downturn in our wheat production because of drought it is of great concern to think that we are moving into a situation where the things that have been mentioned in this article could be vital to the future economy and the wheat growers of this nation. Mr Ansley further states:
For the rest of the world, probably the greatest threat of America's current woes lies in its potential for promoting greater trade protection.

The US believes it is getting the sharp end of the trade stick, especially in agriculture. Pressures for greater protection and retaliatory action are behind much of the current campaign against EEC farm subsidies.
Americans argue that the EEC is blatantly flouting an informal understanding reached in Tokyo not to cause disruption to their traditional agricultural market.

The US calculates that EEC subsidies have: boosted annual wheat exports from an 'historic' 7 m tonnes a year to 14 mt; cornered 20 per cent of the global sugar market; challenged Australia as the world's number one beef exporter; and snatched 35 per cent of the international broiler trade.
Europeans justify this on the grounds of the US trade deficit with the EEC, and last year's world-wide farm trade surplus of almost $27 billion.

It is no wonder that the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is warning that growing protection could spark an international liquidity crisis that could see a return to the 1930s style insolvencies. It says that we are following the run- up to the Great Depression.

I will now make just a few comments on the economy in Australia at the present time. As I said earlier, we could have been in a very strong position if our legitimate taxpayers had paid their share of taxes and this Government had been able to keep out of the market for funds. We may have had a situation in which interest rates were not as high as they are in Australia. We may have had a situation in which the economy was in a better position to withstand some of the excesses that it is feeling at the present time. International Harvester is in trouble not only in the United States of America but also in Australia. Wheat farmers are not buying tractors. They are not buying the equipment that they were buying previously. Not only because of the drought but also because of high interest rates. The Government must take some of the blame because of its economic approach.
I now turn to page 6 of the Minister's speech and speak a little about the finalisation of pools. The Minister in his speech states:

The Australian Wheat Growers Federation has proposed that when the stock of wheat held in respect of a season is reduced to a residual level the Board should be enabled to transfer it from one season to another.
The Opposition does not disagree with that proposal; in fact, it fully supports it. The Minister further states:

The Bill provides that the Board should transfer residual stocks from one pool to another only when it has priced the wheat and such a transfer could not potentially cause or add to a call on the Government's commitment under the guaranteed minimum price arrangements. I will be taking up with the Board the desirability of it determining and announcing each season its policy in respect of the residual stock which is intended to be transferred to a later pool.

I would have thought that the Minister should take a much stronger stand on that . He is saying that he will be taking up with the Board the desirability of determining policy. I think the Minister should have it clearly in his mind just what the position should be as far as transferring residual stocks from one season to another is concerned. He should clearly lay down some guidelines rather than take up at this stage with the Board the desirability of doing something. Surely to goodness the Government can do something on its own without waiting for the Board to give it advice.
I conclude by referring to the last paragraph of the Minister's speech. I was rather intrigued by it. It clearly indicates the position from which I started. The speech states:
The amendments contained in this Bill arise essentially from proposals put forward by the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation and the Australian Wheat Board .

I do not know whether the Government is trying to put itself in the position where if anything goes wrong it is not responsible for it. Certainly, the Minister has been putting paragraph after paragraph into his speech stating that these are proposals put forward by somebody else and not by the Government. The speech continues:

The revised arrangements take account of changed circumstances for the marketing of wheat since the current five-year plan was introduced in 1979. These proposals, especially in respect of imports and hedging, will assist the Australian Wheat Board in its complex task of marketing the Australian crop to the best advantage.

There is no doubt that this is a very complex task. Australia is very fortunate to have a wheat board and a wheat growers federation that are in such a strong position that they can clearly put to this Government advice which is of benefit to the industry. The Minister states:
Experience with the revised arrangements will be reviewed in the context of consideration of wheat marketing arrangements beyond 1983-84. I commend the Bill to the House.

Perhaps the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party and their organisations may be able to come forward with plans which will provide some stability in the wheat industry. Nowadays those parties place all their emphasis on proposals put forward by other organisations I point out to the Government and to the political parties that support it that perhaps they need some of those people back in their organisations. I know that a lot of those people are in the Australian Labor Party and we are very glad to have them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-One cannot help but be amused by the approach taken by the honourable member for McMillan ( Mr Cunningham). He tried, first of all, to chide the Government because of the continued co-operation and consultation that exists between the Government and the Australian Wheat Growers Federation. He chided the Government because it is prepared to accept amendments that have been worked through by the Federation after a great deal of consultation with me as Minister and with my Department over a couple of years. Of course, the honourable member for McMillan would not be aware of that bit of history. SPEECH.PARA: One thing I can say about the speech of the honourable member for McMillan is that Ralph Willis, the shadow Treasurer, is not at any risk. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) will recognise that. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think the Minister should refer to the shadow Treasurer as the honourable member for Gellibrand.

—I am delighted that at least the honourable member for McMillan put a bit of fire into the debate. The shadow Minister, the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin), was as dull as dishwater. He parroted the usual stuff, saying: 'I have not really thought this through but I will float this and I will float that and if it rests somewhere the Labor Party might pick it up as policy'. SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Werriwa disappoints me every time he comes into this House and talks about primary industry Bills. I have yet to see anything of substance emerge from a speech made by the honourable member for Werriwa. He is very good at knocking legislation in a not totally unsubtle way but we are yet to see any positive thinking on his part. At least the honourable member for McMillan had enough courage to have a go at the economy although he was a bit astray about the causes of inflation and high interest rates. TALK.START.PARA: —May I have your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker, to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill and the Royal Commissions Amendment Bill 1982. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—It is the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these two measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been agreed the we have a cognate debate covering the Royal Commissions Amendment Bill 1982, which will amend the Royal Commissions Act of 1902, and the National Crimes Commission Bill 1982, a new piece of legislation to establish the National Crimes Commission. The Opposition will move amendments to both measures. These amendments have been circulated. The amendments to the Royal Commissions Act will give commissions the power to summon witnesses and take evidence. A provision is contained in the Royal Commissions Amendment Bill for dealing with people who fail to attend hearings or who fail to produce documents. It deals also with the question of search warrants and self-incrimination. We accept some of those matters but we have moved amendments to this legislation to give more safeguards to the rights of people affected by it. A number of amendments to the National Crimes Commission Bill have been circulated. They relate to protecting the rights of people who may be obliged to appear before the Commission. If honourable members look at the drafting of the legislation they will see a suggestion that a commission has power to obtain evidence and search warrants. The question arises whether the hearings should be public as well as private. Of course none of this will relate to the prosecution; it is like a pre-trial.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important when we are dealing with crime that we balance the situation and the rights of the individual are not affected. That is where we think these two pieces of legislation are defective. We want the Government to accept the amendments which have been on notice for some time. If the Government does not see its way clear to accept them we think that the legislation has a fatal flaw and we cannot be expected to support the proposals, not that we do not want to get to the real issues in dealing with crime. I think that is where one would like to start the debate on this matter. If honourable members look at Hansard for this session of Parliament they will see that we have spent an enormous number of days discussing what is called white collar crime, the failure to prosecute white collar crime and the failure to detect white collar crime. We have had a plethora of reports in a number of areas, whether it be the meat scandal, the tax scandal or something to do with the painters and dockers. One sees a whole mass of action taking place merely to try to tell us something that perhaps most people in the community know. That is that an enormous amount of crime is being committed. It is not being detected and it is not being dealt with.

Let me make this point. We still have to adhere to the principles of justice. Anybody who is prosecuting a person has to have evidence. Everybody who is prosecuted is entitled to be assumed innocent until it is proven beyond reasonable doubt that he is guilty. It is probably significant that earlier today a report by the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking entitled 'Nugan Hand (Part 1)' was tabled. Nugan Hand bank has disappeared. Nugan has died. Hand cannot be found and it is thought that he is dead. If one looks at the ramifications of the report one will see enormous problems in the normal course of events to detect and deal with high level crime . Legislation and statutes have obviously been designed for what one could call the horse and buggy days because that is about the extent of the technology, by way of transport or anything else, that was applied.

We now have massive international arrangements dealing with intelligence operations; the ability to gather intelligence across the world without leaving one's country; the ability to transmit funds into international bank accounts; and the ability to use aircraft. All sorts of extraordinary additions have come into play. These measures ostensibly assist a country in the normal course of its trade and commerce or defence, whether it be military activity or intelligence gathering. If the personnel who are involved in those sorts of actions becomes corrupt or addicated to criminal activity in a sense we say that perhaps we are unable to deal with it. That cannot be the situation. If one looks at Chapter 10 of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, which I think came to light in September this year, one will see a number of matters which the Commissioner, quite properly identified as being of very great significance.

He mentioned the two unpublished reports which none of us, except the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and perhaps the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden ), has seen because they were confidential reports. In addressing his mind to those reports he spoke about the very serious nature of organised crime. He said that there are currently discussions in the highest places concerning the need for a Crimes Commission. Now the Government has gone on post haste, to say that it will set up a crimes commission. I would have thought, and I know that people thinking about this matter would have thought, that the Government would have been able to act at least in co-operation with the State governments irrespective of their political views. But the Government has not done that. In rushing this legislation into the Parliament it has bypassed the States. That is an extraordinary gaff in getting any sort of intelligent understanding of what we are about. Anybody who has been discussing a unit, a commission, a group or any sort of special secretariat has said that what we need is a body composed of a judge, the police and representatives of the public who are able to marshal all the resources that are needed to detect crime as against prosecuting criminals. There needs to be some co-ordination between all levels of crime detection in Australia. This will not happen under this proposed commission.

One of the most significant suggestions of the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs was that there be access to tax records. Costigan also makes this valid point also. One is really stretching one's imagination to suggest that criminals who give evidence will tell the truth. In fact, he makes it very clear that they will continue to lie. That is their natural predilection. They have no intention of telling the truth. He said that it is only when one gets to the documentary evidence that one can ascertain that, in fact, they are lying. So one wonders why we will have a commission of unknown quality. The chairman might be a judge but the rest of the members could be any people one likes to name. This group will ascertain all the rights and wrongs of complaints and will assemble, with a view to prosecution of the offender, evidence of the commission of an offence. I think that is the wrong way to go about it.

I am mindful of the fact that one has to get some balance on the question of what it is all about. Whenever the control of organised crime is considered, the investigative powers are stressed. But if the proposed Crimes Commission is to be properly constituted its hearings would have to be either secret or public. If they were secret, the possibility of all kinds of abuse cannot be overlooked. If, on the other hand, it operated openly and publicly and with the possibility of media coverage for the witnesses, there would be the real danger of trial by association. So honourable members can see the real problems of such a concept. Where do the rights of a citizen be if, in one sense, he is being investigated in secret or, in another sense, investigated in public. Both can do him or her untold damage.

We should look at the examples that we have had before us in recent times in this Parliament. I refer to the Berthelsen case which has nothing to do with crime as such. Berthelsen was an employee of the Department of Defence. He left that Department and joined the Auditor-General's Office. The Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence inquired into defence purchasing and Berthelsen gave evidence in camera to that Committee. One would expect that evidence to be confidential and secret and not made public to anybody. The evidence was that there was something wrong with the communications section of the Department of Defence and, as honourable members know if they look at the reports of this Parliament, that evidence caused the House of Representatives Standing Committee of Privileges to meet. It took evidence from the top present or former public servants. It was noticed that a number of them were overseas at the time and were unable to give evidence. But those who gave evidence said that they found nothing wrong with Berthelsen. They said he was the pillar of propriety and an excellent person. However, Berthelsen made the point, which was subsequently substantiated by the Committee, that because he had given evidence in camera he was victimised. In fact, he was placed on what is called the reserve list of the Public Service, which is the nearest thing to commercial extinction one can find from the point of view of continuing to belong to the Public Service.

The point I am making is that the man gave evidence in secret to a group of politicians of this nation, but there was no secret about what was said. Putting the situation at its best. The evidence he gave was immediately leaked to the Department of Defence. In fact, quite extraordinarily, the evidence was sent through the post, which seems to be our method of giving people some cover. Mr Berthelsen's evidence was sent to the Defence Department and he got somebody's else's transcript. If one looks at the minutes of the Defence Department one sees that the people in that Department solemnly met to consider how to counteract Berthelsen's evidence.

The matter had nothing to do with criminal conduct but it had everything to do with the rights of a person who gave legitimate evidence in camera on what he felt was wrong with the communications system. I have made the point that he was about to be removed from the Auditor-General's Office and placed on the reserve list. All the witnesses who came before us said that there was nothing wrong with him but when we looked at the files we found that this man was ready for the high jump because he had done this dreadful deed of telling elected members of the national Parliament there might be something wrong with their communications system.

If one also looks at what happened recently in the Volkman case one must begin to wonder where the integrity of governments lies. The Volkman case involved a man who felt entitled to make a complaint to the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs that there was something dramatically wrong with the former Federal Narcotics Bureau. Volkman's evidence, which he gave in camera to the Williams Royal Commission, named individuals who were associated with white collar crime. He virtually wanted the appropriate authorities to have a look at whether there was some substance in what he was talking about. I have a copy of this evidence which was given in 1978. Volkman complained bitterly that he felt something was dramatically wrong with the Narcotics Bureau because it was not grappling with crime. He mentioned the Nugan Hand Bank; he mentioned the involvement of the Central Intelligence Agency intelligence; and mentioned people in high places. He talked about the laundering of money. He also talked about the mafia. But nothing was ever done.

Because this gentleman had enough courage and integrity to go before the Williams Royal Commission to give evidence in camera what happened to him? As it turned out, none of the evidence was in camera. The unfortunate person gave evidence, but some of the people who were apparently assisting the Commission-to use that term-felt they might have had a duty also to tell their superiors in the Public Service that Volkman had blown the whistle on them, to use the vernacular. What happened to Volkman after that? This is the modern day and age of democracy. Volkman was charged with sending birds out of the country. Of course, one of the things he had to do in the course of his job was to police that occurrence but he was charged with that offence.

In the course of the charges being laid a search warrant was issued. Officers went to his premises and immediately grabbed from him a copy of the in-camera evidence in which he named most of his colleagues-if one can call them that-who were guilty of some crime. He beat the first charge in a prima facie hearing on which the Government spent a lot of time. It even appealed against the magistrate's decision to allow evidence. He beat all those cases. The magistrate said: 'I do not think there is enough evidence to have a trial by jury'. Nine months went by and the present Attorney-General (Senator Durack) filed an ex officio indictment against Volkman. Eventually that too was quashed, but only after the Government spent millions of dollars prosecuting this man. It called 56 witnesses, including some from the Federal Bureau of Investigation of the United States. This poor unfortunate had to mortgage his home to defend himself.

What is the lesson in this? In the process of giving that evidence he began to talk about matters mentioned in the report on Nugan Hand, by the Commonwealth- New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking, presented today. He referred to massive international crime, to narcotics, to Nugan Hand, to the Central Intelligence Agency, to Australian Security Intelligence Organisation influence, to intelligence officers not doing their job but instead becoming mixed up in rackets for personal gain, and to the use of aircraft in and out of this country. He referred also to people who have since met their demise because perhaps they were involved in these crimes. It is a pretty horrendous story and in that these facts are known, is not being over-dramatised.

The guilt must lie in very high places. What was the real pressure upon the Government to persecute this man to such an extent? If he had been charged and found guilty of just exporting birds he would have been subjected to a pecuniary penalty but, instead, he was charged with conspiracy under the Crimes Act, which seems to be a novelty reserved for tax evaders and avoiders, because he might then have to do five years in gaol. The Government should look at its own intelligence operations and the motivation and influence for the Attorney- General spending so much of the taxpayers' money in pursuing a man whose only crime was to give evidence in camera.

Those are two examples of what can happen in a Crimes commission type of situation. Who would be prepared to go before a Crimes Commission and make a statement about something that he believed was wrong? Let me make the position very clear. There is a great and urgent need for a type of criminal investigation unit conducted at the highest level but I do not know that it ought to have a permanent structure. That would present dangers. The best safeguards would be to use the judiciary and not the police force, in the first instance. Because the judiciary would be removed from direct affiliation with the investigation of crime, if a citizen such as Volkman or Berthelsen felt that there was rottenness or corruption, whether in the Government, the Opposition, the bureaucracy or the police force, he could go somewhere and make a complaint to a judge, whether Federal or State, and say: 'I think something is dramatically wrong. Perhaps the taxation records or banking records would show it.' If the resources of the intelligence agencies would reveal it access to them could also be provided as well. The complainant would be protected. He would not be 'rubbed out', as happened to Cosgrave, one of the persons whom Volkman mentioned, or the Wilsons, who were buried because they had the unfortunate tenacity to make complaints. If a person comes in conflict with high level criminals the hit people, as is very evident from the Wilson situation in the United States, can soon get him. Wilson was a former CIA agent who was engaged in gun running, but no witness to the crime seems now to be available.

If all of these facts are put together and a need is seen to provide some sort of structure, the way proposed in this legislation is not the way to go. Who would want to appear before the proposed National Crimes Commission and make a complaint? One could not trust the fact that it was deemed to be made in private , especially in view of what happened to Volkman. Nothing can be private if evidence has to be given that way. It is far more important that a citizen be able to appear before some recognised official who would not disclose his identity, who could make appropriate investigations and then send such information as may be required to the Attorney-General or to the police for further action. In the process of building up such a structure it is important, as has been identified by all who are interested in the subject, that since we have police forces and other sources of information permanently employed, they ought at least be involved with each other in guaranteeing that there will be no mismanagement of information.

The Government has failed miserably by trying to bypass the States in this matter. It has no hope of running effective crime detection units if it bypasses the States.
