In most cases the States would have immediate access to known criminals through their police forces and would have details of all the company structures through their corporate affairs commissions.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have they done?
—The point is that meetings were set for the various Attorneys- General. They have been ignored by this Government, which is surprising.
—That is not right.

—It is right. It is no good the Minister shaking his head. They were to have appointments with him as recently as 5 November. The Government has raced this Bill into the House. What chance do the States have to co-operate with this Government under this Bill?

SPEECH.PARA: In the few minutes left to me let me advert to what the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) said in May. He said that organised crime had penetrated all Australian States and that there had to be action to ferret out the politicians and businessmen involved. I do not know what evidence he had of the involvement of politicians and businessmen but he said that he could have spent at least five sitting days in the parliament under parliamentary privilege having a real fling at a couple of people in government, had he wanted to do so. His duty was to do so. We have not heard from him since in that regard. At the same time the police chief said that he had no evidence at all against politicians. I do not know the motivation at the time of the Minister in charge of the police.

Let us look at other statements the Minister was making back in May. He said that we were losing the fight against crime and that a series of royal commissions had shown that we have major problems, including drug trafficking, arms dealing, the laundering of money, the corruption of officials and terrorism . Is it not about time that we had some real action in this regard? His own Commissioner of Police, then Sir Colin Woods, said that while he was reluctant to speak openly about other police forces, he was a strong supporter of joint efforts with other police forces to attack entrenched organised crime. The Opposition wants to help the Government to get an intelligent approach to this matter, because it is a question not of votes but of how we are to look at crime .

What did the Costigan Royal Commission into the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union identify as the big problems? Costigan said that perhaps we do not have the appropriate personnel and that the right personnel have to be trained. He also raised the question of how that personnel might be equipped. He said that those personnel are not the police forces that we now have; they have to be a bit above that. He said that it was very difficult for federal police officers to understand white collar crime at its highest level. He said that white collar crime involved a number of people-not only the low grade criminal who might perpetrate the final act but also the mastermind behind the organisation. He mentioned the entrepreneur, the investor and the type of financier who was rarely present at the commission of a crime and who acquired a fair amount of financial acumen. He said that the amount of money involved was measured in millions of dollars.

This is not just a straight proposition. For example, Costigan said that drug trafficking required the movement of money out of Australia by international transactions. Nugan Hand was a way in which to do that. We cannot expect the average policeman to follow that sort of train of events. The Reserve Bank and other institutions should have had registers of money coming in and going out. It would not have been too hard to look at tax records. It would not have been too difficult to understand who were the sorts of people who might be involved. Had an intelligence agency used an aircraft to move heroine into the country, at least there should have been some suveillance of it. There should certainly have been some observation of people who were going in and out of the country without passports or visas and who perhaps were identified with crime. We need at the highest level some organisation that can clearly investigate justifiable complaints. Volkman made such complaints. Costigan talked about the problems of high level crime and how it runs into millions of dollars. He said that he was satisfied that the criminal organisation which is described in this report is flourishing in Australia.

Just because the Government is establishing a National Crimes Commission it cannot really expect that it will deal with the problems. I suggest that the Government needs an intelligence unit. An intelligence unit would pick up all the intelligence sources within Australia, including the State sources. It would pick up the source of their intelligence information. The Government will make itself virtually counterproductive if it ignores the States and if they become hostile. I note from the public media that none of them now wants to be involved with the Federal Government in the establishment of a National Crimes Commission , not even Queensland or Western Australia. They feel the Government is trying to set up something of which they will not be a part. I can understand their concern, but what does it do for the Australian citizen who is very concerned about the fact that crime is rampant in Australia and when there is evidence of this from Costigan himself? Mr Costigan said:

The scope of this criminal organisation should not be assumed to be limited to Australia. It certainly includes . . . South East Asian countries. It stretches its tentacles to the USA and there is some evidence to suggest that the criminal elements of that country play a role in the execution of the schemes of this organisation.

So they do. It is very clear that they do. The organisation went as far as international arms trafficking. Some of the deals mentioned were laundered by Nugan Hand. Who received the money? Surely that ought to be a source of interest to both the United States and Australia. Here we are bereft of any aptitude or evidence to try to establish what happened. I have asked the Prime Minister whether he had any evidence and he said: 'No, we have not'. People who have had any dealings with arms going to Argentina would know that at least one $30m contract went through Nugan Hand. Let us consider the massive amount of heroin which was imported into this country. Where did it come from? It did not come from within the country; it came from outside it. The people involved brought this material into the country by air. Apparently they had some sort of protective device because they were deemed to be associated wih intelligence activities when, in fact, they were associated with criminal activities. Nothing was done. Ever since there has been death and destruction and it is permeating our society. The correct remark was made today by the Minister who said that there has been an erosion of business morality. It is not limited to business morality; it permeates our whole structure. If the nation feels that the Government cannot grapple with this situation it must think that it is completely inept, as it would appear to be.

My plea to the Government in the final minutes of my speech is to have another look at the structure of the National Crimes Commission. We will agree with the necessity to deal with the ability to identify high level crime, but is this the way to go? The answer is no. Is it right to ignore the States? The answer is that it is not. Is it right to get some sort of co-operation whereby criminals can be dealt with both inside and outside Australia? Is it important to talk about the corporate structure and to ensure that it does not engage in continual crime, as it is doing? Costigan talked about Nugan Hand and others in the corporate structure who were mixed up with the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. He made the point that that was just a cosmetic front and that if the Painters and Dockers Union was closed down those organisations would certainly find another front-it would not matter to them. What is the Government doing about the criminals involved in these activities? Costigan virtually named them. The activities are not just limited to tax evasion.

I make the point, as which Costigan made very well, that the Government needs to appoint specially trained people-I would start with the judiciary-to identify the merits of the complaint. That would guarantee the protection of the informant who, in my view, would be at risk. If members of the judiciary were able to say: 'Yes, I have found some evidence', the matter should go to the appropriate body-whether it be the Federal Attorney-General or a State Attorney- General-to consider prosecution. That would not interfere with the rights of the citizen. It would be a case of merely obtaining access to the intelligence which was already available in Australia. It would mean that our own intelligence agencies were not above the law. It would mean that the Central Intelligence Agency was not above the law simply because it had some intelligent cover. The white collar criminals in this country would be dealt with. We have to establish that sort of concept. The Opposition's amendments to the legislation will merely try to give some rights to the citizen. I think the Government ought to have another look at the National Crimes Commission Bill to see whether it could be redrafted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to join briefly in this cognate debate on the National Crimes Commission Bill and the Royal Commissions Amendment Bill. The stated objective of this legislation, which is to secure investigation and prosecution of offences of a serious kind, particularly offences in the nature of organised crime, is, of course, commendable. Whether the apparatus to be set up to achieve these objectives is the best way of going about it is another matter, and I will come to that in a short while. What is interesting is the apparent rethinking or even the double take by the Australian Labor Party which seems to have rather belatedly signalled its support, albeit qualified support, for the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not long ago that the Opposition was firm in its public antagonism towards these measures. The gyrations of the Opposition culminating in a complete about face, as I see it, is something of a mystery to the interested observer. The Opposition's spokesman on legal matters, Senator Evans, gave an interview a couple of weeks ago on Australian Broadcasting Commission radio which did not give much of a clue as to the reasons for his party's change of heart. He did, however, confirm that the Labor Party was unlikely to oppose the legislation although again his rationale was not all that clear. The shadow Minister made one comment worthy of attention. He said:

Our concern is that although this is probably an effective model for a permanent crimes commission in the future, the real justification for it in the mind of Mr Fraser is to use it as an excuse for winding down, terminating eventually the services of Mr Costigan, who's been doing such an effective job, and replacing him, in effect, with someone more to this Government's political taste.

By intimating a preference for the appointment of Mr Costigan to head up the National Crimes Commission in the terms that he used, Senator Evans may simply have intended to divert attention from his party's back flip. The accusation that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) was motivated by a wish to curtail Mr Costigan's work is clearly spurious. This Government appointed Mr Costigan to inquire into the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. It subsequently, when those investigations revealed large scale tax frauds, extended the terms of references to enable the royal commissioner to take in this new line of inquiry. That is hardly evidence of the Prime Minister's or the Government's preoccupation with Mr Costigan's politics or his political preferences. However, it does say something about the importance that Senator Evans places on the political affiliations of appointees to royal commissions and if that is carried through to the nth degree that can only be deplored. Questionable also must be the changes of mind, apparently at the behest of their masters who comprise the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party, by the Premiers of Victoria and New South Wales. Mr Cain and Mr Wran were less than enthusiastic about the creation of a national crimes commission before Senator Evans made his proclamation. Even now the silence of the New South Wales Minister for Police can only be described as deafening.

Although the Government will, after the passage of these Bills through the Parliament, be committed to a national crimes commission, there is room for misgiving about the way that it has arrived at its decision. The Acting Attorney -General (Mr N.A. Brown), who is at the table, acknowledged in his second reading speech the emphasis that the Commonwealth gave to 'the greatest desirability of the States and the Northern Territory participating in this matter'. I would have put it even higher than that. The active and committed support of the States and the Northern Territory is essential. If the purpose is to harness the combined talents of anti-crime agencies to combat serious and organised crime around Australia, one could be forgiven for thinking that a prerequisite was the full co-operation of the States and the Northern Territory. After all, they control seven of the eight police forces in this country.

Despite the machinations of the Opposition and the fancy footwork of the Premiers of Victoria and New South Wales, the States are plainly not supportive of this proposition in its present form. To the extent that the misgivings and doubts of the States and the Northern Territory exist, they should have been satisfied before the Government took the unilateral step of introducing legislation. It is not consistent with the Government's federalist policies to act unilaterally while a series of ministerial and officer level conferences is in progress. Surely the Government could await the outcome of those conferences- the suggestions and good will that that process could produce. Even at this late stage I urge the Government to follow that course.

In so urging, I am mindful of the fact that as recently as 20 August this year a meeting of the Australian Police Ministers Council first considered the Commonwealth's proposal for a crimes commission. In acknowledging that the proposal embodied in this Bill was 'one possible option to be considered', the Police Ministers Council went on to add:

. . . a second option advanced by Western Australia might be to upgrade and further develop the Australian Bureau of Criminal Investigation including the established links with operational law enforcement agencies around Australia.

Subsequent meetings in which Commonwealth representatives participated fully and a projected meeting in Melbourne last Friday, which did not eventuate because its deliberations were pre-empted by this legislation, were to be held to come up with constructive suggestions as to how to deal effectively with organised crime in Australia. One of the constructive suggestions for the consideration of the Commonwealth as well as the States and the Northern Territory called for the establishment of a national criminal intelligence commission. Such a commission could have used the existing law enforcement structures as they exist in Australia and would have involved upgrading the Australian Bureau of Criminal Investigation. The alternative to a national crimes commission in the form of a national criminal intelligence commission also remains worthy of consideration, even at this late stage.

I believe there is great concern in a number of quarters about this measure. There is a body of opinion that reckons the creation of a permanent royal commission, as proposed, is too dangerous. The Opposition's shadow Attorney- General is one who has expressed the fear that it could become a forum for destroying the reputations of individuals by eliciting malicious hearsay gossip which may prove to be unfounded. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) has already mentioned those possibilities. The crime committee report to the executive of the Western Australian Law Society Council commented, in relation to the proposed commission, as follows:
(1) would tend to interfere with and cause confusion within the present State and Federal Police Forces. There would certainly be competition and an overlap of the various forces.

(2) also, such a Commission would constitute a serious threat to the historical rights of its citizens for the reasons given by Mr Clifford in his comments of July 1982, which include the words: 'if it is secret--
He is talking about the crimes commission-

then the possibility of all kinds of abuse cannot be overlooked. If on the other hand it operates openly publicly, with the possibility of media coverage for the witnesses that it subpoenas, then there is a real danger of ''trial by association'' and a denial of all the human rights which the Civil Liberties Organisations are so concerned about.'
(3) the Commission could in time lose its impetus and driving force and become a hindrance rather than a help.
Mention has been made of comments made in July of this year by Mr Clifford, who is the Director of the Institute of Criminology. On that occasion Mr Clifford also said:

It is disturbing to see the way in which Crime Commissions are being linked with the control of organised crime, as if one necessarily implied the other. The United States has a number of Crimes Commissions and as most people know, it still has a very flourishing organised crime industry which the Crime Commissions may harass or embarrass from time to time, which they may even check at certain times or in certain places, but which they are quite evidently in no position to properly control. In some places a Crime Commission has been a political exercise, a kind of posturing for the benefit of the taxpayer without any appreciable effect on the amount of organised crime in the area.

That is the end of that part of his dissertation. The crime committee of the Western Australian Law Society drew the conclusion from those quoted remarks that Mr Clifford's comments are supportive of an alternative approach to controlling organised crime in Australia along the lines possible if a criminal intelligence commission is established instead of a national crimes commission. The Chairman of the Victorian Bar Council also has serious misgivings. He has written:
The Council sees the dangers associated with a Crimes Commission as greatly outweighing its advantages.
In a letter to me which advances much more argument than I intend to quote the Chairman of the Victorian Bar Council concluded:

Insofar as such a commission is sought to be defenced by reference to US counterparts, it should not be forgotten that the United States Bill of Rights confers constitutional guarantees of individual liberties. Such guarantees are not present in the Australian constitution and therefore any Australian Commission will not be subject to the same degree of control by the courts, as would be the case in the United States.
The Chairman continued:
The Bar Council regards the proposal as a grave threat to the fundamental civil liberties of all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just when the Pope has admitted that the Inquisition was wrong we are bringing one in.

—I suggest there is some truth in that. Given the opinions or stated preferences of the Victorian Bar Council, the relevant committee of the Western Australian Law Society, the Director of the Australian Institute of Criminology and the former chief of the Australian Federal Police, Sir Colin Woods, there is a case for moving cautiously towards the creation of a crimes commission or some other body with similar objectives. I believe there are others active in criminal law, and in law enforcement generally, who share the concerns of those I have already cited. Couple their concerns with those of the States and the Northern Territory and we have good reason for thoroughly thinking through the measures we may take effectively to combat organised crime. I hope the Government will be persuaded to look at the matter again and that it will accept a proposition to defer this legislation until a course of action which will have widespread support can be embarked on.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not, at the moment anyway, support the amendments foreshadowed by the Opposition-not because one or more of them have no merit, I add. Basically I do not support them at this stage because the whole basis of this legislation and what it seeks to do is too dicey and uncertain. I simply put it to the House that after 80 years without a national crimes commission or similar body another few months is not too long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the concept of the National Crimes Commission Bill. Equally I support the amendments moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen). I disagree with the Government as to the procedure. Nobody will disagree with the claim that organised crime is escalating throughout this country. The cost to the Australian community of organised crime has been estimated at a massive $5 billion. Crime reaches into every city, every town, every home and every pocket. It has forced up insurance rates, cost taxpayers more to meet the payroll of expanding law enforcement agencies and pushed social services costs to cope with an increasing army of drug addicts. It has corrupted. Its putrefaction has spread through every level of society. It has tainted professions, including those with the task of administering the law-the police, the legal fraternity, the judiciary and politicians.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to be assured that economic crime will be dealt with by the Commission. The seven elements that constitute economic crime are listed to become beyond doubt one of the major questions in the 1980s. They are white collar crime, corporate crime, computer-related crime-about which, I suggest to the Minister for Communications (Mr N.A. Brown), we ought quickly to give a reference to the Law Reform Commission-bank-related fraud, organised crime, official corruption and miscellaneous frauds. Those are the seven. Who bears the cost? Is it the corporate entity? Is it the finance house? Is it the Government? Of course not; it is the average man in the street, the consumer, the end user. He is the one who bears the brunt-not the Bar Council of Victoria.
The director of the Institute of Criminology, Mr Bill Clifford, has pointed out :
Far more money is taken at the end of a ball point than at the end of a smoking .38.
Justice Moffitt made this observation on organised crime:
It will arrive within the Trojan horse of legitimate business, fashioned for concealment and apparent respectability by the witting or unwitting aid of expert accountants, lawyers and businessmen.

The Government wants to pad them up with plenty of packing under the guise of civil liberties and human rights. I wonder whether the Bar Council wrote to me about the Greeks charged with fraud in relation to social services-not that I remember. But I get plenty of letters from the Bar Council when it comes to spivs, charlatans and corporate crooks.

Let us look at the solutions to the crime problem. The knowledge that organised and sophisticated white collar crime can be committed with impunity is obviously destructive to the morale of society and encourages a general attitude of contempt for the law. Much more sophisticated efforts and much greater resources than have been employed until now are required in this area if the cancer of organised corporate and syndicated and white collar crime is to be effectively dealt with. The extraordinary complexity of the area of crime is also presenting great problems for the court system, and the conventional methods of trial seem to be barely adequate to cope with it. I have heard no one tonight put up any constructive suggestions. Chief Justice King, in Adelaide, had this to say and it is basic, although many of my colleagues will disagree with it:

The basic truth must be recognised that the causes of crime are fundamentally moral causes and a radical reduction in the rate of crime will only occur when there is a profound and widespread improvement in the moral and civic attitudes of people generally.

There is a need for consistent law. The big problem about controlling modern crime is that our criminal justice services-this is what Clifford was talking about, and not what has been alluded to-the police, courts and prisons, were really designed for the nineteenth century and for dealing with conventional crime. Modern transnational, technically sophisticated and well organised criminal cartels are distinctly twentieth century. International law is bogged down in sovereignty limits of jurisdiction while the globally oriented modern criminal can move from country to country or move assets from country to country in a way which often makes him immune to the best efforts of national police forces, with instant access to a very sophisticated information system, all outside the control of those with the national jurisdictions.

Much of this spills over to Australia, where our separate jurisdictions are a godsend for the slick operator with appropriate legal services. That is the problem-the States. In the treatment of crime, Australia has indulged itself for too long in the luxury of separate State systems which not only leave the Australian citizen vulnerable but make Australia itself more vulnerable in international terms.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.
Mr N.A. Brown-I require that the question be put forthwith without debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr JACOBI

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been operating like petty kingdoms. Criminals have not been slow to take advantage of the boundaries which one State imposes on another or the limits of Federal jurisdiction. Federal and State police forces are handicapped by the differences in law, by the differences in bureaucracy and by boundaries which still apply in attitudes as well as in the law. Australia began constitutionally by a fairly simple combination of six States and a Federation. We had all the chances in the world to avoid the hopeless mishmash of impotence which now afflicts the United States of America and which the Government wants to continue to inflict on this country. Yet step by step we have approached the same morass with divisions arising in company law, the development of Federal courts, the setting up of independent law reform commissions, corporate affairs commissions and now a national crimes commission bereft of effective State support. Everything is piecemeal and correspondingly designed to bloat the bureaucracy without really embarrassing the best organised offenders who have the kind of legal advice which makes them experts in the limits of jurisdiction. Efficiency will be obtained when both think more nationally than parochially and concentrate on the need to prevent the criminal escaping their attention. I ask the Minister: Does this Bill help to correct the problems facing this nation? Certainly it is based on good intentions, but so is Hell. We need to know if we are not to descend further. In principle I support the Bill, but in my view it does not go far enough. The roots of our problems are deeper and more long term than will be dealt with by a super police power.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Victorian Assistant Police Commissioner, Mr Paul Delianis, recently warned that organised crime will become so closely interwoven with legitimate business that there will be a need for penetrating intelligence resources and specialist investigators to unravel its complexities and that fighting organised crime may be beyond the boundaries of present day law enforcement expertise. He believes the battle against crime infiltration of legitimate business will be further frustrated by the emergence of untouchable crime bosses and that professional assistance in the way of well qualified commercial lawyers and accountants will become more commonplace while avenues of gathering intelligence that are currently available to police will need to be exploited further. He also noted the trend towards world wide organised groups being interrelated for criminal purposes and modern business techniques being applied to crime.

Let us turn to the United States. The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) quoted Clifford. I suggest he go back and has another look at what he said in the full context. The establishment of 11 crime commissions in the United States was generally justified-let us look at the reasons-by frustration at the failure of conventional enforcement to deal with organised crime. Statistical studies showed that more than half the indictments gained against known organised crime figures were being dismissed. When convictions did result the criminal was not sent to prison in the majority of cases. Unconventional approaches were therefore sought to counter the capacity of crime bosses to distance themselves from the dirty work and exploit legal rights to the limit with the aid of talented counsel. The rationale for the crimes commissions was that they were to supply alternative controls on the crime bosses by publicly exposing them, by discovering administrative reforms which would put roadblocks in the way of organised crime, by collecting evidence of corruption or impropriety by public officials who were captives of organised crime, and by providing a backdoor method of imprisoning crime bosses.
Mr Rocher-Does Clifford support the establishment of a crimes commission?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr JACOBI

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the honourable member to wait a moment. He has had his say and he should let me have mine. I do not think he put forward anything that was very constructive. The hands of this Commission will be tied when State law is being contravened, when police structures need to be reformed, when juries cannot be found to sit for a year or more and when politicians get involved at the State level as well as the Federal level. There can be no doubt that since the late 1970s the rate at which leading American organised crime figures have been convicted has increased enormously. That can be attributed to a package of measures-I make no apology for this because I agree with it-in which the civil liberties of a small number of people have been traded off against the reduction in organised crime. Society ultimately will have to make that decision.

INTERJECT.PARA: The rationale for the Crimes Commission in the United States of America has been very similar to the reasons that are given in Australia for having royal commissions. They operate in an inquisitorial mode rather than in an adversary one. They depend on an ongoing team of specialists for support rather than the recruitment of new staff and the setting up of a new administrative structure for each reference.

Let us look at the planning role. The Crimes Commission should have the major task of co-ordinating a criminal justice service in each State. If we really want to talk to Clifford about the question, that is what he was really saying. What this nation has to do is to retool the criminal justice system. We badly need that. That is what the Minister ought to devote his mind to. I think it is an almost impossible task to get a common criminal code for this nation. It is an indictment on the State systems that we have separate criminal codes for each State. That is the task to which the Minister ought to apply his mind. This would mean investigating the malfunctioning of the present system and inquiring into allegations of corruption or the wastage of resources. The proposed commission, as I see it, will have neither the power nor the expertise to apply its mind to this problem.

I think it has to be acknowledged-the Minister must face this point-that more than 80 per cent of all expenditure on criminal justice lies with the States. It will therefore be difficult to persuade the States that the Federal Government is not seeking to extend this authority by setting up a national crimes commission. That is the Minister's dilemma. I think the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is correct; we will have to find a procedure different from the one on which the Government is embarking. Even when dealing with offences under Commonwealth law, the resources of the States are needed-police resources, courts, or corrective services. We need commissions at the local level which will consist of officers from within the services who know best how to run them as well as academics, lawyers and private citizens who can bring our democratic society into the twenty-first century in dealing with crime. If a centralised co -ordinating body is established I do not believe there will be any constitutional or political problems. In fact, such a concept ought to be welcomed by the States.

It took the Federal and State governments-I know how hard this matter was worked on at a Federal level-13 years to set up an Australian Institute of Criminology. It will take almost as long, I suggest to the Minister with all honesty, to set up the National Crimes Commission. The Institute of Criminology now provides research into policy making around the country at a rate which challenges that of any other institute of comparable size in the world. When I was in Washington recently I discussed the National Crimes Commission with officials of the Department of Justice who informed me that the Institute of Criminology has world status. There is no question of that. It was an enormous task to establish that Institute. I suggest, as an example of Federal-State co- operation, that the Institute of Criminology has no rival in this country. It ought to be supported. It is an integral part of the machinery which operates against organised or white collar crime. Its expert capacity ought to be used to the fullest advantage in planning crime commissions.

I turn now to what the honourable member for Curtin who has just left the chamber, had to say. He envisages setting up co-operation with the States in the same way as we have with company law. We have inflicted upon the corporate sector of this country an enormous, ineffective bureaucracy. What the corporate sector badly needs and deserves is a federal companies law. There is no question about that. If this Government follows this same system by imposing a crimes commission on the States we will have the same problems. We have to approach these problems on the basis of at least co-operating and talking to the States and trying to get some organised system to deal with crime in all its aspects.

I conclude by suggesting to the Minister that crime commissions are far from being automatic and convenient clamps on our rarefied problem of organised crime . I think the Government will have to work at the problem a lot harder than it already has. I do not think the Government will be able to continue or succeed in this area if it chooses to ignore the States. I agree that the Government has to continue with the concept of a crimes commission but it has to entice the States to co-operate to the maximum degree. I simply suggest to the Minister that if he gets these things wrong now it will cost a great deal more to get us out of them than it has cost to get us into them.

I make no apology to anybody. I have struggled for a long time to achieve fulfilment of this concept of a national crimes commission. I suggest to the Minister that the way in which he is going about the establishment of this Commission is fraught with many problems. I think the suggestion that was made by my colleague opposite was sensible. Before this Government places this legislation on the statute book it should go back to the States to try, at least as far as possible, to get some agreement with them to retool the law and the judiciary in particular. We struggle to get a single penal code throughout this country. If we can achieve that we will go a long way towards combatting organised crime.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Crimes Commission Bill raises three questions of truly national importance: First, the dimensions of the threat posed to our society by organised crime; second, the means that should be adopted to combat this threat; and, third, if a national crimes commission is the right means, is the model proposed by the Bill the right one?

SPEECH.PARA: By its very nature it is impossible to know the dimensions of organised crime. There are no statistics on it. But we do know that reported crime, which is a very different thing from actual crime, is on the increase everywhere. If we exclude drug offences, reported crime in Australia increased by a staggering 62 per cent between 1974 and 1979. But while it is impossible to be certain of the true dimensions of the problem two things seem indisputable: that organised crime exists in Australia and that it is on the increase. It is also indisputable that the growth of organised crime in recent years has been significant and dangerous as criminal elements have responded to opportunities of the times. As the noted criminologists Sir Leon Radzinowicz and Joan King have pointed out:
Crime is nothing if not responsive and nothing if not opportunist.

As society changes and becomes more wealthy and more permissive, as patterns of social organisation become more complex, as communications become faster and more elusive of surveillance, as commercial arrangements and corporate structures and the means of storage and retrieval of information and wealth become more intricate and sophisticated, so opportunities for criminal exploitation develop.

It is natural that criminals should respond by taking advantage of the opportunities offered to them in areas such as the illegal trafficking of drugs, organised gambling, organised prostitution and corporate frauds, to name but a few of the areas open to exploitation. A highly organised world begets highly organised crime. So crime has become-it has been for many years-big business, traversing State and national boundaries.

We are all of us conscious of the growth of organised crime. Its growth has become part of international and Australian folklore attested to by a wealth of anecdotal evidence, by growing public concern, by growing public debate and by acceptance in our language of such expressions as those used by the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) such as 'white collar crime', 'computer fraud' and as well, of course, 'the Mafia'. More concretely, however, the growth in organised crime is attested to by the increase in specialist inquiries that concern or unearth organised criminal activities. I take but a few examples: The Moffiatt Commission on Alleged Organised Crime in Registered Clubs in New South Wales, which was referred to by the honourable member for Hawker; the Woodward Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking; the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking; the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, the Woodward Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry and the McCabe-Lafranchi special investigation under the Companies Act of Victoria, the latter an instance of the growing use of special investigations under the Companies Act to detect corporate frauds.
What are the means to be adopted to combat this evil? Premier Wran in a policy statement to the New South Wales Parliament on 27 February 1979 said:

Clearly, organised crime presents a threat to our society. It is equally clear that it is the responsibility of the Governments of this State and this nation to devise means whereby they can counter and combat the threat that is posed.

One might say that the States have been very reluctant thus far to come to the party. The courses are basically two: To seek to improve the traditional means of law enforcement and especially the police forces or to do this and at the same time to adopt a fresh and major initiative. The record thus far of the conventional law enforcement agencies in the detection, in the bringing to trial and the conviction of those involved in organised crime is lamentable. Striking evidence of the deficiencies of the conventional approach is provided by the evidence of the widespread and highly organised stripping and dumping of companies exposed by Mr Costigan's Royal Commission and by the McCabe-Lafranchi special investigation. Without these kinds of investigations it seems plain that the activities described in those reports would never have been discovered by our existing law enforcement agencies.

The Costigan Royal Commission and the McCabe-Lafranchi special investigation demonstrate cogent reasons for the establishment of a national crimes commission . First, the activities reported on were exposed by specialised investigation. Second, those investigations have not been conducted by the police, although police are used as part of the investigative team set up under Mr Costigan, and nor were conventional police methods of investigation used. Third, the aptitudes , skills and techniques brought to bear in these investigations, particularly those outlined in Mr Costigan's edited chapter on strategies employed in his investigations, are not to be found in the police forces of Australia whose structure, manning and investigative techniques have yet to catch up with organised criminal techniques and activities. As Mr Costigan said:
The law enforcement agencies have not identified in any meaningful way the nature and extent of organised crime operating here.

Mr Costigan has pointed to three difficulties in the path of law enforcement agencies in the suppression of organised crime. They are: Inadequate personnel; inadequate equipment; and inadequate powers. Whilst, if the determination and the funds are available, defects in equipment and powers can be overcome it will take many years to remedy the deficiencies in personnel in Australian police forces even supposing that the police forces are ready for the fairly radical restructuring that this would require. Bluntly stated, our police forces are decades behind what we need to combat effectively organised crime. We cannot wait for them to catch up; the problem is too urgent-hence, in my view, the need for a national crimes commission.

To establish a national crimes commission does not mean that we should not at the same time seek to improve the standards of our existing law enforcement agencies. Its establishment simply recognises the deficiencies in those agencies and the urgency of the threat posed by organised crime. What then of the proposed model? The proposed Commission is open to the obvious criticism-this criticism has been made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) -that it would be better to have State co-operation. No doubt this is so, but the record of State and Federal co-operation inspires no confidence in the prospects of a speedy agreement on either the need for the Commission or the form it should take. We have not so many years left to us.

The Bill provides for State participation so that the States, if they wish, can participate. That is an option which is left open to them. Essentially, what the Bill proposes is a standing royal commission with a time limit of five years. Its brief is twofold: Firstly, the investigation of offences and the assembly of evidence for the prosecution of offenders engaged in organised and sophisticated criminal activities; and, secondly, the reporting on patterns of criminal activities-particularly organised criminal activities-and the making of recommendations for changes in the laws and administrative actions needed to combat those activities. To secure these aims the Commission is given four broad areas of power: The power to recruit highly specialised and competent staff; the power to apply directly for search warrants and to retain custody, for a reasonable period, of papers and things discovered in searches; the power to apply for an order for delivery to the Commission of the passport of a witness; and the power to conduct, in public or private, compulsory inquisitorial examinations. The power to recruit specialised personnel is, of course, essential. The success of the Commission will depend almost entirely on the quality of those who run it and those who staff it. The powers concerning searches and passports are certainly wide ranging but, in my view, necessary. In each case application must be made to a judge for an order. This should be sufficient to prevent abuse. The powers given to the Commission to conduct inquisitorial hearings seem to me to go too far.

Our system of criminal law is based on two premises: The presumption of innocence; and that it is for the Crown to prove its case and not for the accused to establish his innocence. Basic to the accusitorial system is the right of a person who is accused of a crime or who is questioned about a crime to remain silent. Our system is in strong contrast to the inquisitorial system of continental Europe. It reflects the public revulsion to what has been described by an American judge as 'the inquisitorial and manifestly unjust methods of interrogating accused persons, which has long obtained in the continental system'.

The two major departures from the principle that a person is not to be required to answer questions which may disclose criminal action by him or to present documents which may disclose criminal action by him are to be found in Acts setting up royal commissions and in the provisions of the companies Acts which control special investigations. These two forms of inquiries are in many respects similar in procedure. Both operate on an inquisitorial basis and both require, subject to some safeguards, answers to questions. But what is here proposed is a major breach of the right to remain silent. It is a major breach because the whole purpose of the Commission is to investigate criminal activities. The grave nature of what is proposed can be simply illustrated: While neither the police nor the courts can compel answers to be given concerning criminal activities this Commission, frequently perhaps at the request of the police, can do what neither the courts nor the police can do.

It is perfectly true that some protection is to be given to a person called before the Commission. In brief, before a person is required to incriminate himself there must be an undertaking given by the Attorney-General, binding on the Crown, that the answers will not be used against him in criminal proceedings save proceedings for the offence of seeking to mislead the Commission. This undertaking does not extend to things or documents and experience teaches one-Mr Costigan points this out-that in the case of organised and sophisticated criminal activities documents will often be a more profitable and more telling form of evidence than oral evidence. I therefore think that the protection which is to be afforded by the undertaking of the Attorney-General should extend to the production of documents or things. But to extend the protection given by the undertaking to documents and things does not end the danger presented by the adoption of an inquisitorial system. Anyone with experience in royal commissions or special investigations knows that if a witness, on compulsion, gives evidence that incriminates him and if one gets some slight understanding from him of what the tale is by compulsion through questions, despite the fact that the evidence cannot be used against him it will frequently happen that other means of proving the offence can be found. The protection that the undertaking is designed to give can therefore become illusory.

To permit the Crown indiscriminately to compel witnesses to incriminate themselves by the expedient of giving an undertaking not to use the compelled evidence would be to make a major breach in the citizen's right to remain silent . There would be nothing to prevent the Crown giving such an undertaking to every witness summoned before the Commission. As the whole purpose of the Commission is to concern itself with crime we could, inadvertently, be taking a major step towards the adoption of an inquisitorial system of criminal justice. In my view if we are to establish a commission with inquisitorial powers, and a life span of at least five years, the power to compel witnesses to produce documents or answer questions that may incriminate them should be limited to special and exceptional cases. The determination of what amounts to such a special and exceptional case should not be left to the Commission. The possibility of abuse, simply from an excess of zeal, is far too obvious. Instead , it should be placed in the hands of someone outside the Commission who is answerable for his actions.

I think the person who should make this decision should be the Attorney-General who should be required, when giving the undertaking, to certify that in his opinion there are special grounds that, in the public interest, require the answers given or documents or things produced by the witnesses and he should state what those grounds are. Not only would the Attorney-General be answerable to Parliament for any misuse of this power but also misuse of the power would be challengeable in the courts. Unquestionably, what I propose and what the amendments in my name set forth will slow down some of the Commission's work and perhaps make it less effective. But inquisitorial powers proposed by the Bill are far too radical a departure from our criminal system of justice. The restrictions I suggest on the use of these powers are necessary to maintain the substance of one of the most deeply rooted rights that citizens have-the right to remain silent.

There are three other areas of general comment on the Bill. I believe that the Government, if it agrees to amendments which will be put forward by me, which I understand it may do, will come some distance to meet the comments that I now make. In the first place many witnesses may prefer to give evidence in private. In my experience they are frequently more forthcoming in private. Their views should be included as a specific matter for consideration under section 16 (6) of the proposed Act. Furthermore, I can see no good reason why section 6D sub- section (2) of the Royal Commission Act which provides that witnesses before a royal commission whose evidence may unfairly prejudice the profits or financial interest of any person should not, in a proper case, have their evidence taken in private. Witnesses should not only be entitled to witness expenses which they receive under the Royal Commissions Act but not under this Bill-although I believe that the Government would accede to a proposal that that entitlement now be granted to them under the Bill-but also in a proper case they should be reimbursed their legal expenses. I say this simply because persons called before the kind of commission that is proposed, no matter how innocent they may be of wrong doing, are well advised to be legally represented. Since the purpose of the Commission is very much a public interest purpose it is right that those who assist it should do so at no cost to themselves.

Lastly, clause 37 provides for the furnishing of an annual report to Parliament . Clause 10 provides for reports on specific matters. In my view the protection given by those clauses concerning the naming of witnesses should be extended. It should be provided that the proposed commission shall take reasonable care to ensure that the identity of a person is not revealed if to reveal his identity might, when taken together with any material appearing in a report, prejudice the safety or reputation of the person or the fair trial of a person who has been or who may be charged with an offence. Trial by public reports, trial by the media and trial by the Parliament, so impossible to refute and so insidiously damaging, have no place in this country. If people are to be judged, let them be judged by the courts.

We can never hope to eradicate corporate crime or organised crime. We can hope to limit and to contain it. But we could only hope to limit and contain it if we were willing to take fresh approaches to the problems presented by organised crime. What the Bill proposes is a beginning. In my view, we must progress to a united national approach. I agree with much of what the honourable member for Hawker said on this subject. This means an end to the idiocies of jurisdictional complexities and jealousies and, finally, I should think, to a common criminal code as the honourable member proposed or, at least, to a common criminal code designed to deal with organised crime. But let me add one warning. Let us be slow to breach fundamental rights. It is perfectly true that criminals can make bad use of those rights. But it is true also that those rights have protected citizens for hundreds of years. We should be very careful before we throw them to one side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this debate thus far indicates that all honourable members have agreed that society has a duty to protect its institutions and its people against the attacks of organised crime. I think there has been some measure of agreement that there is a need to co-ordinate and organise the resources of State and Commonwealth law enforcement agencies and authorities to meet not merely the problems of organised crime but the new forms of crime which were listed by the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi). He has continuously, I think to his credit, pointed out in this House the development and the nature of the developments of corporate criminal activities within our society. Part of the problem which he highlighted correctly was that, for the most part, all State specialist police services which have the prime responsibility for the enforcement of law, whether they be in Victoria or New South Wales, are understaffed and underfinanced and the specialist officers who man them are largely underpaid. Caught in this situation, this Parliament is entitled, I believe, to ask itself the question: Has the Government done all that is possible to strengthen, co-ordinate and assist in the reframing and particularly in the refinancing of State government law enforcement agencies. I believe that, if one looked at what occurred with this Government, the answer to that very important question must be in the negative. I am bound to say that I, for one, am deeply concerned about the extent of the provisions and the width of the powers which are sought in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me refer the House to the functions of the proposed commission. We will create a commission which has powers to investigate, on its own motion or at the request of the Attorney-General, any circumstances suggesting that an offence may have been made or may be being committed against the law of the Commonwealth or, indeed, any allegation-it does not have to be a circumstance-that an offence has been or is being committed against a law of the Commonwealth or Territory can produce an active investigation by the Commission or at the behest of the Attorney-General. I believe those powers are too wide. I believe this House is in grave danger in giving to any Attorney-General or to any commission powers of such an extensive nature.

This legislation is an overreaction to some of the facts that I think have been properly brought to the attention of the people of Australia in the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Instead of endeavouring to co-ordinate and finance the law enforcement agencies whose job it is to prosecute the law and to investigate, we are creating an ongoing, permanent commission which, on its own motion or on the request of the Attorney-General, without reference to the Parliament, can commence an inquisitorial process into any section of our community. In the final analysis I believe that what separates a democratic society from a totalitarian society are those institutions which ultimately, when choosing between the rights of the state and the rights of the citizen, will opt for the rights of the citizen. I am opposed to the development of the inquisitorial process and I am opposed to the development of that process in the way which is contemplated in this legislation. I do not believe that any government or any Attorney-General should seek to have these powers and I do not believe the Parliament should readily concede these powers.

I have heard honourable gentlemen opposite cast grave reflections upon the Attorney-General of New South Wales. I have heard it suggested in this House that from time to time he has abused his office. If that can be said by way of political thrust in respect of a State Attorney-General why can it not be said in respect of a Commonwealth Attorney-General? These powers are wide enough to enable not necessarily this Attorney-General but some future Attorney-General to say: 'I believe that the tax avoidance industry poses a grave threat to the revenue collecting facilities of the Commonwealth'. There is lots of evidence to show that certainly what has occurred has involved breaches of the law. I have heard it said in this House by people who hold very responsible positions that many of the funds which came from taxation evasion finished in the coffers of the Liberal Party. I do not know whether that is true or false.

I suggest to the honourable gentlemen opposite that there is nothing to stop an Attorney-General who is so minded from saying on the basis of that allegation: ' We will have an investigation to see whether that allegation against the Liberal Party and its collective membership is true and we shall place the Liberal Party into the inquisitorial process'. Honourable members opposite, especially the Acting Attorney-General (Mr N.A. Brown), who is sitting at the table, might say in the Parliament that that is not what was intended. They might say: 'We did not intend that'. What do we mean when we talk about organised crime? This legislation, as drafted, is wide enough to include the Liberal Party. It is wide enough to include any of the fringe political groups in our community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even the Melbourne Club.
—It could, indeed, include the Melbourne Club.
—What about the City of Richmond? Did they get any allegations of political graft? Tell us about the City of Richmond. It would be an interesting study.

—Let me refer to the allegations in respect of the City of Richmond. I am delighted with the Acting Attorney-General's interjection. I am delighted with it and will write into the record the fact that I was one who had to stand up in this House on the basis of a completely false and slanderous allegation made as part of an inquisitorial process-
—By a perjurer-
—By a perjurer and a liar, a man who is now doing 12 years gaol-to deny that a bribe had been taken.
—That is not what Mr Nicholson said-

—It was referred to on page 3 of the Age but when, within a matter of days, the gentleman conducting the inquiry found that there was not one segment of truth in it, there was no page 3 lead in the Age on the subject. This Acting Attorney-General is perfectly happy-
—It must be a different report.

—I find his remarks interesting. He is proving out of his own mouth that he is not fit to be trusted with these powers. I go further and say that I do not trust any politician, any government, with them. Least of all do I trust this Acting Attorney-General because, by the nature of his own filthy allegations that he is perfectly happy to throw across at me-
—Order! The honourable member will confine his remarks to parliamentary language-

—This is the man who wants this Parliament cozily to comply with his request for the most wide-ranging powers, powers which affect the rights of every citizen and group in this community. He has shown by his interjection in respect of one inquisitorial process that took place that he could not even get the recommendations or findings correct.
—You obviously have not read the report.
—I have read it very well, I can tell the Acting Attorney-General.
—You must have a different report.

—No, I do not look at it through the same eyes as those of the Acting Attorney-General; that is the difference. That is precisely my point. The honourable gentleman cannot deny that the proposed powers are sufficiently wide to allow him or any Attorney-General to say: 'I suspect that a particular citizen has breached the laws of the Commonwealth. I suspect that this political party has breached the laws of the Commonwealth. I suspect this trade union. I suspect this company'. On the basis of that act, which does not have to be ratified by the Parliament, that company, that individual, that trade union, can be subjected to a process which, if it is reported in the media, can be tremendously damaging. It can destroy the innocent as well as pursue those who are involved in criminal activities. This Parliament has not merely a duty to strengthen agencies in the pursuit of those who are engaged in criminal activities. It has the much more profound duty of protecting the fundamental rights and liberties of the average Australian citizen. That is the point.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that this legislation represents anything more than an immediate, gross, over-reaction to some of the findings-I concede that they are findings about which all honourable members ought to be concerned-in the Costigan and McCabe-Lafranchi reports. One does not deny that for two minutes. but let me ask: Was it organised crime that was involved in this massive exercise in tax evasion?

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a combination of both.

—That is perfectly true but what is even more true is that, on the basis of the evidence that was available within the Attorney-General's Department, upon the basis of legal opinions by leading Queen's counsel recommending prosecution, this Government did nothing. Tax evasion became an acceptable social practice amongst the most wealthy sections of this community. It was fashionable. There was a time, if one went to parties of young lawyers and doctors, that they talked about their new cars. but in recent years they have been talking about the latest tax evasion scheme. They did not regard themselves as criminals or as part of organised crime. They believed that they were acting with the cosy complicity of this Government-'wink, wink, nod, nod; if you can get away with it and vote Liberal we will all be better off'!
—More exciting than sex.
—In the case of the Minister at the Table that would certainly be true.
—Especially if you live in Richmond.
—There were not too many people in Richmond involved in tax evasion. I doubt that the Acting Attorney-General can say that about some of his gentlemen friends.
—There would have been more cash taken than cheques.
—All this proves how dangerous this legislation is.
—Order! the honourable member for Prospect does not here have the call.
—Surely they are proving the point over and over again.
—Order! Honourable members will refrain from interjecting. The honourable member for Melbourne Ports has the right to address the House in silence.

—I had occasion tonight to look over again one of the great debates in this Parliament, the debate on the Communist Party Dissolution Bill. The basis of that legislation was an attempt to dissolve the Communist Party of Australia. All the arguments and all the presumptions that founded that legislation could be used tomorrow by the Acting Attorney-General to start a commission of inquiry into the Communist Party or any other political or religious group in our society that he believed he wanted to investigate. I do not say he would. But does this Parliament accept those presumptions as easily and as lightly as has been suggested simply on the basis that we are going to do something about organised crime?

SPEECH.PARA: I share, and I voice, the concern that has been expressed by such bodies as the Victorian Bar Council. I do not always agree with it and I do not expect all honourable members here to take the view that what the Victorian Bar Council puts forth has to be accepted as gospel. But no one could describe the Victorian Bar Council as a group of young political radicals. When an eminent body such as that, with such a wide range and diversity of political opinions, expresses itself in the way in which it already has and not merely cautions this House against this legislation but advises against it because of the dangers in it for the rights and liberties of the Australian citizen, I believe we must take cognisance of it. I would not seek these powers for a Labor government. I certainly would not concede these powers in their present form to this Government. I do not doubt the sincerity of honourable members opposite when they say that they are concerned to deal with organised crime. But if they believe that they are going to do it with some form of super inquisition which puts at peril the rights and liberties of Australian citizens, then that for me is too high a price to pay.

I believe this Parliament should think deeply. If it thinks deeply it will realise that the proper approach to this matter is to co-operate with the law enforcement agencies of the States and to be prepared to fund the kind of specialist services which are clearly needed. If there is to be some kind of commission of inquiry which is felt necessary by the States and the Commonwealth in respect of the pursuit of organised crime, I believe that can be done with a prudence and a caution which is not evident in this legislation. It has taken the Australian people, as it has taken the people of the British Commonwealth, a long time to develop the rights of the individual citizen. The protection of the courts, which ultimately is the only protection-whatever the inadequacies of our system-stands between the individual citizen and the power of the state. I do not believe those rights should be put in jeopardy. I do not believe the state should seek the kinds of powers which strengthen a process which by its very nature is abhorrent to the whole tradition of our legal system.

I would need to be convinced, in respect of any individual case, that the Parliament ought to act in a way which is now being contemplated. For that reason, I will not merely support the amendments moved by the Opposition but also I say very sincerely to the Minister and the Government, and to the voices of concern that have been expressed on that side of the House, that the best thing this Government could do would be to take this legislation away and think about it far more deeply than it has. Organised crime is not about to go on a gala festival between now and the new year. We need better legislation than this . We certainly need legislation which will not imperil the rights of the Australian citizen in the way in which this legislation does.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I see it, two major issues have emerged to this point in the debate on this legislation. Firstly, there is the question of the Commonwealth's relationship with the States of Australia and the way in which they are affected by this proposal and the extent of Commonwealth power. Secondly, there is the protection of individuals in relation to the nature of the inquiries that might be pursued by the proposed national crimes commission. I wish to address myself this evening, firstly, to the relationship that the Commonwealth has with the States of Australia and to indicate some of the reservations I have about the way in which the legislation is framed. I will make some suggestions to the Acting Attorney-General (Mr N.A. Brown) as to some alternative approaches that might be taken. However, I very much agree with the thrust of the legislation. The speeches of the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi), and the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), detailed the reasons why we have a requirement for a national crimes commission. The two honourable members spelt out the nature and extent of the problem which had been revealed by various inquiries and also the work of the Australian Institute of Criminology. I do not think it is necessary for me to go over those matters again. I would suggest to the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), who expressed some reservations about the proposal, that if he wants to see the reasons for this legislation he should read closely the speeches of the two honourable members whom I have mentioned.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Crimes Commission Bill has been framed so as to give to the Commonwealth certain limited powers to investigate breaches of law. The Bill is limited because the breaches of law are only breaches of Commonwealth laws that might be investigated by the proposed commission, unless the States specifically refer matters to the commission. Some might say that that is a co-operative approach, but I suggest to the Acting Attorney that if the States prove, as it appears to this point, to be unwilling to co-operate and unwilling to take this referral on board they ought to have regard to some of the recent case decisions which have said that the Commonwealth's power might very well be extended in a number of areas and in a number of ways. The States ought to have regard to the extent to which the Commonwealth might be able to legislate further than it has seen fit to do in this legislation.

I address the Acting Attorney-General's attention to some of the articles that have been written about an implied national power that the Commonwealth Government might have to legislate in important areas such as this. This power has been considered recently in what is known as the Australian Assistance Plan case. In that case the High Court was considering the validity of an appropriation by the Commonwealth to fund the Australian Assistance Plan which was an initiative of the previous Labor Administration. Under section 81 of the Constitution, which is the appropriation power, appropriations must be made for the purposes of the Commonwealth. None of the justices in that case took a narrow view of the appropriation power. They did not assume that the purposes of the Commonwealth was the narrow range of purposes that are outlined in section 51 and section 52 of the Constitution which are normally thought to constitute the Commonwealth's powers. The Court thought that the purposes were somewhat wider than that. I direct the attention of the Acting Attorney to some of the views of what might be described as the more conservative judges who address themselves to this matter in that case. Mr Justice Jacobs had some comments to make. I will quote briefly one of them. He said:
The growth of national identity results in a corresponding growth in the area of activities which have an Australian rather than a local flavour.
The then Chief Justice, Sir Garfield Barwick, said:
The extent of powers which are inherent in the fact of nationhood and of international personality has not been fully explored.

I think that would be regarded as a particularly cautious statement by that gentleman; yet it indicates that we really have not traversed the extent of our nationhood power. That is a matter that might be addressed. I also suggest that the Acting Attorney look at the comments of Mr Justice Mason. He said:

the existence and character of the Commonwealth as a national government in combination with the incidental power . . . and the executive power . . . gave the Commonwealth a capacity to engage in activities which could only be effectively carried out by a national government.

Some people have thought that that runs only to the more obvious examples such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and some research and exploratory organisations. But I think there are wider national interests involved in this issue which might all be addressed in legislation such as the National Crimes Commission Bill. I think there would be few who would deny that this is a very important area, an area where national interests are affected and where if we look at the nature of crime not only national but also international the Commonwealth has a great responsibility. The fact that this legislation is called legislation for a National Crimes Commission highlights that.

I also suggest that the Acting Attorney look at the trade and commerce power. There have been some suggestions that under the trade and commerce power, raised under section 45D of the Trade Practices Act in the Actors Equity case, the Commonwealth has a power not only to regulate but also to protect. I would think that the sort of protection that we would want from criminal activity might be such that our trade and commerce power would enable the Commonwealth to regulate a much wider variety of interstate criminal activity or quasi-criminal activites . That is a matter that might be looked at. There is also the important Koowarta case involving the Queensland Government and the extent of the Commonwealth's power in relation to the question of our Racial Discrimination Act.

Whilst time does not permit me to canvass many details of that matter, there are some international conventions which deal with drug trafficking which Australia has signed and which might well provide a proper base for Commonwealth laws dealing with drug trafficking and the like. The Commonwealth could enact laws and these matters could be investigated by a National Crimes Commission under the powers given in this legislation. I would like to cover many more matters, particularly in relation to the question of powers. However, I would encourage the Acting Attorney to look at these matters and to raise them with the States. They might very well become a proper basis on which the States would realise that if they are not prepared to co-operate the Commonwealth might be able to go it alone.
I will address the second matter, the protection of individual rights, on another occasion. I therefore seek leave to continue my remarks at a later time.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Child Welfare-Pensions-Poland-Australian Postal Commission: Post Office Box Facilities-Aboriginal Health-Adult Migrant Education Service-Death of Mr Rudy Komon-Newspaper Article

PROCTEXT.PARA: Child Welfare-Pensions-Poland-Australian Postal Commission: Post Office Box Facilities-Aboriginal Health-Adult Migrant Education Service-Death of Mr Rudy Komon-Newspaper Article
Motion (by Mr N.A. Brown) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of weeks ago I met in King's Hall a Mr Michael Shelley and his wife Katherine, who asked me to read the rather voluminous papers which set out their grievance. The couple are Nazarite Christians. They were barefooted, informally dressed but obviously scrupulously clean. Their principal grievance was that child welfare authorities in Queensland had taken their son Elijah from them and delivered him to a foster parent. I have since examined their papers and while it is not an easy case and involved conflict of two valid principles-the duty of society to see that children are adequately cared for versus the rights of parents-I believe the wrong decision was made in this case.

SPEECH.PARA: Michael and Katherine Shelley are Nazarite Christians and their understanding of christianity is that they must adopt a particular lifestyle, which is in conflict at several points with the normal way of life of our society. To take some examples, the Shelley's beliefs commit them to living from day to day; eating only simple and natural food; wearing clothing only of natural fibres and going shoeless; not cutting their hair or shaving, and not even binding up their hair; not using household appliances, including washing machines and refrigerators, nevertheless keeping scrupulously clean, which includes daily hand washing of clothing; not using drugs and alcohol; refusing medical attention in times of illness and instead employing prayer and anointing of the sick person; and constant travelling, as they say, 'nearly every day in faith for our Lord Jesus Christ'.

In the view of most people, these principles are eccentric if not bizarre. However, most people would not deny the Shelleys the right to seek to live out the dictates of their conscience. Despite our community's professed commitment to freedom of conscience, on various occasions the Shelleys have been gaoled on vagrancy charges. Inevitably during their travels the Shelleys have attracted the attention of the conscientious child welfare authorities of South Australia, New South Wales and Queensland concerning the well-being of Elijah. According to Mr Shelley the authorities in New South Wales and South Australia, after their investigations, saw no need for further action. Mr Shelley has also supplied me with a copy of a document from the Queensland Department of Children's Services at Rockhampton, dated 22 April 1981, which states that as a result of the examination of Elijah by several paediatric experts it had been agreed that:

. . . while Mr and Mrs Shelley lead an unconventional transient lifestyle, there is no doubt that Elijah receives the highest level of emotional care and love. Elijah's vegetarian diet is quite unusual for a child his age, but medical advice is that the diet is well balanced and appears to be adequate.

However, the same expert and conscientious opinion was that in the interests of the child there should be regular monitoring of Elijah's state of health and therefore his parents were requested to seek medical examination of their son at three-monthly intervals for the next six months from the local paediatrician in whatever town they might be in. On that occasion the Shelleys agreed to meet this request but Mr Shelley has since stated that he has withdrawn his assent, and this has had very serious consequences. The Queensland authorities saw fit to remove Elijah from his parents' custody and now Mr Shelley is most dissatisfied with and very concerned about the care that Elijah has received at the hands of both the Queensland authorities and his foster parent.

It does seem that no serious attempt has been made to take account of the parents' conscientious values and religious susceptibilities by those who have taken upon themselves the raising of Elijah Shelley. It does not seem that either the Queensland authorities or the Queensland State Ombudsman have come up with any less harsh solution to this problem. There are grounds for believing that the rights of the Shelley family have not received their due from the authorities. Surely some less arbitrary, less brutal, procedures can be applied in this admittedly difficult case. Surely the only recourse open to the authorities is not the traumatic breakup of a loving family.
