Surely further attempts at a compromise can and should be made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a number of occasions in this House I have found it necessary to draw attention to the meanness and what virtually amounts to criminal negligence in relation to pensioners caused by the policies of the Federal Government. Tonight I wish to draw attention to the circumstances of Mrs Brigitte Wustemann of 37 King Street, Bayswater, Victoria, which illustrate so clearly the plight of pensioners under the social security system administered by this Government. Mrs Wustemann is a 42-year-old widow with a 17-year-old son and a 15-year-old daughter. She is presently receiving a widow's pension with all the attendant fringe benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: The two children have left school and are at present seeking work. One of the failures of the present school system in Victoria-which the State Australian Labor Party Government hopes to remedy-is the inability of the system to provide invigorating educational programs which will attract young people at a time when their learning capacity is at its height. Nonetheless, the two children have made the decision to leave school and take their chances in the job market. The problem for Mrs Wustemann is that as soon as her daughter reaches the age of 16 years, in a few months' time, Mrs Wustemann will lose her entitlement to her widow's pension and the associated fringe benefits, including rate rebates and discounts on telephone rental and public transport. At age 42 years with work experience related to 18 years ago Mrs Wustemann is now forced to seek work. In such circumstances her job opportunities are minimal to say the least and it is almost certain that she will be obliged to apply for unemployment benefits. At her age and with no recent work experience she will be expected to look for work in a job market where more than half a million people are unemployed.

It should also be appreciated that there is another class of person similarly affected, that is, the single parent pensioner. Apart from the high unemployment levels for the working population in general unemployment is particularly high for women. The official figures for July indicate unemployment rates of 20.7 per cent for 15 to 19-year-old young women and 17.9 per cent for all women. These rates are much higher than the general unemployment level for men which is 5.8 per cent and 15.6 per cent for the 15 to 19-year-olds. Many women such as Mrs Wustemann will find it impossible to enter the work force having devoted their lives to their families and having lost or not having had the opportunity to obtain the relevant skills which are necessary. At age 40 years or more their retirement age is only 10 years or less away. For this reason alone many employers are unwilling to offer a job to women in these circumstances.

A community group, Women in Search, has published studies indicating that women in the 40 to 50 years age group who lose the widow's pension suffer considerable emotional anguish at being unable to obtain employment and experience feelings of hopelessness and insecurity in relation to their future. As a result these women are increasingly falling prey to ill health. Those who do not succumb to illness, having lost the widow's pension and being unable to obtain work, must seek the unemployment benefit with the associated loss of fringe benefits. It seems that the Government continually fails to appreciate the considerable financial drain resulting from the loss of fringe benefits. This figure can be quantified as being a minimum of $20 a week with many people losing as much as $ 30 a week or more.

Where the widow or single parent is attempting to meet housing repayments the financial consequences are even more disastrous. Women in Search suggests that the age eligibility for the widow's pension should be reduced from 50 years to 40 years. This reduction in the age eligibility would give the women concerned the security of a pension card with all the attendant fringe benefits. It should not be forgotten that retraining schemes are also necessary for unskilled women who wish to enter or re-enter the work force.

It is high time that the Federal Government indicated more compassion for widows and suporting parents who find themselves faced with the future financial prospects which Mrs Wustermann will experience in several months time. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) should accept that the Government has a responsibility to assist widows in need by making the age qualifications for the widows pension more realistic by recognising the special problems of people such as Mrs Wustermann. Of course, it can be argued that there are many other disadvantaged groups which also deserve support, but my intention tonight has been to draw attention to one group which is often overlooked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to express my concern at the decision of the Polish martial law authorities last month to abolish the free trade union movement Solidarity. I want to join with other members of parliament who have expressed their dismay at the way in which the Polish Government has again displayed its brutal and repressive arrogance by totally ignoring the expressed wishes of the Polish people. The free world has supported this almost unique and certainly courageous attempt by the Poles to establish for themselves a more just and more democratic society through this free and independent union.

SPEECH.PARA: The Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Sinclair) said on 9 October that the Australian Government believed this step was likely to hinder the process of national conciliation so desperately needed in Poland today. I think that this sentiment has been best expressed by Magda Wojeck, a key member of the Solidarity Co-ordinating Office Abroad located in Brussels. In a letter to the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman), who has been a strong supporter of the Solidarity movement, she said, in response to the abolition of Solidarity:
Although the Union does not exist on paper it exists in the minds of the people in Poland and the work they do-you can formally delegalise a union but you cannot delegalise 10 million people.

I want to add my support to the people of Poland in their struggle. In particular, I want to reiterate my support for the Polish community of Perth which, naturally, is most distressed with the current situation in Poland and with the martial law authorities. The Polish community of Perth, during the course of this year, has expressed its solidarity with Solidarity in a most tangible way. As Chairman of the Western Australian State Committee for Relief to Poland, I want to thank the Polish community of Western Australia for their most generous and energetic contribution to this appeal, which concludes this Friday. The great bulk of the funds raised has been raised by the Polish community of Western Australia, which has worked tirelessly to ensure that through its efforts and through this appeal it can help to provide food, clothing and medical supplies to the people of Poland who need the physical sustenance and the moral support for their struggle which these funds, raised voluntarily throughout the Western World, will help provide.
Recently, on 17 October, the Polish community, at yet another fund raising function for this appeal, passed a resolution addressed to the Prime Minister of Australia in the following terms:

We urge you, Sir, to commit, on the international arena, the good name and prestige of the Australian Government, to the unequivocal condemnation of the regime governing Poland for the most flagrant violation of human rights. For the use of force, suppression and detentions perpetrated on its own people. For reducing the economy to the state of ruin and for submitting, openly and shamelessly to the wishes and dictates of an unfriendly neighbouring power.
We also urge you, Sir, to instigate and give support to any prudent but resolute policies intended to bring relief to the Polish Nation which has suffered too much for too long.

At a public meeting on 23 October-there was also a public march through Perth, organised by the Federated Clerks Union and the Polish community in which I took part-another resolution was passed. The resolution read:

This meeting deplores the dissolution of Solidarity by the repressive Polish authorities and calls upon the Federal Government to advise the Polish Ambassador of our concern at the dissolution, to press for a guarantee that no citizen will be penalised in any way for being a member or supporter of Solidarity, and to seek an assurance that all members or supporters of Solidarity who are either imprisoned or interned will be immediately released with the restoration of all citizen rights.

On 27 October I presented both these resolutions to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). I congratulate the Polish community of Western Australia and other members of the Western Australian community on the support that they have given to the Solidarity movement, particularly through the appeal of the Western Australian State Committee for Relief to Poland, and I call on the Federal Government to take action to ensure that the Polish authorities are made aware of the concern which we as a government and as a people feel regarding the callous disregard that they have shown towards the fundamental rights of their own people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several weeks ago a constituent of mine approached me about a postal matter. She was wishing to establish a business and required a private post office box. She was expecting to receive approximately 50 letters or documents each day through the post. She lives in Five Dock, which is part of the electorate of Lowe, and she went to the Five Dock Post Office and found that no post office boxes were available. She went to the Drummoyne Post Office and found there was none there. She went to Gladesville across the Parramatta River and none was available there. She went to small post offices. She found that many of them, particularly the sub-post offices had no post office box facilities at all. She went in towards the city to Pyrmont and there was none there. Eventually she found an out of the way post office in the city where she could obtain a post office box. This was no good to the lady at all. I was quite surprised to hear of this. I have written to the Minister for Communications (Mr N.A. Brown) about the issue. The constituent wanted to start a business and provide some employment but she just could not get off the ground in the local area.

SPEECH.PARA: I and my secretary rang local post offices all around the electorate of Lowe and stretching into some of the other electorates, where a business person might go to try to get a post office box. It is quite a reasonable assumption that one can obtain these facilities. At Burwood, in the heart of my electorate, no post office boxes are available and there is a waiting list of several years. The post office building is a National Trust classified building and no work can be done to extend the facilities. No post office boxes are available at Burwood North and there is a waiting list. At Concord none was available and we were referred to another post office. At Croydon there was none available. We were told that the post office was also a National Trust building and there were no facilities and no room to expand. At Hunter's Hill, which is quite close to my electorate, there was none available. At Ryde, just out of the electorate, where my secretary lives, no post office boxes were available. There were and still are post office boxes at Strathfield, which is a new post office, but it is an impossibility to park near it. It is on a very busy intersection and business people or local charities do not want to take a post office box that they cannot get at easily day or night, because it is right on a very busy intersection. We were told that some small post office boxes were available at Enfield and there were also small boxes at Strathfield. But Enfield is on the Hume Highway, the main thoroughfare between Sydney and Melbourne, and people just cannot park in such places.

I was most concerned about this lady's complaint because I believe we must, as members of parliament, do everything possible to encourage business activity to help small business people get off the ground. I have looked at the Postal Services Act which states that the Australian Postal Commission:
. . . shall perform its functions in such a manner as will best meet the social , industrial and commercial needs of the Australian people for postal services . . .

I submit to the House tonight that the Australian Postal Commission is not exercising its duties in a manner that will best meet the social, industrial and commercial needs of the Australian people. I notice in the Act that the Minister may give directions to the Commission. I am drawing this to the attention of the House tonight in the hope that the Minister will bring this problem to the attention of the Commission because I think it is a reasonable expectation that a person opening a business is able to obtain a post office box. I believe the boxes save money for Australia Post. They provide a community service to local business people and to charities and in addition they raise revenue. I feel it is time that the Postal Commission looked at this matter seriously and looked at the whole question of providing these facilities for the business community and for the charities and local organisations which need these services. I am sure that any honourable member in the House will find in his own area, particularly in the older, established suburbs, that these facilities are just not available and there is no plan by the Australian Postal Commission to provide them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Mr G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the Australian Medical Association published a booklet, I presume primarily for its members, entitled ' Aboriginal Health and Lifestyle-a Health, Education and Promotion Monograph'.
—A very good book.

—I think it is an excellent book. It will serve a great educative role in our community, particularly for general practitioners, many of whom need to be further educated and alerted to the peculiar problems of Aboriginal health . I know that this has been an issue that many members of this House and of State parliaments have studied closely over the last few years and have put a lot of time and attention into. I am aware the the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs addressed the problem several years ago in an inquiry directed towards Aboriginal health. Similarly, the same Standing Committee tabled a report in this place on Thursday, 28 October with regard to Aboriginal fringe camps. That report which reflected on the problems in town camps highlighted many of the problems related to Aboriginal health. I did not agree with all of the recommendations in that report. In fact, I was a signatory to a dissent in that report on some of the issues relating to Aboriginal health. But it is good to see that these issues are being addressed, particularly by groups such as the Australian Medical Association.

SPEECH.PARA: I also draw the attention of members, the public and doctors to many of the statements that were made yesterday at the launching of that booklet by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Wilson) who naturally praised the publication of the booklet. He drew attention to many of the problems and highlighted a number of issues. But what impressed me particularly, probably in light of the dissent that I lodged with regard to the town camps inquiry, was the political point that a Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has addressed with regard to the differing responsibilities between the Commonwealth Government and State and territory governments in the fields of functional responsibilities such as health, education and welfare.

In fact, the Minister's report should be commended to the media and to all interested people because it shows a fresh view by a Minister at the direction that this Government is obviously looking as far as financial relationships between the various governments are concerned. I think the Minister in his address yesterday set out to define the respective roles and responsibilities. He pointed out quite clearly that it is incumbent on State governments to take up and provide services for Aboriginals at the same standard and at the same level. The Minister stated quite clearly that the primary objective of the Commonwealth was to accelerate the work done by the States and in particular to look at what can be termed the areas of double disadvantage or the severe disadvantage which results to people caused by their peculiar aboriginality.

I commend the Minister's statement in full to many people who should look at it and at the concurrent responsibilities between the various levels of government not just in the health area but in all areas in which there are State responsibilities. It is quite refreshing to see that a Minister has picked up and not just blindly walked into what everybody has been quoting as to what the 1967 referendum did. He defined and put down in a new way quite clearly that there is a concurrent responsibility between all levels of government and in particular groups such as medical associations and others who intend to try to assist in these important areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very concerned tonight at the lack of services provided by the Adult Migrant Education Service. I think this Government is exposed in regard to its lack of commitment to migrants who are very disadvantaged by their lack of knowledge of the English language. The adoption of the report of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs shows a drop in funds to the AMES on-arrival program of $2.7m and an overall reduction in funding for the adult migrant education services in real terms of $1.3m compared with the level for the last financial year. But the real failure of this Government lies in the fact that it has not recognised the needs of migrants in Australia and the damage planned to the courses already provided. For example, the teacher-student ratio this year will be worsened by 33 per cent from 1:15 to 1:20. Whilst theoretically all migrants now have access to full time courses of 300 hours, in future such courses will be available to only 20 per cent of those in need and the course length will be reduced to 240 hours. Others though will have to be content with part time courses over 10 to 12 weeks comprising only 150 to 180 hours instruction. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs ( Mr Hodges) is well aware that educational studies indicate that at least 900 hours is the optimum course length.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from this reduction for future immigrants to Australia, 525,000 migrants already in Australia are in real need of tuition in the English language. A command of the English language is essential for migrant workers who are seeking employment during periods of record unemployment and job shedding in the manufacturing industry.

This Government has failed to discharge its responsibilities in this area. It still refuses to provide the States with adequate funds to establish a permanent education service for migrants. Despite projections of future migrant intakes and the existing need of over half a million Australians the Government refuses to provide the extra meagre $4m or $5m necessary for the establishment of a permanent AMES. Instead the program all around Australia is staffed almost totally by casual teachers, many of whom work full time but are employed on an hourly casual basis. According to a New South Wales Industrial Commission statement of 18 August last, these people are subsidising the AMES. For example, approximately 60 per cent of the instruction time in New South Wales is taught by casual teachers.

The Federal Government should immediately take the first step towards a permanent education service by providing funds to convert all full time positions to permanent ones. For example, I think the current position in New South Wales is that there are only 130 permanent positions and 50 of those are administrative, which means that there are only 80 permanent teachers in the service and 200 casual teachers. In my electorate of Cunningham, which has the highest percentage of local population born overseas, there are only four permanent teachers and 80 casuals. This is a disgrace. The New South Wales Ethnic Communities Council and the New South Wales Ethnic Affairs Commission both believe that full time teachers should be permanent and not casual. They know that this would provide a stable education service and show a true commitment by the Government to the migrants that it encourages to come to Australia. We call on this Government to provide an immediate and extra grant to the States to upgrade the AMES as a matter of urgency and to increase the rate of permanency in the adult migrant education service in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I draw to the attention of the House the magnificent contribution of a man who came to Australia 32 years ago as a very poor man and took his first job as a chauffeur. When he died on 27 October he left a mark that I am certain will ensure his place in our history. I speak of Mr Rudy Komon.
—He was a great man.
—Hear, hear!

—I am glad to hear that support from both honourable members. I knew Rudy Komon very well indeed. I was happy and lucky enough to have him as a friend. We shared a very pleasant duty as directors of the Rothbury Estate winery. He was one of the people who were instrumental in starting it. In fact, he was instrumental in many of the developments in Australia that led it hopefully towards excellence. His whole life was dedicated towards excellence. He made such an impact on the art world in Australia that the full extent of it probably would be able to be assessed only by those artists who benefited so incredibly from his activities.
—But it should be written.

—I hope that one day it will. It should be written, certainly. For example, he had impact on Sir William Dobell, whose paintings Rudy Komon first marketed, if you like, from the back of a truck in eastern suburbs of Sydney- door by door. He was a friend, supporter, mentor and guide to so many artists that the list of those he helped is like a who's who of Australian art.
—Fred Williams.

—Fred Williams, indeed. Not only did Rudy assist Fred Williams by discovering him, promoting him and supporting him but also, much to the late Fred Williams's delight, he introduced him to high quality wine, of which Rudy Komon was immensely fond. In fact, Komon managed to convince quite a few of his artist friends, many of whom he friendly regarded as barbarians, about the delights of drinking wine. In fact, he was very proud of the claim that he had convinced even Ian Fairweather that he should switch from whisky to wine. As I understand it, Len French and Fred Williams ended up with quite good cellars.

SPEECH.PARA: The incredible thing about Rudy Komon was that all this interest in what some people could well regard as the activities of a rich group, an upper class, a select collection of elitists, was his natural delight. He came here, as I said, a poor migrant from Czechoslovakia. He died a man renowned and loved by many people whom he had enthusiastically called barbarians during his life.

TALK.START.PARA: —He broke the story of Masaryk's murder.

—I was unaware of that. I must say that I was glad to have been called a barbarian by Rudy. That he regarded me sufficiently as a friend to call me a barbarian cheered me immensely. I know of no other person who has on his own contributed so much to the development of so many artists in their pursuit of excellence as has Rudy Komon. He, appropriately enough, was the subject of a painting which caused some controversy in the awarding of the latest Archibald Prize. He was, of course, a man who enjoyed controversy. In his 32 years in Australia the contribution that he made was enormous. We will all miss him. Only a fortnight before he died I drove him home from the opening of the Australian National Gallery when he commented on the magnificence of the Australian collection there. If any man would know whether that collection was magnificent it should be Komon, who contributed so much to the development of excellence in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Sunday, 24 October, the Sunday Telegraph carried an article headed 'School Head in Centre of Racist Uproar'. That article dealt with alleged statements made by the principal of the King's School at the school 's speech day. That matter was picked up in a speech concerning the estimates for the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs by my colleague the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay). The honourable member said:

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the report in the Sydney Sunday Telegraph which related to statements that are alleged to have been made by Canon Stanley Kurrle, the headmaster of the King's School at Parramatta. It was suggested in the Sunday Telegraph that Canon Kurrle made a number of assertions about migrants not being brought to Australia in a time of recession. Indeed, it is suggested in that article that he said that there should be assistance to repatriate those people.
I find it disturbing that a person who purports to be a Christian would make those types of remarks. I think that, if Canon Kurrle did make those remarks, he should look into his own heart.
Later in his address he went on and said:
I think that all of us as Australians should put aside these incredible racist approaches that are starting to surface in our community at present.
He further added:
I think the types of remarks that have been attributed to Canon Kurrle are repulsive, . . .
I took a point of order which was not upheld by you, I suspect, Mr Deputy Speaker. I stated:

I ask whether honourable members have to vouch for the accuracy of articles from which they quote. I was at that function at Kings School and I do not recall remarks of the sort that were mentioned in that newspaper article. I would like to know whether the honourable member has checked the accuracy of the article.

The question was clearly raised in my mind because I was at the function and I did not recall any remarks of that sort being made. On 25 October, the day before this matter was raised in the House, the Principal of The King's School wrote to me. He had this to say:

I imagine that you will be aproached over remarks I was supposed to have made at the Speech Day you attended. In case you require the information, I enclose a copy of the Sunday Telegraph's report, a transcript of what I actually said, and a copy of the printed report. Towards the end of this there is a reference to the need for national unity. I doubt whether anything in that paragraph would give grounds for the report in the Sunday Telegraph.
Last weekend the Sunday Telegraph carried a retraction of its report. It stated:
APOLOGY TO REV. CANON S.W. KURRLE

In the edition of The Sunday Telegraph of October 24, an article was published headed ''School head in centre of 'racist' uproar.'' That article attributed to Canon S.W. Kurrle, the headmaster of The King's School, Parramatta, statements at the school's speech day which were not made.

Canon Kurrle has informed us that what he wished to suggest was that, in the light of the severe economic difficulties which confront the Australian economy today, and in particular in the light of the severe unemployment facing young people, it was desirable that newcomers should become Australians as quickly as possible, so that Australia could attain the unity necessary to overcome its problem as a nation.

I have a copy of the relevant tape containing the remarks that Canon Kurrle made on Australia's multicultural policy. He related those remarks particularly to the question of unemployment which was a matter of concern and which was raised in his address at the school. I have looked through the transcript of the tape. No reference is made to migrants being sent back from where they came. As I have mentioned, there was a questioning of the policy of multiculturalism. I did not agree with the way in which the Principal expressed them but I do not think it could be suggested in any way that his remarks were racist. For the benefit of honourable members I would like to table the extract from the tape of the Principal's speech as well as the formal printed address that he gave on Saturday, 16 October. I have sought the permission of honourable members opposite to table the tape extract and the address.
Leave granted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 11.39 p.m.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Independent Audit: Department of Industry and Commerce

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What independent audit is required by the Minister's Department to ensure the proper expenditure of funds granted to non-government organisations by the Minister or the Minister's Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: As advised in answer to Question No. 4800 (Hansard, 14 October 1982, page 2148- 9), the non-government organisations to which grants are made by the Department of Industry and Commerce are Advance Australia, the Customs Cooperation Council and the World Tourist Organisation.

Grants made to Advance Australia, a non-profit public interest company, are for the conduct of the 'Advance Australia' campaign, the principal objectives of which are set out in the company's memorandum of association. Advance Australia is subject to the Companies Act 1982 which requires, inter alia, that its accounts be subject to independent audit. Price Waterhouse, Chartered Accountants, are the present auditors.
My Department contributes to the operating costs of the Customs Cooperation Council and the World Tourism Organisation, to both of which Australia is an active member.
In respect of the Customs Cooperation Council, an annual audit is carried out by two auditors who are officers of the Customs administrations of two member countries of the organisation.

In the case of the World Tourism Organisation, the accounts are examined by two auditors elected by the General Assembly, on the recommendation of the Council, for a period of two years. Auditors are eligible for re-election. The auditors, in addition to examining the accounts, may make such observations as they deem necessary with respect to the efficiency of the financial procedures and management, the accounting system, the internal financial controls and, in general, the financial consequences of administrative practices.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Independent Audit: Department of Home Affairs and Environment

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What independent audit is required by the Minister's Department to ensure the proper expenditure of funds granted to non-government organisations by the Minister or the Minister's Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Home Affairs and Environment applies Finance Direction 13/13 and its associated guidelines in ensuring that Commonwealth grant funds are adequately protected. This Direction requires acquittances by means of supporting receipts or an audit certificate observing the following rules:

the certificate must be given by an independent auditor (to be taken as a third party) who is a qualified public accountant and who is not a member, employee or public officer of the grantee organisation. The purpose of the independent audit is to provide the Department with an unbiased assurance that the grant funds were expended in accordance with the terms and conditions of the grant.
non-government organisations would exclude all bodies constituted by Federal, State and Local Governments acting in an executive (as opposed to legislative) capacity.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Construction, upon notice, on 9 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What stage has been reached in negotiations on the proposed replacement for the Empress of Australia on the sea passenger service between Tasmania and the mainland.
(2) What consideration has been given to using the Australian National Line's ' Trader Class' vessels in carrying passengers as well as freight to provide a replacement passenger service.
(3) What are the economics of using the 'Trader Class' vessels as a possible passenger/freight service to replace the Empress of Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 19 October I advised the House that I had received five 'Statements of Interest' for a replacement for the Empress of Australia from the Australian National Line, Brambles Industries Ltd, Celsiunator Pty Ltd, Tasmanian Shipping Services and TNT Bulkships.
I have made copies of the five statements available to the Tasmanian and Victorian Governments, so that the Commonwealth can consider them in consultation with representatives of these Governments.
I expect that the outcome of these arrangements will allow the prospective operators to decide by early 1983, whether or not to proceed with their proposals.

(2) and (3) As the 'Trader' vessels could provide a maximum of 6 berths for male passengers only on each voyage, it would not be practicable to consider these vessels as a replacement for the Empress of Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 14 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many deportation orders were issued during 1981-82.
(2) How many deportations in 1981-82 were undertaken for (a) illegal entry, (b) overstay of visitor's visa, (c) criminal activity and (d) working without a permit.

(3) Is the Commonwealth responsible for the costs associated with these deportations; if so, what attempts are made to recover these costs; if not, what was the cost to the Commonwealth of these deportations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (b) 305 persons were deported as a consequence of contravention of the conditions of their temporary entry and stay-these included overstayed visitors but separate statistics for that category are not maintained.
(d) Nil (working without authority is not one of the grounds specified in the Migration Act for making a Deportation Order).
(3) Section 21A of the Migration Act 1958 provides that:
where the Commonwealth makes arrangements for the conveyance of a deportee from Australia, the deportee is liable to pay the Commonwealth an amount equal to the passage money and other charges;

a deportee is liable to pay the Commonwealth in respect of the cost of keeping and maintaining him while in custody, a daily maintenance rate determined by the Minister and published in the Gazette; and
an amount payable to the Commonwealth under these provisions as a debt due to the Commonwealth may be recovered in a Court.

The Department seeks to obtain payment voluntarily before departure ( instituting legal proceedings would delay departure and increase costs overall). Where a deportee has an airline ticket, that ticket is applied toward the departure. The Department records debts and letters are sent to each deportee advising them of their obligations and requesting payment. If this proves to be unsuccessful further letters are sent requesting payment by instalments if necessary.

The total expenditure from the detection, custody and deportation vote during 1981-82 was $1,266,646. This figure included the cost of maintenance in custody and the removal of deportees, however, without examining all individual files, it is not feasible to say how much of that expenditure was recoverable by the Commonwealth.

The amount recovered during 1981-82 was $30,895. I should point out that the amounts not recovered included the cost of maintaining custody of the 146 people who attempted illegal immigration from the vessel VT838 and also includes the custody of other groups who were eventually expelled from Australia after rejection of claims of refugee status. These were unusual costs not normally encountered.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 16 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article in the Age of 21 August 1982 regarding the future prospects for Australian sugar exports.

(2) Is it a fact as stated in the article that Australia (a) relies heavily on the international sugar trade, (b) relies heavily on continuing problems in Soviet sugar beet production and (c) is facing increasing competition from the European Economic Community which continues to boost its sugar exports.
(3) What steps has he taken to investigate alternative markets for Australian sugar.

(4) Has the Government considered investing funds in sugar-alcohol programs as a possibility for replacing oil imports and as a suitable alternative market for Australian sugar growers; if so, what financial commitment has been made; if not , why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) (a) Australia relies heavily on the international sugar trade. In 1981 about 85 per cent of Australia's production of sugar was exported. In 1981/82 Australia exported 2.5 million tonnes of sugar worth about $764m.

(b) The continuing problems in Soviet sugar production are of indirect benefit to Australia as the USSR usually sources most of its imported sugar from Cuba under a special arrangement, with the European Economic Community (EEC) being the next major supplier. In the past the USSR has not been a major market for Australian sugar; a shipment in 1981 of around 20,000 tonnes was the first sale of Australian sugar to the USSR since 1975. The main benefit to Australia is that because of its recent domestic shortages the USSR has absorbed some of the large surpluses of sugar produced by the EEC. Soviet imports of sugar from the EEC have grown from nothing in 1975 to 873,107 tonnes in 1981. Without this additional demand the world price may have been even lower than the present depressed level of US 6 cents per pound. However the effect of USSR domestic production shortages on the world market as a whole has been limited, as in recent years EEC exports have grown dramatically from 701,766 tonnes in 1975 to 5,343,752 tonnes in 1981.

(c) The Commonwealth Government has made strenuous representations to the EEC over the adverse effects that the Community's exports have had on the trade of efficient agricultural producers such as Australia. On sugar in particular Australia has made continuous efforts within the GATT to have the EEC accept disciplines on the subsidised export of its surplus sugar production. Through the irresponsible use of excessive price supports and export subsidies, the EEC has changed its position from that of a net sugar importer in 1976 to that of a major net exporter of sugar in 1981. At a time when the world's sugar trade is characterised by declining consumption, increasing protectionism in major markets and increasing competition from sugar substitutes, the effect of additional competition from subsidised EEC exports has been to depress the returns of efficient producers such as Australia.

(3) The Commonwealth Government prefers to leave commodity marketing primarily to the private sector. On the question of new markets, however, the Commonwealth Government provides assistance to Australian exporters through the Trade Commissioner Service and the benefits available under the Export Markets Development Grants Scheme.

(4) I understand that fuel ethanol production using sugar cane as a feed stock is uneconomic at current world oil prices. While the Commonwealth Government understands the problems faced by the Australian sugar industry due to low world sugar prices, the Commonwealth Government does not consider that these problems will be solved by providing financial assistance to encourage ethanol production as an alternative use of Australian sugar cane.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the award given to CPOWTR I. R. MILLARD for his cost saving suggestion which would result in potential savings of $3m per year; if so, will he provide an outline of this proposal.
(2) Has the proposal been implemented; if not, what is the timetable for its implementation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The suggestion is that service families be given the option to hire furniture for use in a service married quarter or rented home, whilst waiting for their own furniture to be delivered rather than remaining in temporary motel accommodation. The potential savings suggested of $3m per year is regarded as being highly optimistic and assumes, inter alia, a very high percentage of members would exercise this option, and the availability of hiring services outside of capital cities and during periods of peak movement.

(2) No. This suggestion is but one of many measures that are under investigation to improve the removals service, and reduce the total departmental cost. Speedier arrangements for delivery of members' own furniture would be more beneficial to a larger number of members and measures to achieve this aim have therefore been given higher priority.

Many difficulties are foreseen in the practical implementation of the hiring scheme as suggested, with the result that there is not complete agreement between the Services as to its viability. These aspects are being further investigated but it is not expected that it will be possible for a firm decision to be taken on its introduction or otherwise until early next year.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Telephone Installations, Woolloongabba Exchange Area, Brisbane

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 16 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are approximately 200 people waiting for telephone installations in the Woolloongabba Exchange area in Brisbane.

(2) Were staff from that exchange reallocated to the South Brisbane Exchange to clear a backlog of work there; if so, did the reallocation of Woolloongabba staff cause staff shortages and service difficulties in the Woolloongabba Exchange.

(3) Is it the intention of the Government to persist in the imposition of staff ceilings while several thousand Australians are waiting for new telephone installations and congestion of exchanges increases.
(4) Will he cause Telecom Australia to cease immediately the spending of millions of dollars on national advertising to promote services which are not readily available to thousands of Australians.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based upon advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 16 March there were approximately 307 applicants awaiting provision of new services in the Woolloongabba Exchange district. Of these, 280 were deferred awaiting exchange equipment whilst the remaining 27 were delayed because of insufficient cable capacity in their area. About 300 of these deferred applications are now in the process of being connected.

(2) Installation staff were diverted from the Woolloongabba Exchange to the South Brisbane Exchange in mid-January to complete that project because of the larger backlog of potential subscribers awaiting service in the South Brisbane area.

The staff diverted from the Woolloongabba Exchange were additional to normal staff and engaged solely in the installation of new exchange equipment. Their withdrawal from this project had no detrimental effect on the quality of service provided by the Woolloongabba Exchange as the normal maintenance staff remained.
(3) The Government no longer requires Telecom to observe staff ceilings.

(4) Telecom regards advertising as essential to give its customers an awareness of the wide range of products and services it provides. At the same time Telecom endeavours to ensure that its advertising is within the bounds of customer acceptance. In line with this, action has been taken recently within Telecom to scale down some of its newspaper advertisements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to reports that the recent spate of publicity surrounding the Supporting Parent's Benefit has been interpreted by some as an attempt to create a community perspective pending changes of benefit policies and procedures.
(2) Are the policies and procedures affecting benefit payments and in respect of recipients being revised, or is such a revision planned.

(3) In particular, are counter payments of special benefits to be reviewed; if so, will benefit recipients and community and voluntary agencies be given the opportunity for direct input into any such review before changes are made to departmental policies and procedures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware that there has been comment and speculation in the press in recent times on matters relating to supporting parent's benefit. I am unable to comment on how these media reports have been interpreted in certain sections of the community.

(2) The provisions of the 1982-83 Budget in relation to my portfolio have shown that there are no changes to existing eligibility conditions for supporting parent's benefit. Existing provisions which require a claimant to take reasonable action for maintenance will be applied. Additionally, the law has been amended so that supporting parent beneficiaries are subject to the same income test as are widow pensioners-where maintenance for a child in excess of $ 6 per week is received, the excess will be treated as the income of the supporting parent beneficiary.

As is the case with all social security programs, supporting parent's benefit is subject to constant review to ensure that procedures employed effectively implement policy and that policy continues to be relevant in the light of changing circumstances.

(3) A claim for supporting parent's benefit is determined as quickly as possible but where a delay is likely and hardship is evident, a counter payment may be made. There is no proposal to alter this procedure.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 24 August 1982:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Answering of Questions on Notice: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 25 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the details of the Minister's arrangements for the answering of questions on notice, specifying what officers (a) on the Minister's personal staff and (b) within the Minister's Department, are responsible for (i) examining the questions asked (ii) preparing the answers.
(2) How many questions on notice, from senators and members, has the Minister been asked from 25 November 1980 to date.
(3) What is the average delay incurred between the time of questions being placed on notice and the provisions of the answer.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Industry Research Associations: Federal Government's Funding

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 15 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which industry research associations operate at the present time.
(2) What arrangements exist for Federal Government financial support for each of these associations.
(3) What has been the Federal Government's funding for each association over each of the past 10 years, including the appropriation for 1982-83.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are a number of organisations which have the general characteristics of industry research associations, that is they perform or contract out research and development work and provide technical information and consultancy services for their members.

Under its research associations program the Government supports five associations which carry out these functions through income derived from members ' subscriptions and which make the results of research available to all members.
Support is by way of block grant administered through my Department.
(2) Those receiving block grant support are:
Bread Research Institute of Australia;
Sugar Research Institute;
Australian Welding Research Association;
Brick Development Research Institute;
Radiata Pine Research Institute (approved in 1981)

In 1980 the Government announced its policy of increased support for new and existing research associations. Currently, new associations may be assisted through a once-only establishment grant of $40,000 and payment of an annual grant on a dollar for dollar basis, up to a maximum of $200,000, for a period of up to 5 years. Levels of support for associations recognised before 9 September 1980 is determined in the context of existing agreements.

The five associations supported through my Department receive grants which match industry research contributions in ratios either 1:1 or 1:2, up to certain maximum grant limits; in two cases (Sugar Research Institute and Bread Research Institute of Australia) this limit has been reached.
To gain recognition under the research associations program associations must fulfil certain criteria, two of the more important being:
securing adequate levels of financial support from industry;
disseminating research results funded by the grant to all members.

One other association, the Australian Wine Research Institute, receives support through my Ministry and the Department of Primary Industry. That Department's 1982-83 grant appropriation is $225,000 and the 1982-83 appropriation for the grant administered by CSIRO is $22,600.

Several other organisations which perform research obtain Federal Government support by means other than the research associations program. For example the Australian Mineral Industries Research Association recieved $150,000 in 1981-82 under the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme which is administered through my Department.

In addition the Australian Mineral Industries Research Association and the Australian Coal Industry Research Laboratories have been supported by grants administered by the National Energy Research Development and Demonstration Council. Enquiries on details of these grants can be directed to my colleague the Minister for National Development and Energy.
(3) Levels of Federal Government funding over each of the past 10 years for research associations covered by my portfolio are as follows:
Radiata

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 12 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in the British newspaper, the Guardian of 19 September 1982, entitled 'Power from Wind'.
(2) What investigations have been carried out in Australia on the feasibility of using wind power in suitable locations, including island locations.
(3) Does Flinders Island, Tasmania, have a problem arising from its lack of a link with the Tasmanian power grid.
(4) What are the estimated electrical power needs of Flinders Island.
(5) How many megawatts of power are currently generated on the island.
(6) What would be the estimated cost of linking Flinders Island to the Tasmanian electrical power grid.
(7) Does Flinders Island represent a suitable location to utilise wind power.
(8) What contribution would a 3 megawatt capacity windmill make to Flinders Island's power needs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The article refers to a plan to build an experimental 3 megawatt wind generator on Orkney, to be completed in 1985 at a cost of #6m. This experiment, and other similar experiments in the United States of America and Europe will be monitored by the Department of National Development and Energy.

(2) Considerable effort has been devoted to the investigation of wind power in Australia. Projects include the Bass Strait Wind Energy Study undertaken by the Tasmanian Hydro Electric Commission with support from the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration (NERD&D) Program. The project recorded wind characteristics at selected sites on King and Flinders Islands, in order to assess the feasibility of using wind turbines to supplement the existing electricity supply.
Other wind power projects in Australia include: Projects associated with islands:
collection of wind data on Lord Howe Island by the University of New South Wales
installation and monitoring of a 50 kilowatt and a 22 kilowatt wind power generator on Rottnest Island by the State Energy Commission of Western Australia
Other projects:
various projects involving collection of wind data in North-West Tasmania, the Australian Capital Territory, North-Western New South Wales and the Northern Territory;
collection of wind data from 550 locations throughout Australia by CSIRO, for a continental Wind Assessment;
testing and demonstration of a Dunlite hybrid energy system, producing electricity both from wind and from photovoltaic cells;
testing and display of small wind electric generators by the Gas and Fuel Corporation in Victoria;

investigations by CSIRO, the Australian National University, the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology and the University of Western Australia, into the feasibility of supplying wind-generated electricity to State electricity grids; and
development of a vertical axis wind turbine for water pumping by Royal Military College Duntroon.

(3) As with most islands and remote settlements in Australia, Flinders Island relies on diesel generators for electricity generation. This results in electricity generation costs in excess of those prevailing on the Tasmanian mainland, which is reflected to some extent in the tariffs charged by the responsible authority, the Hydro-Electric Commission of Tasmania.
(4) Electricity consumption for the year ended 30 June 1982 was 1 million kilowatt hours. Over the past six years electricity consumption has increased at an average rate of 9.0 per cent per annum.
(5) Flinders Island currently has an installed diesel generating capacity of 400 kilowatts (kW). In 1980-81 the maximum demand for electricity was 280 kW.

(6) As far as I am aware no estimates of the cost of linking Flinders Island to the Tasmanian grid have been made. However, considering the high capital costs of undersea transmission cables and the relatively small quantities of electricity required it could be assumed that electricity supply from the Tasmanian grid would be much more expensive than diesel generation on the Island itself.

(7) The Bass Strait Wind Energy Survey has shown that both King and Flinders Islands have relatively high wind energy potentials. Average wind speeds at an optimal location on Flinders Island were in the order of 37 kilometres power hour. However the suitability of wind energy as a power source also depends on its economics, electricity load patterns, availability of reliable technology and availability of maintenance services.

The responsibility for the provision of power to Flinders Island rests with the Tasmanian Government, specifically with the Tasmanian Hydro-electric Commission. The Commission has investigated the use of wind generators to supplement power supply on the Bass Strait islands. Our understanding is that the investigations have shown that the use of wind power on these islands is not practical at this stage. The situation could change in the future as considerable world effort is being devoted to the development of improved wind generator equipment.
(8) A 3 megawatt wind generator would be far in excess of the Island's total electricity requirements. Smaller units of up to 100 kilowatt capacity could be more appropriate for Flinders Island.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Following performance tests of the contenders for the provision of a 155 mm medium gun, did the gun eventually chosen meet the required accuracy and distance specifications.
(2) Is it a fact that in subsequent testing the chosen gun has shown a consitent failure to achieve (a) accuracy and (b) distance specifications.
(3) What was the (a) accuracy and (b) distance specification for the gun.
(4) What was the (a) accuracy and (b) distance achieved by the chosen gun in (i ) pre-purchase tests and (ii) tests since purchase.

(5) If the gun achieved better performance at accuracy and distance in pre- purchase tests, was this due to modification of the gun under test, or have the guns used in later tests been sub-standard or had other defects.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (5) The evalaution of contenders for the provision of a 155 mm general support weapon system (which includes the ammunition), was based on the available performance data for the contending weapon systems and compared with the specifications developed by Army.
The specifications for the 155 mm weapon system are as follows:
(a) Range: 24,000 metres essential; 30,000 metres desirable.
(b) Accuracy: (1) For Line-One metre for each 1,000 metres of range
(2) For Range-2.5 metres for each 1,000 metres or range
This capability is being sought in two stages:
(1) The successful contender was the 155 mm M198 Howitzer now being purchased from the USA to replace Army's 5.5 inch guns. The M198 Howitzers are planned to enter service in 1984.

(2) Modern technology ammunition is currently being evaluated overseas by a team from Departments of Defence and Defence Support. A decision on the types of ammunition to be adopted by Army is expected to be made in 1983, following which arrangements will be made for manufacture of the high usage types in Australia for entry into service in 1988.

During evaluation of contenders for the replacement gun in 1977, none of the modern technology ammunition was available for firing trails to prove range and accuracy performance. Evaluation concentrated on assessing the contenders' characteristics against other requirements (eg., weight, mobility and ease of maintenance etc) and ensuring that the guns met the specifications required for the new types of ammunition now becoming available. The chosen weapon met this latter criterion.

Although evaluation is not yet complete the contending types of ammunition appear to meet range and accuracy requirements. This will be confirmed during the evaluation process, together with other factors such as cost, ease of manufacture and lethality. The choice will depend upon which contender best mets all requirements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 28 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the article by Mr Phillip Adams in the Bulletin of 21 September 1982 concerning the immigration status of Mr Michael Friedrich and his family
(2) If so, have the allegations made in the article been investigated.
(3) What action has been taken on Mr Friedrich's application for permanent resident status

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) I asked my Department for a detailed report so that I could thoroughly review Mr Friedrich's case.

The facts concerning Mr Friedrich are as follows: Mr Friedrich and his family arrived as visitors on 2 October 1981. Four days later in direct contravention of the undertakings they signed when they applied for their visitors visas, the Friedrich's sought permanent residence.
Mr Friedrich argued that because he had helped people escape from East Germany his life was in danger in his home country of West Germany.

In response to this my Department contacted the Australian Embassy in West Germany; the West German authorities confirmed that Mr Friedrich was an 'escape helper' but that he was in no danger while he remained in West Germany.
The fact that Mr Friedrich returned to West Berlin after he had arrived in Australia confirms this.
Mr Friedrich has been rejected for political asylum or refugee status becuase the country of his origin, West Germany, offers him adequate safeguards.
Indeed, West Germany has one of the best records of providing a safe haven for refugees.
Mr Friedrich has also been assessed in terms of Section 6A of the Migration Act and has failed to be eligible for the granting of permanent residence under this provision.
I am satisfied that there is no justification for the Friedrich's to remain in Australia. I expect them to depart from Australia before their temporary entry permits expire on 14 November, 1982.
Certainly the Friedrich's do have the option of lodging an application form in the proper manner once they return to West Germany.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he announce that the Government considered Nationale-Nederlanden's takeover of Mercantile Mutual Holdings Ltd would strengthen the position of Mercantile Mutual's policyholders and shareholders through the stronger financial backing provided by Nationale-Nederlanden.

(2) Did he obtain any commitment by Nationale-Nederlanden that it would assist Nationale-Nederlanden (Aust) in the event of future difficulties which the latter may experience; if so, (a) what is the nature of that commitment and (b) is it compatible with any Dutch law relating to the limited liability of shareholders; if not, what other guarantees do Mercantile Mutual's policyholders have.

(3) Does the Government intend to ensure, whether or not the shares in life or fire and general insurers are held by foreign interests, that policyholders with foreign-owned and foreign-controlled insurers are given protection equally as secure as that given to policyholders with Australian-owned or controlled insurers; if so, what steps will be taken to provide this protection.
(4) What proportion of (a) life and (b) fire and general insurance in Australia is placed with foreign-owned or foreign-controlled insurers.
(5) Does the Government see any dangers in an increasing proportion of life, and of fire and general, insurance business in Australia being controlled by foreign interests.
(6) What steps does the Government propose to take to prevent the domination of the insurance market by foreign-owned or foreign-controlled interests.

(7) Has the Government considered whether there may be a need to impose special requirements relating to the financial standing of foreign-owned or foreign- controlled companies engaging in (a) life and (b) fire and general insurance business; if so, what are the special requirements that have been considered; if not, what is the reason.

(8) In view of the Government's recent criticism of State government insurance offices, is there a need for action to be taken by his Government in the activities of State government insurance offices in respect of action by those offices which may be affecting the insurance industry generally; if so, what action will he take.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) On the basis of advice from Mercantile Mutual as to the difficulties it was confronted with and from Nationale Nederlanden on its proposed investment in Mercantile Mutual the Government accepted that a strengthening of the position of Mercantile Mutual's policyholders and shareholders could be expected to follow from the proposed 50 per cent equity participation in Mercantile Mutual by Nationale Nederlanden. In particular, Nationale Nederlanden emphasised its long term commitment to Mercantile Mutual. This equity participation was within the framework of relevant legislation including the Companies Act and the Insurance Act 1973 which do not require the giving of financial guarantees by parent or holding companies for subsidiary companies.

(3) The existing requirements of the Insurance Act 1973 and the Life Insurance Act 1945 imposed on foreign owned insurance companies carrying on insurance business or life insurance business in Australia are no less stringent than those applicable to Australian owned or controlled insurers.

(4) (a) The most recent Annual Report of the Life Insurance Commissioner indicates that, in 1980-81, foreign controlled companies accounted for 22.3 per cent of total life insurance premium income earned in Australia and owned 14.8 per cent of total Statutory Fund Assets held in Australia.

(b) No recent official statistics of this nature have been published. However, statistics published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics on 17 March 1978 indicate that, as at 30 June 1976, of the 215 general (non-life) insurance companies then operating in Australia, 107 were foreign controlled companies on the basis of the definition used by the Bureau; these foreign controlled companies wrote 37.8 per cent of business, as measured by premiums, in the year ended 30 June 1976.

(5) and (6) The insurance sector is one of the areas of the economy where, because of national interest considerations, the Government imposes restrictions on foreign investment. It is the Government's policy to require the parties to foreign investment proposals in the insurance sector to first provide opportunities for Australian investors to express interest in acquiring the target businesses. If the Government is satisfied that the parties have made reasonable efforts in this direction then for approval proposals by foreign interests to acquire or increase a substantial interest in an existing insurance company must demonstrate that substantial benefits would be expected to accrue to Australia, taking account of the implications of the proposal for the financial sector and for the level of Australian ownership. In respect of proposals by foreign interests to establish a new insurance company, for approval proposals must also show substantial net economic benefits to Australia or, where the net economic benefits are small, must involve an effective partnership between Australian interests and the foreign investor in the ownership and control of the new company concerned.

(7) See also (3) above. While the Government has introduced the Insurance Amendment Bill 1982 into Parliament for the purpose of strengthening the financial standards to be observed by all authorised insurance companies (ie both Australian owned and foreign owned and controled), it does not see a need for special additional standards to be imposed on foreign owned and controlled insurers. It is also pertinent to note that under the OECD Declaration on guidelines for multinational enterprises, Australia has agreed to accord to foreign interests treatment under laws and regulations no less favourable than that accorded in like situations to domestic enterprises.

(8) The Government's reference to State government insurance offices was mentioned in the context of one of a number of influences which had contributed to adverse underwriting results in the private sector of the general (non-life) insurance industry. However, the powers of the Commonwealth do not extend to insurance business conducted by the States except to the extent that the insurance business extends beyond the limits of the State concerned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic affairs, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Polish refugees have been received as immigrants to Australia since 13 December 1981.
(2) What was the total number of (a) European refugees (b) refugees from Indo- China and (c) refugees from all other countries in the same period.
(3) Does he foresee any increase in the number of Polish refugees entering Australia in the near future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Between 13 December 1981 and 30 April 1982, 2,392 Polish refugees arrived in Australia under the Eastern European refugee re-settlement program.

(2) In the same period (a) a total of 2,886 Eastern European refugees and (b) 5 ,176 Indo-chinese refugees arrived in australia. (c) In the period 1 December 1981 to 31 January 1982, 86 refugees arrived in Australia from all other countries. Statistics for subsequent arrivals of people in this category are not yet available.
(3) No, however, the situation is being kept under continuing review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 17 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Technical Committee on Agricultural Chemicals (TCAC) cleared mirex for use in Australia.

(2) If so, did the TCAC take into consideration the fact that mirex has been banned in the United States of America on the grounds that it is known to be carcinogenic, fetotoxic and teratogenic in mice and rats.

(3) Can he say whether the International Agency for Research on Cancer reviewed the evidence on mirex and cancer in 1979 and concluded that it is reasonable, for practical purposes, to regard mirex as if it presented a carcinogenic risk to humans.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Information concerning Clearances issued by the Technical Committee on Agricultural Chemicals (TCAC) is not made public as such information is deemed to be confidential. Premature disclosure could disadvantage the manufacturer by giving his competitors forewarning of his marketing intentions.

When the TCAC issues a clearance, the applicant is free to apply for registration in the States where it is intended to market the product. State registration authorities publish a list of registered products and information may be obtained from them on all products registered in their State.

(2) The TCAC, in its consideration of submissions for clearance of any proposed use of an agricultural chemical takes into account all available information concerning the chemical and assesses this information in the light of the form in which the chemical is to be applied and the conditions under which it is to be used. The evaluation of this information is designed to determine, in respect to each product and proposed use, the usefulness, effectiveness, safety to users , by-standers, consumers, crops, livestock, wildlife and the natural environment , and possible effects on trade.

In the process of evaluating each use for each agricultural chemical, the TCAC obtains the advice and recommendations of the National Health and Medical Research Council's Poison Scheduling (Standing) Committee and pesticides and Agricultural chemicals (Standing) Committee on poison hazard, toxicity and residue issues. This would include characteristics such as whether a compound was carcinogenic, fetotoxic or teratogenic. In all these matters the TCAC seeks to obtain concensus among the nine separate authorities and organisations involved before issuing Clearance.

(3) Yes. The International Agency for Research on Cancer has published two Monographs on the Evaluation of the Carcenogenic Risk of Chemicals to Humans relevant to mirex (IARC (1974) Volume 5, pages 203-210 and IARC (1979) Volume 20 , pages 283-301). On page 295 of the latter it is stated:
'In the absence of adequate data in humans it is reasonable, for practical purposes, to regard mirex as if it presented a carcinogenic risk to humans.'
